評論內容:
I have two issues
1, the parking prices! Absolutely disgusting, the amout of money they are extorting out of vulnerable people that are here to visit injured, sick and dying loved ones, its immoral and low! As an British infantry veteran of 18 years its blatantly clear to me that the employees that enforce parking at this hospital clearly have idea of the understanding of moral fibre or integrity, i would be hard pushed to find any lower form of human being other than criminals!

Issue 2
The public toilets! It states ALL GENDERS ! This is absolutely offensive to all intelligent people or anyone that possess any basic common sense! It should state BOTH GENDERS As there are only two genders (fact!)(ALL GENDERS) makes absolutely no logical sense?

I my opinion these are the only issues that need to be addressed in this hospital!

作者姓名: ¿Qué piensas, cariño? PODCAST Humor y más
評論內容:
My name is Manuel Priego I had an absolutely wonderful experience today at Addenbrooke’s Hospital in Cambridge. From the moment I arrived, every member of staff treated me with such kindness, professionalism, and genuine care. It’s rare to find a place where humanity and medical excellence go so beautifully hand in hand, but Addenbrooke’s truly achieves that balance.

The nurses, doctors, and support staff were not only incredibly competent but also warm, compassionate, and attentive to every detail. They made what could have been a stressful experience feel calm and reassuring.

Thank you to everyone at Addenbrooke’s Hospital for your dedication, empathy, and for reminding me how powerful simple human kindness can be in moments when it’s needed most.

You make a real difference — and it shows. 💙

評論內容:
God forbid to be seriously ill and counting on this hospital and its staff. I am trying for third day in a row to phone the Phlebotomy and book a blood test. Some may say - that's basic, right? Well, it is a  mammoth task - you can't find anyone on the phone line.

The first day I've waited 45 minutes being 4th on the que. At some point  I realized nothing is going to happen. Rang again minutes later only to be told by another recorded message that 'unfortunately' there are not enough operators to take my call.
The reception have pretty great opening hours - from 12 until 4:20.

I called the next day, when the recorded message about the lack of staff was the first thing I've heard. Same today, this time the message says there will be someone tomorrow. So my question is how many people work on reception and how many days per week?!
In my despair I decided to drop by and just wait on the line, hoping they might have time for me (just to remind everyone I am employed and I am paying for NI every single month)...No luck, I found a massive que of people and I was told they won't be able to take our samples, as they will be closing at 5.... I really want my money back for the non-existing services provided by the 'holy' NHS....

評論內容:
Whilst the staff were nice, the whole experience was awful. I receieved a phone call the day after I had surgery in King's Lynn, saying I must attend an ultrasound at Addenbrookes the following Tuesday.  I asked why and what basically told you have to, despite just having surgery.

Tuesday I'm driving to Addenbrookes as I have no one to take me.  After driving for 70 minutes, I receieve a call to say my appointment is cancelled until 8am the following day.  Waste of a 3 hour round drive for me then.

Wednesday I again drive the 90 minutes to get there (leaving at 5.45am).  To be told upon arrival they weren't aware I'd already had surgery and didn't need the ultrasound.  I had explained this to them the week before!!

So a 4 hour round trip, driving when I'm supposed to be resting, extortionate parking charges and a waste of petrol.

Really not happy, and a complaint has been written.

評論內容: Terrible hospital. I waited with my daughter,  7 hours in the treatment centre as she lay in bed,  before being told her procedure had to be cancelled. She was to have had the remains of a miscarriage removed which has now been in her for over 12 weeks after drugs failed. This was her first attempt at a pregnancy. She has been given no further date yet for treatment. As they only do this every Friday she will have to wait at least another week, if not much longer. I told the doctor that if she becomes infertile I will sue the hospital. I am now editing this post because my daughter has today been notified she is an emergency and will have to come into the hospital today with the prospect of the operation being carried out and yet she was sent away home again to return the next day with another promise that it will be done then. The department is not fit for purpose and if it was a supposed emergency the procedure should have been done there and then. It should never have got to this stage. I will continue to update the ongoing incompetence and negligence towards their patients until my daughter is treated and safe.

評論內容: Incorrectly diagnosed me from a CT scan.. misinterpreted it and ended up giving me a surgery.. after surgery admitted that the surgery was a failure and they decided to revisit my original scan, and confirmed they misdiagnosed and the surgery wasn’t needed! Was told surgery would be minimally invasive, would be sent home the next day and recovery would take a few days at home… 6 days later I am still in hospital in absolute agony every day. From the minute I came too after the surgery it was pure agony, needing injections of fentanyl, morphine, buscopan, oxycodone, dehydrocodiene. Have been able to eat or drink anything in nearly 4 days now. No fluids what so ever. Yet they keep trying to discharge me. 3 days in a row now they have tried to discharge me whilst knowing I have not had any intake of fluid or food. No bowel movement in 6 days now also. Removed me IV 3 days post op whilst I was still in so much agony and sickness and needed the IV medication. Yet they removed it anyway and gave me tablets only, fully knowing my throat is so sore and dry that I cannot swallow and even if I was able to swallow I threw them straight back up. Completely negligent doctors telling me the pain is all in my head. Finally agreed to be discharged just so I could take myself to William Harvey hospital instead. No wonder this place has SO many lawsuits against it

評論內容: This is the worst hospital I have ever been to first I went A&E the drs there were quite helpful I went there because I had not eaten properly in 3 weeks and had terrible stomach problems but more importantly I have lost all sensations to for the need to go to the toilet I already have spinal nerve compression diagnosed 10 months ago which can go into something called cauda equina which needs an immediate mri scan and if it is cauda equina a immediate operation I explained all this to the A&E drs who said they were going to send me up to the surgical team this is where the whole experience became disgraceful when I got there they said they were sending me for a scan I thought it was a mri scan but it was a ct scan because of my stomach issues I then saw a junior dr who listened to me then said she needs to talk her main consultant then he came to see me he was ignorant and very unhelpful they did not offer me any mri scan because in cases of possable cauda equina cases you cannot just look at someone and say they have it or not it has to be a immediate mri scan I told them I was getting numbness in legs and complete loss of sensation of needing to go to the toilet but still they didn’t seem interested and sent me home on my discharge paperwork it’s says asking my gp to look into cauda equina this is an absolute disgrace and I can promise if I do have cauda equina I will be suing this hospital because it causes permanent nerve damage unless diagnosed and treated immediately avoid this hospital like the plague

評論內容: I never expected such a horrible way to treat someone from this good reputated hospital. My daughter has some health issues and went to our local surgery and local hospital unfortunately as usual they didn't take the case seriously send her back several times saying take rest or paracetamol. Finally we decided to go to India and seen by couple of doctors there. When we described abut her they recommend to do some blood text and MRI scan they found she is having MS. They have done some treatment to avoid getting worse but they said as you are permanently staying in UK it is better to start treatment over there. If you want we can start treatment straightway but you have to come back continuously for further treatment, it is up-to you decid. Since it is very hard and fly over to India every time for the treatment is not possible and going to be very expensive,  we decided to get treatment back in UK but unfortunately I am very sorry to say that still now no treatment has started which made situation worse even after couple of visit over there. Sadly when my daughter try to contact the incharrge nuse many times couldn't get threw even got appointments letter after due rate. So she misses her appointments. It really made us so stressed and upset.if the treatment started earlier without making such delay the condition wouldn't get worse. Instead starting treatment each time they asked to do some test. Even after submitting all the prove of illness like CT scan, MRI  scan and all required blood test they didn't properly respond. That is why the condition got worse.

評論內容:
Here is a list of things that’s on my medical records but the doctors/nurses completely neglected to tell me about

bibasal atelectasis (bottom of both lungs collapsed)
Ovarian cyst
hiatus hernia (been showing signs for 10 years now)
2023 hypodense lesion on liver dome - 2025 hypodensities in liver
small pericardial effusion (liquid around heart)

I was however sent home with antibiotics for a uti, even knowing my blood work showed no signs of infection.

At what point did anyone think to bring this up? Some of these were found when I was heavily pregnant which was almost a year and a half ago. I will be reporting this as this must be some type of medical neglect at this point. This is extremely disappointing and the amount of distress this is now causing me and my family is insane. I hope you guys read this and are disappointed

評論內容: I give a one star for my personal experience and my Son's for the A&E department. I myself had been admitted to the A&E dpt three times over the last three years, each time with the same symptoms. Every time I was sent home feeling like I had caused a fuss about nothing and diagnosed with indigestion. I had appendicitis each time which showed on subsequent CT scans . After three years via a GP referral they finally took my appendix out (I cannot fault day surgery unit) Staff in A&E are neglectful and any doctor I encountered made me feel like I was the issue! Each visit consisted of a 12 hour wait in A&E. More recently (this week) my son broke his arm and wrist and waited 12 hours in total in A&E, he has to have an operation as the break is so bad. He was sent home in a soft cast and told he would have a phone call for surgery within the week, two days left and it's Easter weekend, so I doubt he will be called in. Sent home with minimal painkillers and the only phone numbers he was given are answerphones! Very sad to say but Addenbrokes screams out failing under the NHS hospital!

評論內容: I would give it ZERO. 5 years ago I’d have given it 5*. My Uncle spent 23.5h in A&E with a SEVERE fast spreading skin infection & infected diabetic ulcer which they said is fine till i insisted they swab to check there is an infection then they did a swab and confirmed it is infected, he’s lucky it hasn’t lead to Sepsis. After 2 days he finally has a meal, with HALF a potato & tinned fruit. It’s day 4 in hospital, no progress. They aren’t giving him all his daily medication as “doctor needs to prescribe it”. One medicine he usually takes 600mg, they’re giving him 200mg in 25mg tablets. The floor is dirty in ward C7. There was a safety hazard on the floor by his wonky chair all these days till I gave it to the nurse by hand to move. They removed a catheter whilst he was asleep leading to leakage all over his bed. They didn’t bother waking him up or waiting till morning. I’m appalled. They refuse to inform his vascular consultant that he’s admitted here. Nurses only know information they read off a computer otherwise “I’m not too sure, we can tell you tomorrow”. Since Monday they said an MRI needs to be done to confirm no bone infection. Now they don’t need to do an MRI 🤷🏻‍♀️

評論內容: Non existent No Smoking policy.  I regularly cycle to Frank Lee Sports Centre as ex employee and often see people smoking on access roads, car parks and on site and evidenced by cigarette butts on ground.  I remind them that it’s no smoking and a hospital but where are the signs?  Noticed on TV that Bedford hospital had a very clear large sign saying no smoking site and no smoking beyond this point.  Even the Frank Lee Centre has ash trays in the outside area so smokers in full view of the crèche children and from the swimming pool and meaning us non smokers who are the majority can’t sit outside in good weather.  It shouldn’t be left to individuals to point out the issues with smoking.  Why doesn’t Addenbrookes take this seriously considering the impact on the NHS?

評論內容:
Terrible treatment just because my partner is young, The most bureaucratic waste of time I have ever seen (I work with governments and this is bad)

Day 1: Enter A&E just to be told that due to age, its not a problem, they do a nasal swab as an excuse to get rid of us saying the symptoms are due to a viral reaction. We request bloods and urine but are denied.
Day 2: Symptoms are much worse, ended up back in A&E this time they actually get us a blood test, 24 hours later they tell us that its an infection and get us a CT to check for inflammation namely because every symptom was screaming appendicitis (Colitis in the end).
Day 4: finally admitted to a ward, started on antibiotics and oramorph.
After this my partner was discharged a few days later with a new prescription for different antibiotics because the strain was resistant to the ones in hospital. It too me 1 and a half days to collect because I was mucked about by an Nward receptionist who clearly didn't want to help me, until I got a superior involved.

Finally they are now actively refusing to give us a fit note, we spent at least 7 days in the hospital even if only admitted for 5, they watched me wheel her out of the hospital because the furthest she could walk while recovering was to the cafeteria and back.

All of this could have been avoided if they just took us seriously the first time, either by nipping it in the bud before the infection got to the point of hospitalisation, or by putting her into a ward earlier so she could be monitored and administered treatment, completely avoiding the strife and pain we have now both been through (mental and physical)

If you can, please go anywhere else (within reason)

評論內容:
Addenbrooke's was my first ever experience of hospital while being ill. The staff were outstanding, not that I want to be ill again however this is definitely the hospital to be if you are unfortunate enough. I spent a total of 5 weeks at the hospital, mainly on dialysis & I could not fault the doctor's, nurse's & staff, they were so professional & comforting. I would also like to point out the food was extremely nice & a highlight of the day, wonderful place.
I never had the opportunity to thank you all for saving my life as I was moved to Heartlands Hospital in Birmingham on New year's eve 2015, so thankyou all from the bottom of my heart, with loves, huggs & kisses. God bless you.

評論內容:
Unfortunately I’ve needed A&E care every year for the last three.  Each time I’ve been assessed pretty quickly really (under 2 hrs) and then received initial treatment and admitted onto a ward within 3/4 hours.    Care on wards (EAU &  Daphne gynae wards) has been very good.   Worst bit of the process is always waiting for the paperwork and medication on day of going home, it’s tended to be at least 6 hours.   Also, parking is ridiculously expensive, unfair when someone is coming to see you each day.
However, feel fortunate to have Addenbrookes on doorstep.

評論內容: We were seen this evening in clinic 9/out of hours GP - Dr Mohit (I think Sharma was the last name but I am not 100% sure) - fantastic, thorough and patient. Didn't feel rushed, took his time to properly assess and explain why he thought our son had an infection (which we suspected already, hence getting him seen). You do hear a lot of horror stories about the NHS as most people leave reviews after a bad experience so here we are leaving one after a positive experience because good doctors are still out there! :) Thanks so much Dr Mohit!

評論內容:
11November 2024
My partner and I are kiwis and have been traveling in our motor home for 3 months around England and Europe. We both developed bronchitis and as we are leaving to go back to NZ we needed to get treated. We were advised to go to A&E by local doctor being non resident. A&E was having an exceptionally busy day. Every metre of space was filled by patients, staff, equipment and refreshment cart!
We were registered, triaged, swabbed, CXRed,  ECGed, blood samples with cannula, led to 3 different areas of department by Coomby?? And seen by Dr Adele Baig.  Without exception all staff from registrar to giving us antibiotics were smiling, unphazed by the seeming chaos efficient and thorough. We were offered free refreshments through the day.
I am a nurse and couldn’t speak more highly of the care. Most impressed. Thank you so so much. Please pass on to staff

評論內容:
I had an appointment for Zoledronic Acid Infusion at 11 am today. I turned up dutifully early at 10.17 am.
Sadly, I was turned away and proceeded until 12.45 pm being sent from pillar to post (namely to Lister Hospital thence to Chelsea Outpatients Centre and back to Chelsea & Westminster).
Apparently, had I mentioned that I was there for Zoledronic Acid Infusion and not mention my consultant’s name, they would have had my name entry…
The fellow at reception did apologise profusely. However, the system needs to change. I was a private patient and do not pay hefty fees for such service.
Further, the infusion itself was not without issue. The nurse tapped into to a nerve which was excruciatingly painful - until she found a blood vessel that she ought to have used - there were plenty there.
Otherwise, it was a comfortable and pleasant experience. I award 3 stars in the hope for a system change. 🙏🏽

評論內容:
I had a very disappointing experience with my recent appointment. I was told I would be seen by a specialist who would examine the lump on my face and help me understand what’s going on. My appointment was at 9:30, and I arrived on time, but I had to wait another 20–30 minutes before being called in.

When the doctor finally met me, he only talked to me briefly and didn’t examine the lump at all. Then he left the room for about 30 minutes and came back saying everything was fine and that I shouldn’t worry. I tried to explain that I have headaches and that the lump is painful, but he didn’t really listen and just told me to do massages and use warm compresses.

How am I supposed to do that if it hurts and I still don’t even know what the problem is? I left feeling completely unheard and without any real help.

評論內容:
Subject: Unsafe and Sporadic Accident and Emergency Diagnosis Process – Equality Act Compliance and Professional Conduct Concerns
Unsafe and sporadic Accident and Emergency diagnosis process with front-line nurses and doctors that are not trained in the Public Sector Equality Act, Section 149, and the anticipatory duty they are supposed to have implemented well in advance of 2025.
It's not just about communication — as I complained to the Chief Executive, who rambled on about everything but the fact that I was treated in an inappropriate "sexist" manner by the male doctor, as he called me dear and darling to minimalise my pain and did not approach the appointment professionally. He dismissed my complaint of pain in the middle of the wrist and up the side arm bone and told me to go to physiotherapy. He said they didn't have physiotherapy at Chelsea. He treated me as if I had no pain and talked over me, disregarding my comments until the final part of my appointment. Instead of focusing on his job, he was chatting to the other female registrar doctors and making more "sexist" snide remarks to them about "being off for maternity leave and perhaps maybe going to work in gynae was better suited for her return."
I also heard the same man speaking to two different female patients who came in with chest pain and heart palpitations.
The doctor dismissed the female patients’ symptoms as heartburn, when it is well known that women's heart attacks are often ignored — and as age increases, the percentage of women who die from undiagnosed heart disease and heart attacks goes up, whereas men's does not. While I was listening, I heard two men who had been out during the weekend drinking and smoking (which they said was not their normal behaviour) and who had chest pain. They were given ECGs and all of the necessary tests to make sure they were okay. The unconscious bias and sexism in that Accident and Emergency team is unlawful. It is also evident that they are not trained in how to ask the right questions.
I went to a different hospital, and I did have concussion — because I went to Kingston Hospital, they took a CT scan, and then the consultant listened to my symptoms and said yes, this might take up to five weeks to settle down because I was vomiting — that was not because of ibuprofen. I've been taking ibuprofen for 30 years! The fact that they try to sidestep their responsibilities and then push their accountabilities onto failing machines or primary care is unacceptable, unsafe, and does not take account of the duty of care.
Even if there isn't funding or enough staff, or if male staff are not trained in how to communicate with females in a non-sexist manner that doesn't dismiss women's pain as normal — or with neurodivergent patients like myself, who are also suffering from trauma — they should have trauma-informed training and induction face-to-face, like it used to be when I used to run those courses as part of human resources provision. Treating different patients at a lesser level than those who have no neurodivergent needs puts them at a substantial disadvantage compared to somebody who doesn't need additional support. A person who has previous trauma — and is not asked about it — may be triggered when inappropriate questions are asked or when sexist behaviour occurs.
Human Resources and the Training Department for Equal Rights and Equality under the 2010 Protected Rights Act, and their duty under Section 149, need to look at trauma-informed care and trauma injury after-care.
If I had a child or a family member, I wouldn't be recommending Chelsea anymore because of the way my complaint was dealt with — which was vague and made it sound inconsequential

評論內容:
Happened to give a birth at this place. Should have listened to my colleague who said to avoid as her mom called police on them when she was in labour and passing away as they were rejecting to do c section. Thought they were overreacting. I came myself there with my husband and mom on Saturday with contractions lasting 1 min in every 2. They admitted us but kept asking if I want to get discharged as my labour is not progressing when it was lasting already 2 mins with 30 secs break in between. From Saturday on Sunday my water finally broke, I asked them what can I do to progress it as from their side there was no help given. Being in complete agony, felt more like they were waiting for me to pass away. There was no offer of C section at all after 2 days in labour. There was only 1 warning been given to me if they continue observing me then I might get an infection. On Saturday night I was admitted to an emergency room as apparently the infection happened. Still no C section was offered, they asked me to sleep by giving me at that point all injections and pain relieves. I woke up at 4am seeing heart off my baby reaching 190 flashing red, I screamt to get me a doctor and begged to cut me to save poor child as being with no water and now heart......... absolutely traumatic experience. At the end doctor asked me to push as at that point it would have been quicker. TG baby is fine. I have lost 2 litres of blood, had an instrumental delivery, several cuts until middle of my bum cheek. Been held in there until Thursday and begged them to discharge me as if I stayed longer I would have litteraly died as they didnt even know what infection I had and asked me where it hurts to understand where the infection is. I have been given plenty of injections I didn't need. As soon as I get home I started feeling better by not taking any medication they gave me. It's crazzzzy you lose 2L of blood, 7 people in the room returning you to life but blood was offered only in few days, just a day before wr have discharged.
FYI the food they give there is soooooooo bad that makes you even more sick
One positive thing there was an amazing female nurse and 1 great female doctor who helped us to escape this place

評論內容:
Compassionless and Negligent Baby Loss Care

I chose Chelsea and Westminster for my maternity care and initially had a positive midwifery experience. However, when my baby died, the care I received was terrible. If I had known how unsupported I would be in such a devastating situation, I would have chosen another hospital. I’m sharing my experience in the hope that no other woman will go through what I did.

At nearly 13 weeks pregnant, I attended the hospital for my scan. The sonographer called in a colleague, then told us the baby was measuring 10 weeks and 2 days. We initially thought she was saying the baby had been dated wrongly. Then she said there was no heartbeat. I asked if there was any chance of a mistake — I’d had two previous healthy scans — but was told no. I was given a leaflet and tissues, but no explanation or support. I only realised I’d had a missed miscarriage after overhearing the sonographer on the phone. We were sent home in shock, told another department would call.

The next day we went to the Early Pregnancy Unit (EPU). I sat in tears in the waiting room for over an hour, surrounded by other patients, including a woman with a young baby. My partner asked for help, but staff were indifferent. Eventually, we were taken to a private room. I was told I needed urgent surgery and asked about our preferences for our baby's remains. We were also offered cytogenetic testing, which we agreed to and paid for.

I later attended for surgery, having completed electronic consent forms and elected private cremation for our baby. When we arrived at the Day Centre, my partner was told he couldn't be with me (which I later found out was due to building work) — with no compassion or regard for our situation. I was left alone, visibly distressed. Another patient tried to comfort me, but staff showed little awareness or care.

I was placed in a curtained-off area with chairs, not a proper bay (dressings were stored there and a staff member’s belongings). I felt incredibly vulnerable without privacy. Staff seemed unaware of what surgery I was having or which medications I needed. I asked six different staff members about misoprostol and anti-D. No one seemed to know. I had to show them my patient leaflet. I was distressed and alone, without an advocate.

Only the anaesthetist showed any real kindness. When I finally saw the surgeon, he rushed through the consent process and only discussed our baby's remains. He filled out a new consent form — incorrectly. I was too upset to notice, and this error meant our wishes may not have been followed. We had to chase this through multiple calls and emails to both PALS and the EPU — none of which were answered.

Before surgery, I was told I would be placed on a maternity ward when I woke up — which, after losing a baby, was deeply upsetting. Thankfully, I wasn’t. I was discharged later that day, with no follow-up plan.

Within 24 hours I had severe pelvic pain and later heavy bleeding. I contacted the EPU and was told to wait and see. After further bleeding and calling again, they agreed to scan me. I was told I had retained products of conception. I was offered three options — more surgery , medication, or waiting ). All had further complications risks so I was told to wait three more weeks. I felt completely unsupported.

Due to the poor care I had received, I sought a private second opinion. I was told I needed urgent surgery and paid to have this done. The removed tissue was necrotic — I was told I was lucky not to have developed sepsis, which is life threatening.

At no point was I offered psychological support for my baby loss or the trauma that followed. We made repeated attempts to clarify the mishandled consent form. The only real compassion came from the hospital's chaplaincy team, for which we are deeply grateful.

Nine months on, I am still undergoing treatment and investigations. I wonder how much of this could have been avoided with better care from the outset.

I strongly advise other women to seek maternity care elsewhere. I will never return to this hospital.

評論內容:
On 19/09/2025 at 17:15 I called Chelsea and Westminster Hospital with a GP referral for an urgent X-ray for my partner who has a broken foot and is in severe pain. What I experienced was beyond unacceptable.

The receptionist who answered the phone was rude, dismissive and aggressive from the very start. Instead of offering help or guidance she repeatedly snapped that I had the wrong department and that the X-ray department was closed and nothing more. When I politely asked for the correct number or at least some clear instructions on how to proceed she refused, spoke to her colleagues while I was still on the line and then hung up on me.

This is not just unprofessional, it is dangerous. Patients and families call hospitals when they are in pain, distressed and in need of urgent direction. To be treated with hostility, to be denied even the most basic information and then to be cut off is disgraceful.

Hospitals are supposed to be places of care and compassion but this interaction showed the exact opposite. If staff cannot handle calls with decency, patience and respect they should not be in a role where people’s health and safety depend on them. Allowing such behaviour not only erodes trust in the hospital but also risks leaving patients without the urgent care they need.

I am shocked and appalled that Chelsea and Westminster Hospital allows staff like this to represent them at the front line. I expect this incident to be investigated properly and I sincerely hope no other patient has to experience the same treatment.

評論內容:
⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️ A heartfelt thank you to every incredible NHS staff at Chelsea and Charing Cross Hospitals.

I recently had to be admitted to hospital with a severe throat infection, and from the moment I walked into Chelsea and Westminster Hospital to my transfer and stay at Charing Cross Hospital, the care I received was nothing short of exceptional.

Every single member of staff — from the kind and calm receptionists, to the attentive nurses, skilled doctors, porters, and the two amazing paramedics who transported me — treated me with genuine compassion, professionalism, and dignity. I felt seen, heard, and cared for every step of the way.

The NHS is a cornerstone of life in the UK, and this experience has only deepened my appreciation for it. The dedication, teamwork, and humanity shown by these brilliant individuals was flawless.

The NHS is more than a service — it’s a lifeline, and it must be protected at all costs. I am beyond grateful. Thank you all.

評論內容:
My Birth Experience at Chelsea and Westminster Hospital – A Mixed Journey

Some parts of my care were excellent — especially the antenatal clinic visits with the obstetricians, and my C-section delivery, which was handled superbly by a kind and professional theatre team. However, the antenatal visits with midwives lacked continuity and consistent messaging. During my admission for pre-eclampsia, I felt overlooked, and unfortunately, the postnatal ward experience was poor — marked by substandard care, minimal communication, unexplained delays, and missing discharge medication. The only bright spot postnatally was one truly brilliant midwife — thank you, Ruth. While I’m grateful for the delivery care, I left feeling disappointed overall and won’t be returning for future pregnancies.

I cannot express enough how grateful I am for the exceptional care I have received at this hospital. Every time I have visited, the staff have gone above and beyond to address my needs and ensure I felt comfortable and cared for. From the attentive nurses to the knowledgeable doctors, everyone here truly cares about the well-being of their patients.

評論內容:
I recently gave birth here having an emergency C-section after being transferred from another hospital, the Drs and nurses have all been lovely to me, but I have to say, all the money put into this hospital to give a state of the art private maternity unit and the budget couldn’t be stretched the the NHS side to give us ladies there some air conditioning? The whole ward; bays, units, and side rooms are ridiculously hot, there’s absolutely no air flow throughout the place, there’s no fans for the patients to use, the nurses have those awful plastic chairs to sit on which will make them sweat too; I’ve been in just over a week now and I’m having to have my bedsheets changed daily because I’m soaking them in sweat.
Why can’t the nhs Maternity ward have air conditioning? Is having air conditioning only a privilege for the well off to have?
PLEASE SORT THIS OUT!

The staff at this hospital saved my sisters life and helped her deliver her baby safely at 26+ weeks of pregnancy.
The NICU ward and staff are amazing, people well trained who know what to do in any situation. The doctors on the maternity ward same, we had a Spanish lady doctor who explained everything that was about to happen when I arrived at the hospital with my sister because of preeclampsia and HELP syndrome. She was brutally honest and told  me the chances are what they are but she and the teams will do everything for both of them, and they did.
ICU staff, again very kind and professional, the care they give is top class.. Sabrina and her colleagues were amazing those 20 something days my sister was on the ward.
Can’t praise them enough for what they did.

評論內容:
I was taken into Chelsea and Westminster Hospital after badly injuring my leg which left a deep wound. Firstly, an ambulance arrived very quickly and I was taken into the urgent care unit. I did have to wait some time however all the staff were courteous and pleasant under extremely difficult circumstances including a bigoted old man being abusive to the staff. The waiting room was absolutely packed , obviously lots of people with very minor issues that they could see a GP about turn up at A&E.
Both Doctors Liam and Michelle were wonderful , they cleaned and patched me up and arranged for a bed as I was to have surgery the next day to deep clean and excavate the wound . There was a bed available in the Gynaecology ward Annie Zunz.
The staff that looked after me in that ward were absolutely wonderful, both day staff and night staff. Nadine, Ito , Mercy and the team are so caring , compassionate , kind and respectful. The ward was kept Immaculately clean and they are absolutely run off their feet. You could not wish for a better team looking after you. At the operation, the Consultant surgeon  , Orthopaedic staff and Anaesthesiologists were fantastic, putting me at total ease at every stage. I was looked after by the amazing Bola who was so caring and kind. I met people from all around the world in that hospital and I’m proud to say it’s what makes the NHS a fantastic organisation despite all their many challenges. Thank you to everyone at Chelsea and Westminster.

Thank you again
Many Blessings to you all
A Arefi ✝️

評論內容:
A disaster. We went to the Freeman having read that's the best place for blood cancer. My wife has a wheelchair, so she sat in that to wait. After several hours she saw a ",young man ",who didn't even know why she was there, or what was wrong. He told her to wait back outside and he would organise a scan. A couple more hours later  I asked a nurse how much longer it would be, to which the nurse replied "Oh, I forgot to do that "After another couple of hours, with no  contact  I decided to take my wife home, she was so tired sitting in a wheelchair for so long
In all, we were there over 5 hours, and still nothing done. If the Freeman is the best, heaven help the worst.

評論內容: I can’t thank enough the people in the Cardiology centre who have recently installed a new heart valve for me to improve and extend my life. From the first meetings to the leaving of ward 30 I was treated with the utmost respect and care from the surgeons, theatre staff, J&M in ITU and the many on ward 30. After several days on the ward they never put a foot wrong with great communication, care and attention to my needs, empathy and the feeling of all being in this together. I was happy to come home and settle into a process of slow healing but find myself daily to be thinking of those amazing people who all went above and beyond. Thank you so much to you all.

評論內容: I have just spent 10 days on ward 14 after a hip replacement due to a fall. I was extremely impressed with the care I received there. One example,  Cath was having “one of those days” but continued to show her caring and helpful nature to even one of the more difficult patients. However the majority of the staff were like that even through staff shortages.  I would also like to give special mention to Amber Egan who was always doing that little bit extra. I had been strong and cheerful from the start of my stay but eventually at 4.00 am on day 7, I hit a low and got upset.  Amber took the time to sit with me, to listen and comfort me and for that I will always be greatful.  The world could do with a lot more Amber’s

評論內容:
I recently visited the dental unit to have three infected teeth removed, and I can’t thank the team enough for the care I received. I’ve always had a huge fear of the dentist, but from the moment I arrived the staff were incredibly patient, supportive, and understanding.

They took the time to reassure me, explained everything clearly, and made sure I felt as comfortable as possible throughout the whole procedure. Their kindness and professionalism turned what I thought would be a terrifying experience into something manageable, and I left feeling genuinely cared for.

I’m so grateful to the entire dental team for their compassion and skill they went above and beyond for me. I would highly recommend this unit to anyone, especially if you struggle with dental anxiety.

評論內容:
I have a dancer review one day to be followed by an hour and one half meditation treatment by intravenous i fusion two days later, these two appointments every two or three weeks.  My transport from Hertfordshire is an old diesel car for which I have to pay Congestion and ULEZ payments, at the same time parking my car is only available via use of a local NCP Multi-storey carpark for which parking fees are extortionate.  Depending on the length of my appointments I pay between £11:80 and approx £37 each visit to this NCP, so in any one review & treatment week I can be out by up to approximately £100 which I self fund for my travel expenses.
I’d like to be able to reclaim at least some of these expenses, but the process to get this set up is too complicated…..

評論內容:
Guy’s Hospital is a good modern hospital, and my experience there was overwhelmingly positive from start to finish. Located in the heart of London, it’s a busy place, but everything from the organisation to the quality of care made it feel smooth and well-run.

The staff are the real highlight — every nurse, doctor, and support team member I encountered was kind, professional, and genuinely attentive. They took the time to explain things clearly and check in regularly, which made a huge difference in reducing any stress or anxiety. It’s clear that patient care is a top priority here.

The hospital itself is modern and clean, with up-to-date facilities and equipment. Even though it’s a large hospital, it didn’t feel overwhelming. The wards were well maintained, and hygiene standards were consistently high.

Appointments and procedures were well coordinated, and even when there were delays (which can happen at any hospital), communication was transparent, and staff remained helpful and calm. It’s also great to see how efficiently everything is run given how many patients they serve daily.

Overall, I felt safe, well cared for, and respected during my time at Guy’s. I wouldn’t hesitate to recommend it to others needing treatment or care in central London.

評論內容:
Guy’s Hospital is one of London’s leading medical institutions, known for its excellent healthcare services, skilled professionals, and advanced treatments. As part of Guy’s and St Thomas’ NHS Foundation Trust, it provides top-tier care across various specialties, including cancer treatment, cardiology, and dentistry.

The hospital is modern, clean, and well-equipped, with a dedicated team of doctors, nurses, and support staff. Most patients receive compassionate and professional care, and the hospital’s commitment to research and innovation ensures access to some of the best medical treatments available. Its location near London Bridge makes it highly accessible, with great transport links.

However, like many large NHS hospitals, it can get extremely busy, leading to long waiting times for some appointments and treatments. While the staff work tirelessly under pressure, the high demand can sometimes impact the overall patient experience.

Despite these challenges, Guy’s Hospital remains a reliable and well-respected medical facility, providing excellent care to thousands of patients each year.

評論內容:
The doctors and nurses in ICU and are phenomenal, they saved my mums life and granted her another two months with us and to not let our last memory of her be traumatic. I will forever be thankful.

Moving onto the Hedley Atkins ward, again Dr's and Nurses were all great except from one Dr Bliss, who proceeded to tell my my mum that she has an estimated 3 to 6 months left whilst making quips about how a tea and bourbon makes everything better and how we all have to go someway and it unfortunate this is how my mum has to go. Whilst my mum was crying. She was clearly so used to saying this to patients, and completely dissociated from the fact that she's telling someone about their immenent demise, that is their whole world. Jokes will never be appropriate in that instance.
I found it cruel and disgusting, even the junior Dr who was with her came back after and showed compassion and care. She should go to additional training on how to stay professional when delivery delicate news, you think it would be common sense, but evidently not.

Other than that one instance, the hospital staff really do care and work very hard.

評論內容: I would NOT recommend this hospital. Ask to go anywhere but to JR or WPH.The neurosurgery department, especially the consultants are negligent and show no value of a life. Its very much a conveyor belt system. Al the staff stick together, including external staff. Note: JR is a university hospital and students would need to practice some place. where do that?.at a university hospital?..and why are patients brought and admitted far and wide to this particular hospital, instead of most other much better and closer hospitals. Because its a perfect provision for students.  My relative was admitted  Dec. 2024. A time of year when most doctors and  staff with any useful  appropriate knowledge have long gone on leave. And you are left in the hands of whatever staff.... My relative had two seizures soon after her surgery..this was picked up by a relative as patient seemed to be shaking. Nurses were sat a few inches on tall stools inches from our relatives bedside, with top of the range equipment monitoring her, which they were supposed to watch. In spite of all these provisions they missed to notice that her having seizures.How did they fail to notice the seizures? Because most of the time, instead of looking at the patient or the monitoring equipment they were on their phones. These were the staff we were looking to, to keep us in the know about how our relative was doing etc to watch out for any seizures. After this our relative was left in a vegetated state...all because of their neglect..unfortunately there is no way of proving this or any kind of neglect..there is also no way of knowing whether our relative was operated on by a practicing student. Worse still is, that in spite of all bad treatment by JR and WPH our relative is doing realy well because of the family's commitment and encourageme..it really upsets the family that medics at WPH and JR are denying our relative the help she was offered. And the consultants do not  work with the family.

評論內容:
Was sent here by 999 because I am in a high-risk group being 7 months pregnant, with a known weak immune system and asthma.
They kept me sat on a horrible uncomfortable chair for over 6 hours in A&E with a 40c temperature while I struggled to breathe properly, then told me I have flu and to go home and take paracetamol.
They did not offer me antivirals after doing the blood test to confirm the flu, even though they knew my situation. They did not offer me nebuliser or inhalers even though they could see and hear me struggling to breathe. They did not offer me paracetamol to take home with so I was unable to medicate until the following day because we didn't get out of that place until midnight.

The hospital is terrible. The system is extremely slow and a lot of the nurses kept making obvious errors; one woman was called into the room for the same test over 3 times, until she had to tell them shes already done it and to please stop calling here in. Another patient was sent to a different department, only to be called out by name no less than 10 minutes later, we had to explain they've already sent him out. The nurses then only called the same 2 names for the next hour, even though neither of those patients existed in the room at all.

You are made to feel forgotten, unworthy and weak. The way they spoke to me to tell me "its just the flu, you can go home" made me feel so ashamed of even going in, regardless of me being high-risk. They did not care to check on my baby, they did not care to medicate me effectively before I left, they just wanted me gone so they can run the next person in and out of the doors.

Worst hospital experience ever from this place.

評論內容:
Would give no stars but that's not possible so giving one. I have had a lot of experiences with hospitals in all kinds of departments over the years and usually it's a mixed bag. I have never, ever in my life seriously considered taking legal action as a result of my treatment, even if I knew I could have and had the grounds and evidence to do so successfully. The John Radcliffe Hospital is the first I have seriously considered actually doing so as a result of my experiences (plural) there.

I hate leaving this comment because it feels so unfair to the very small number of very good and brilliant nurses (they were exclusively nurses, but not all the nurses) and other non medical staff members who don't deserve to be associated with this review, let alone any prospective legal action I do take (if I do) and I love and feel very protective of the NHS and so many who work within it. That said, at this point, if I have another serious medical emergency (likely but not certain) I will not be going to A&E, I will not be calling an ambulance. I would rather just cross my fingers and play it out than relive anything like my last experience there.

評論內容:
I’ve chosen the hospital hoping to have a safe experience for my childbirth. I was wrong.
Departments were closed due to lack of staff. I was in labour and in a queue for a delivery room!
My first nurse were on double shift and explicitly told me she couldn’t wait to go home, while my contractions were kicking.
After an emergency C section they put me in a room with other 5 new mums and no one gave me a plan or support with breastfeeding.
I left the hospital the day after the operation out of desperation.
Advice for first time mums, go to a smaller hospital where you are sure you will be taken care of.
Traumatised.

評論內容:
I have always had nothing but the utmost professional, honest and wonderful care during my many visits to the JR in Oxford. I am under the Neurosciences department. I am also under the neuromodulation team.

My surgeon, Ms Stana Bojanic has always been lovely, to the point and honest, which I love in a surgeon. Every conversation has been with a caring ear too, especially when I have had moments where I was struggling with pain and/or mobility issues.

Most of my primary care under the neuromodulation team I have dealt with Waclaw Batko and Clare Watson (with some intermittent conversations with others like Carmen Barbato) and all have been truly amazing! Their professionalism mixed with a bit of a softer side, perfect for their job roles for being in close contact with people who tend to be in a lot of pain makes them wonderful to have as a point of contact when we are struggling. They also manage to put things in an easily understandable way without making it worded like you are a 3 year old, as I’ve had with some hospitals due to knee issues in the past. I cannot put into words to praise them highly enough for how much they have helped me and changed my life with this device.

So a simple “thank you” to you all doesn’t seem enough. I’d also like to extend my thanks to all those in the respective teams… As I am well aware there are many that don’t get the thanks they need. Like the administrators and people on the reception desks who have always been so polite and always smiling. Which can make a huge difference when you’re in a lot of pain daily and don’t see many people out of the house.

評論內容:
I had a very positive experience at John Radcliffe Hospital in Oxford while receiving specialist care. The hospital was exceptionally clean and well-maintained, which immediately put me at ease.

The nurses were incredibly helpful and kind, always checking in and making sure I was comfortable and informed. The doctors were outstanding – not only highly skilled, but also compassionate and attentive. I felt confident in their expertise and appreciated the time they took to explain everything clearly.

From start to finish, the care I received was professional, respectful, and thorough. I’m genuinely grateful for the level of attention and support I received during my visit.

I would highly recommend John Radcliffe Hospital to anyone in need of specialist medical care.

I would say things get done a lot quicker when you remind the staff about yourself, ie I was in the gyno ward for almost an hour waiting for a doctor so I called the nurse to please check when the doctor is coming, he came quite quickly after that, then all other things like speeding up paperwork or removing iv needle and reminding them to take me to my ultrasound etc, they are very busy so may forget so you need to know where you need to go and they will make sure you get there. All in all I had a good experience.

評論內容:
Waiting hours on the emergency is way too long, no one has been seen in4 hours wait, it feels like doctors wait to give up waiting and go home! When feeling unwell it's torturing to wait 7 hours  tobe seen by a doctor (we arrived 20:30 pm and our turn was 3:30am)
sat on very uncomfortable chairs, pack of I'll people around you, poor oxygenation,  you feel asphixiated and need to be walking outside to get fresh oxygen,  no plants to filter the air for so many people in such a small space! There is a really loud fan noise at all times working like a massive extraction fan that could be heard anywhere in the waiting room. The place is highly depressing,  if they are not ill they will get ill just by being there. It doesn't feel doctors care about the waiting hours! Went to buy smt to eat but all shops were closed, tried using the only toilet available in the main (the disabled) and there were nowhere you could hang the coat, I was wearing a long coat, there was no way I could use the toilet wearing it or holding it! Also the toilet holder had 2 toilet rolls that you could not get any of them out, they were cut inside! So had to walk along the corridor to the next available toilets and even though there was no one cleaning there was a big yellow burrier in front of the doors, it had 4 toilets and they either had a broken lock ora broken coat hunger, the flush was not contactless which it shouldn't be acceptable in a hospital and it was half broken. If you ask Oxford citizens to donate 4 toilet locks a a few coat hungers, absolutely everyone will be happy to donate, and STOP asking monetary donations as we all know money gets missused, but instead create a donation system where people van donate what is actually needed!  I think Oxford van do better, there is no excuse like there are short of staff, pay them double and you'll see how much staff will be there working! Provide free health care education with bursaries and bonuses, encourage young people that aspire to become doctors, make medicine education more accessible, money is not the problem, it has never been, UK has enough money to built hospital for each city in the country! Cut parliament job positions in half and for each position is cut 10 doctors can be hired, the resolutions are endless...

評論內容: Absolutely appalling behaviour from a majority of the staff in the Lichfield Day Surgery Unit. My mother went in for a revision septoplasty and inferior turbinate out fracture procedure, we had to wait from 7.30am to 2.30pm for her to go down to theatre. The staff was constantly giving us false information about the waiting times and were really rude to us. They wouldn’t give my mother pain relief other than paracetamol and she was crying and thrashing around in pain for hours because of it. I am not impressed, if this is how they treated my mom imagine how they are treating your loved ones. As human beings you’d think that they would show some sort of compassion. Sort yourselves out.

評論內容:
I recently  had the "pleasure" of spending few hours in emergency waiting room.I was directed there by a nurse from 111, I went there in the middle of the night at the time the nurse had given me.The pain was unbearable,I stayed there until 6am, I was so much in pain that I couldn't wait any longer.I felt cold,uncomfortable, I tried to find comfortable position on the chair, tried to lie down on the floor,but It didn't help.I asked for something for pain, but paracetamol didn't help.After few hours I decided to go back home, it was already morning and my Health Centre was opening soon,so I thought I would see my GP sooner.
There were people in waiting area in even worse condition than mine and they waited even longer...
I do not blame the staff, because there are simply to few of them and it is getting worse..I do not recommend this place, but if you have to go there it is best to take with you blanket or sleeping bag and pillow and prepare yourself for hours of waiting..

評論內容: I have PKDS and they gave me medication that someone with PKDS cannot take. I had and still have severe pain from my lower back which has since spread to my knees. No one touched my doctor spoke to me for exactly 30secs (I recorded it) before sending me home with medication I shouldn't be taking. I called a&e and the person in charge of the phones hung up on 3 times and didn't answer 8 other times. I was in the hospital for over 12 hours and had a 30 second conversation without any Prognosis. Even the nurses took no notice of me. I wasn't given painkillers unless I asked for it whereas everyone on my ward was looked after and nurses took initiative on their behalf. Other patients were discussing to eachother about how they felt bad for me as I am by myself and there's no one to stand up for me. This is the kind of "small" negligence and "easy to make" mistakes that led to my mum's death in the same hospital. What you think are small mistakes, literally takes lives. What if I wasn't someone that reads the leaflet? I've only become that way because too many times have you (NHS) given me medication that can cause me more harm than good. All I wanted was an explanation for the medication choice or even for someone to say we knew you had PKDS but this medication will still be safe for you. At no time was I asked how I am doing or if I was feeling any better or worse. I'm so upset.

評論內容:
One of my family members became ill while we were enjoying a weekend at Oxford. Paramedics had to admit her to John Radcliffe with suspected gallstone attack. She stayed in for two days and from start to finish every member of staff were exceptional, from
A&E, to Resuc and SEU. Special thank you to the wonderful Doctor Ella in SEU.  The hospital is run with superb efficiency and great empathy. The staff of volunteers went out of their way to support all my family members. Excellent facilities, including M&S food shop &  café and separate food court, including Subway and 24 hour Starbucks.
The care and follow-up treatment were exemplary.

評論內容:
Disabled parking!

I take my elderly mum quite often to the hospital, she is 89 with dementia and heart failure. She has a disabled badge as she can't walk any more without help. Every time I go to the hospital all the disabled bays are full, with some people waiting in cars having dropped their passengers off at the hospital door then they go and sit in a disabled space while they wait, rather than pay for a spot or wait elsewhere. Today I drove around for over an hour trying to find a space, we were very late for our appointment.  There has to be a better system. My poor mum was so confused and tired at the end of it all.
The staff, as always were lovely.

評論內容: Sad to leave this review as I know most of the nhs are wonderful.  My wife experienced symptoms of retinal detachment.  We rang 111 who referred us to ring John Radcliffe eye care as it was a Sunday.  The man who answered the phone refused to accept her because she was just out of area even though 111 had referred us there.  You need fast service with this condition.  It turned out she had six to eight tears in her retina.  We ended up going to a and e in Gloucester who referred her to Cheltenham who were amazing.  The surgeon came and collected her as soon as she was seen in a and e and worked really hard to save her sight.  Cheltenham were absolutely brilliant.  John Radcliffe should learn some lessons from them.  She was refused treatment even after 111 had advised her to go to John Radcliffe because she was a little out of area.  The politics of logistics were put before her sight.

I know we can’t blame the staff but holy moly. This place is ridiculous. Every time I come here it seems to get worse and worse.

The first time I came here with my older brother who had sliced his hand open we were told to go and wait despite the fact his bandages weren’t helping with the bleeding.

The second time my brother who came off his motorbike and hit his head and complained of neck/head pain was discharged the next day as they ‘needed the bed’

Absolute disgrace. Minimum waiting time is now around 4 hours so you better hope it’s not life threatening otherwise you’ll be done for in the waiting room.

評論內容: My experiance was one of observation; Some staff working very hard and overloaded , others were seen their whole shift sitting around laughing and joking (this must be frustrating to their overloaded colleagues).  The main gripe I have is with the discharge time. I was moved from an ECU bed to the ward (7e) at 6.30am , told at 11am that I would be discharged imminently but nothing despite me reminding the nurses frequently until , eventually, at 8pm (9 hours later) I gave up and stormed out without any meds or discharge letter. The lady opposite me had to do similar and also complained. This ward 7e had nurses that seemed to enjoy antagonising the elderly patients and teasing them which I found utterly disturbing and no-one seemed to want to progress my discharge which would have freed up a supposedly 'much needed' bed. With apparent incompetence and lack of interest like this  is it any wonder the bed situation is where it is :(

評論內容:
Gaslit nightmare!
Suffered nasty fungal infection for 6 weeks now. Seen by 3 different GPs who all tried different treatments. Pain worsened on Saturday night so called 111 and was sent to Horton A&E early hours of Sunday morning. Doctor there was fantastic. Confirmed infection on sight and also called in a consultant who confirmed swelling was "bright, tight and hot to touch". So they immediately sent me to the John Radcliffe SEU via ambulance. In SEU triage, I saw a doctor who told me I need an MRI but the wait can be long, so how would I feel about going home and coming back when an appointment is available. I said no, this is horribly painful and I was sent here because it's urgent. On morphine overnight and saw a consultant on Monday morning rounds. He denied any sign of infection. I was gobsmacked. I asked to see a different doctor who, after going into a room with the consultant and nurse in charge of my care, came out and told me that he agreed with and trusted the consultants opinion - WITHOUT EVEN LOOKING. I asked him to see for himself which he did at protest. He denied seeing any infection. It felt surreal. I was scared, so I emailed PALS who were fantastic. They had me moved to a ward that night where a nurse and yet another doctor looked at me. They confirmed infection and have now been in a bed for 2 days waiting for an "urgent" MRI. Saw another Doctor on Tuesday morning rounds who asked me "what do you know about a fungal infection?" and proceeded to state that he believes I'm exaggerating the pain due to the fact that I'm autistic. What is wrong with the doctors here? This is terrifying.

評論內容:
I recently gave birth at the Golden Jubilee site and unfortunately had a deeply traumatic experience with one of the midwives. While some staff were compassionate and supportive, I experienced serious negligence and unprofessional behaviour that put my baby at risk.

On my first night after an emergency C-section, my baby was placed in a position that was unsafe and could have caused suffocation. Luckily, my partner noticed in time. Despite my repeated requests for support with basic care due to being heavily medicated and physically unwell, the midwife was dismissive, reluctant to assist, and at times made comments suggesting my baby was a burden compared to others in the ward.

Additionally, my concerns about my daughter’s breathing and reflux were dismissed as being “normal for a C-section baby,” which has now led to severe centile dropping. Her jaundice was also not properly monitored or treated once we left the hospital, despite her levels rising on several occasions. Medication was delayed, and my concerns were often ignored or dismissed, leaving me in tears and extremely anxious.

This experience caused significant emotional trauma and has seriously impacted my trust in healthcare professionals. While many staff at King’s were caring and supportive, the behaviour I experienced was unsafe and unacceptable. I sincerely hope the Trust addresses these issues so other parents do not go through similar distress.

評論內容: Absolutely amazing. I've been to many different NHS Hospitals as someone with chronic illnesses. The staff here during my visit yesterday were stellar. My immunologist was fantastic and took the time to actually listen to my medical history and background. I had a blood test afterwards and we had to get 8 vials of blood. As someone who is difficult to bleed, due to small veins, I am normally left feeling like a burden to the phlebotomy departments I encounter every couple of months. However, Kings Phlebotomy were impeccable. I had a female staff member take my blood initially but my difficult veins meant we only got 2 tubes of blood. She used her initiative and got her very experienced colleague to help with the rest of the bloods. 8 tubes in total. The man that took my blood was wonderful. Kind and patient. He had genuine empathy and was the nicest phlebotomy staff member I have met. I didn't get his name but was told people call him "the Vein Expert" and he managed to take blood out of my arms (which over 50+ phlebotomists have struggled to do over the last 5 years Ive had of poor health) Thank you so much to the lovely staff at King's College Hospital. You all deserve a pay raise

評論內容:
Broke my collarbone and failed to receive the appropriate follow up care, due to multiple mistakes, resulting in unnecessary pain and a long period off work.

Initially told to wait 2 weeks to see a doctor as which point they mistakenly thought I broke my collarbone that week. Was told to get an operation as it would allow me to go back to work but was mistakenly removed from the operation list.

Was eventually offered an operation date 5 weeks after the fracture, without any follow up appointments in between. At which point I had to insist on a new set of X rays. Was given three different opinions by three different doctors, only one of which actually bothered to look at my arm.

Caused me substantial amounts of stress trying to find out what was going on.

Three weeks since I was last told I would receive an MRI and physio, still nothing. Luckily I am able to work again now.

No idea what system they are operating on but it is very flawed and potentially very dangerous.

評論內容:
I am a NET (Neuroendocrine Cancer) Patient. I have been treated at various hospitals in London, The Royal Free, Guys, St Thomas' and Royal Marsden. I have had various, frankly not great, experiences with most of them. Usually not the Medics or Nurses  but most being badly let down by truly staggeringly terrible support and admin staff. The worst being Guys Cancer Centre by a long way.
Kings is such a relief. A breath of fresh air. I will admit I actually cried after my first appointment. Not because of any bad news but I had lovely receptionist, (I did not believe they existed within the NHS..like Hens teeth) charming helpful Nurse, absolutely lovely helpful Professional Dr. I had someone call me when I was on the train...30 mins after I left..asking when would suit me to schedule a scan! I had to ask him to repeat the question. They would suit me!! It was truly unreal. In 10 years of chasing, begging, pleading and asking for scans. (Good luck with getting one at Guys. Expect to go grey and lose your sanity arranging anything with them) They were asking me when suited me? I think its a public/private partner ship.
If only only NHS departments or units were run like the NET Cancer Unit at Kings.
Truly a shining light in a sea of absolute mediocrity.
I cannot speak for other departments but the NET Cancer team should be showing other Hospitals in London how it is done.
cleaned_text: i am a net neuroendocrine cancer patient i have been treated at various hospitals in london the royal free guys st thomas and royal marsden i have had various frankly not great experiences with most of them usually not the medics or nurses but most being badly let down by truly staggeringly terrible support and admin staff the worst being guys cancer centre by a long way kings is such a relief a breath of fresh air i will admit i actually cried after my first appointment not because of any bad news but i had lovely receptionist i did not believe they existed within the nhs like hens teeth charming helpful nurse absolutely lovely helpful professional dr i had someone call me when i was on the train mins after i left asking when would suit me to schedule a scan i had to ask him to repeat the question they would suit me it was truly unreal in years of chasing begging pleading and asking for scans good luck with getting one at guys expect to go grey and lose your sanity arranging anything with them they were asking me when suited me i think its a public private partner ship if only only nhs departments or units were run like the net cancer unit at kings truly a shining light in a sea of absolute mediocrity i cannot speak for other departments but the net cancer team should be showing other hospitals in london how it is done

評論內容:
I recently visited King’s College Hospital A&E after injuring my wrist, and I wanted to say how excellent the care was from start to finish.

I was seen within about half an hour, went straight through to X-ray, and everyone I encountered - from reception to the radiology team to the nurses - was kind, efficient, and reassuring. I was quickly diagnosed with a wrist fracture, fitted with a cast, and given clear instructions on what to expect next.

The follow-up was also incredibly smooth: I received a phone call the very next morning from an orthopaedic doctor who explained my break in more detail and arranged an in-person appointment for the following week.

You often hear about how stretched the NHS is, but my experience was nothing short of fantastic. I’m really grateful for the professionalism and compassion shown by everyone I met. Thank you to all the staff at King’s for making a stressful situation so much easier.

評論內容:
I wanted to share my experience during my recent visit to the hospital, we arrived at reception around 10 pm with concerning symptoms , early pregnancy contractions, we couldn’t hear the staff member as the microphone wasn’t working. He simply said there was nothing he could do and refused to speak louder, which was frustrating, I felt like my concerns weren’t taken seriously. Sadly, some of the staff also came across as quite dismissive. A bit more kindness and clear communication would have made a difference.

I asked twice for a blanket as I was feeling very cold and faint, but unfortunately, no one responded. I was then sent to another unit (EAU), where I had to sit on a chair even though I had explained that I was in severe discomfort due to my abdominal pain and exhaustion. What surprised me the most was that the hospital was very quiet that night, with no obvious crowd or busyness, yet I felt completely overlooked.

I remained there all night without much attention or updates. In the morning, a nurse simply told me I could go home. Initially, they mentioned prescribing antibiotics, but then changed their minds without much explanation.

I left feeling dismissed, unsupported, and disappointed by the lack of compassion during what was a very frightening time for me. I hope sharing this experience encourages the hospital to reflect on how vulnerable patients are treated, especially during late hours when they may already feel scared and alone.

評論內容:
The usual…………

Today I arrived in A&E at 5PM and was beckoned to speak to the member of staff through a narrow slit in the glass as the microphone/speaker set up was broken. The next stop was triage where a super friendly nurse took down my symptoms and gave me a couple of paracetamol to damp down my fever.  I then had to hand the piece of paper they had filled in at another window, to facilitate check-in to the Emergency Department. I then sat in the first of what turned out to be many waiting rooms where the water machine was broken. Next I was called in to assessment area where I repeated all my symptoms again and handed over my urine sample (which was immediately lost). From there, I went to have blood taken and then returned to the waiting area. An ED doctor came to see me so I detailed my symptoms to them as well and provided a second urine sample. They told me I urgently needed hydration and antibiotics via IV. My next stop was yet another waiting room where I was connected to a  fluid IV which had barely started before it was paused to give me some antibiotics. When the antibiotic IV had finished, the nurse who had started it was not in the department and none of the others were willing to reconnect the fluid drip. I had to wait until  the original nurse had returned, which they eventually did. While in this room I was told I would need to be admitted. Next stop, another waiting room but this time with reclining chairs at least, from where I write this. It is now 02:30 AM, I know that even if I eventually get a bed, I will be woken up at 05:00 for meds and again at 06:00 for blood tests. It is now 03:06, I have finally been moved to a ward which has many empty narrow ‘gurney’ beds on it. How anyone can possibly sleep here is beyond me…..and we all know how important sleep is for healing

After an accident and brought at A&E with the ambulance my summary was open fracture at my upper arm and dislocated shoulder. Orthopaedic department was full and I've been moved to 3 different wards. My permanence at the Twining ward, Dawson Ward and Cheere Ward has been really good, some nurses are literally amazing going above and beyond their job description. A couple though looked a bit careless and couldn't get bothered much, nurse or mc donald would have been the same.
The food is pretty decent and most of the kitchen staff were really looking after me, holding the food until I was stopping starving, regardless if it was out of food time.
The experience was strongly affected by the lack of communication from the orthopaedic department, they cancelled my surgery twice and delayed more than a week, doctors were ghost, they turned up only when we called them repeatedly or to tell me they were cancelling the surgery, terrible attitude, superficial and were looking bothered from me making questions. They barely checked how I was doing, it was a matter of what they had to do because someone had to do that job, otherwise they would rather skip it. Not impressed at all

評論內容:
My father was recently admitted to the Accident and Emergency (A&E) department at King's College Hospital, where he remained for three days before being transferred to the Frank Stansil Acute Assessment Unit. During his stay on the Frank Stansil ward, he was not provided with any hot meals and was only offered crisps and sandwiches, which were unsuitable for his dietary requirements due to a stated allergy to butter.

Furthermore, the staffing levels observed within the emergency ward appeared to be significantly low, with a noticeable lack of available doctors and nurses. The overall standard of care was unsatisfactory to the extent that my father felt compelled to discharge himself from the hospital as he didn't feel safe and his well-being was serverly effected.

評論內容:
I had a truly shocking experience at this hospital. I arrived with suspected anaphylactic shock due to an allergic reaction and spent 6 hours waiting to be treated. Despite clearly struggling to breathe and begging for an injection, the only thing the doctor did was prescribe me some tablets. No urgent care was provided.

To make things even worse, when I went to the pharmacy the next morning to get the medication, I was told that the doctor had forgotten to stamp the prescription, meaning I couldn’t even get the medicine I needed.

This level of negligence and lack of urgency in a potentially life-threatening situation is absolutely unacceptable. I am deeply disappointed and concerned for anyone else who might find themselves in need of emergency care here.

評論內容: My first visit to this hospital today. It's big. Every corridor appeared clean. The toilets were clean. I experienced a fresh, hygienic smell the whole visit. My appointment was with the Neuro MRI unit for a MRI head with contrast. I was seen on time. I was treated kindly and with respect. I was reassured and spoken to throughout the scan which lasted around twenty minutes. I cannot fault my experience. I feel grateful and humbled. I appreciate my appointment was on Easter Sunday and the hospital may have been less busy than usual. This may not necessarily be completely indicative of the way the hospital functions during the week when I am sure there are very many more patients needing prompt and urgent treatment. I imagine there is huge pressure for the staff to deliver a service in a way that would reflect the way they would wish to be treated themselves. Thank you to each and everyone of you who continue to strive to offer comfort, care and kindness.

評論內容:
The gynaecology department is excellent. After nearly ten years of suffering from endometriosis, I was referred here and found the team and specialist consultant with initials TD to be amazing.

I waited over a year to be seen but all of my interactions have been positive. The doctor suggested I attend the endometriosis class and that group session that TD ran was really good.

Since Sept 2024, I had a blood test, MRI, bone scan, day surgery and a Ryeqo prescription. Every interaction has been positive and the staff have been so great and professional. My day surgery in April went well and all of the team there made me feel at ease. This is random but the surgeon NG was my boss's doppelganger - I tried not to focus on the fact they have the same looks, accent, mannerisms and humour! I mean that in a complimentary way and NG helped put me at ease.

This hospital is outstanding for endometriosis issues.

評論內容:
Struggling since last Friday with a tooth infection. Waiting on a nhs dentist til Tuesday. By Monday it had inflamed so bad that I had difficulty breathing and eating and became a little frightened.
Monday morning after taking the day off work, I used the nhs 111 service which advised me to go to St Thomas hospital. I travelled there and unfortunately they do not take in dental cases or issues at all.
They advised kings college hospital on denmark hill camberwell.
I went through various "checkpoints' to register / be assessed and so forth. I left after approx 6 hours of patiently waiting in a/e dept. during examination processes. I have rarely experienced private medical treatment but my experience yesterday was on par at least.
An incredible level of care, due diligence, thoughtfulness and kindness at this hospital. Even if I had no dental issue I would have been lost for words!!
Communication, efficency, I am delighted after how good this treatment was as I was a little concerned for my health but all staff were brilliant in their job duties and tasks. I wish I could remember everyones name because all were equally excellent in their profession. However, favaroh (farah) temmy,  I spent a while with especially farah who advised and completed the minor surgey. Thanks again to all and if the nhs was at this standard nationwide then I'd be very very surprised. This a/e team deserve a pay rise!
