評論內容:
I am deeply disappointed with the experience my husband and I had with Dr. Imad in A&E. Although the initial two-hour wait was shorter than expected, the consultation itself was rushed and dismissive. Dr. Imad barely took the time to assess my husband’s condition, providing what felt like a 30-second consultation. Despite our request for an X-ray, he refused without much consideration.

To make matters worse, he sent us to a pharmacy that was closed—something that could have easily been avoided if he had considered it was a Sunday. The next day, when we went to the nearest pharmacy to the hospital, we were told there was no prescription available for us. Confused, we returned to A&E for clarification. Instead of being met with empathy, Dr. Imad was visibly frustrated. He walked briskly ahead of us, almost as if he were trying to get rid of us, while giving directions to the actual hospital pharmacy. When we explained that we had simply assumed the closest pharmacy was the correct one, he curtly told us, “Then you didn’t listen to me.”

Both my husband and I were exhausted, fasting, and dealing with his severe pain. It would have been easy to mishear or misunderstand directions in that state, but instead of showing any compassion, Dr. Imad was condescending and impatient. His lack of empathy and dismissive attitude were incredibly disheartening, especially coming from someone in a profession meant to provide care and support.

This experience was extremely negative, and I sincerely hope management takes this feedback seriously. No patient seeking help should be made to feel like a burden or be treated with such disregard.

The one star is for the helpful reception team only.

評論內容:
Would have given zero stars if I could. They are a disgrace. My GP surgery asked for a referral in September 24. Appointment was booked. After several weeks and just a few days before they refused it saying their protocols had not been followed. This is NOT a legal requirement! To help me, my surgery filled in their forms, again marked the referral as urgent. They sent it back, saying protocol not fully complied with. My surgery argued the case and they said they would have a clinical review and get back. That was 12th Nov. We didn't get a reply. My surgery followed up. They were told no one to type up dictated notes. It's now 8th Dec and my surgery has sent them another email and copied me in and told them that as well. My family has 2 doctors in it. We believe in the NHS. We support the NHS. But Kings is a disgrace. We know the problems faced by the NHS, mainly caused by the Tories but Kings has been a problem for some time. Go to the Brompton or Royal Orthopaedic and it's a different ball game. Professional, caring people, from the bottom to the top. Kings is a problem due to its management. They need an overhaul. They need a shakeup. There is no need for this appalling travesty of a hospital. I intend to contact members of government and shame them. You are a disgrace Kings.

It's now almost another week and despite my GP's email, we have still not had a reply! Amazing as the documentation from my surgery marked my condition as URGENT. 3 months Kings. You are useless

Guess what, only got a reply a couple of days ago after my surgery repeatedly called and tried to get through. They said I didn't need surgery but another intervention first. They didn't read the notes, it was already done! I'm lodging a complaint, which I will post here on how to do it. My surgery is now referring me to another hospital, I DON'T trust Kings

Update. Was referred to RNOH Stanmore. Kings findings TOTALLY wrong on their last report. Wrong diagnosis, wrong treatment! They wanted me to go to a pain clinic, Stanmore recommended surgery as soon as they saw the scan!  If I continue without it, I will require more pain medication and will end up in a wheelchair. That's the verdict of the consultant. Shame on you Kings. Shame on the people who looked at my results and got it SO WRONG. Good thing my surgery referred me to Stanmore.

評論內容: This is a reputable hospital—clean and efficient. The dermatology department is exceptional. I sought a second opinion on my dermatitis here after being treated at St Thomas' and Guy's Hospital, which are well-known as leading centers for skin care in the UK with the largest clinical dermatology department. After a few treatments at St Thomas and Guy's , I was informed that nothing more could be done. However, the dermatologists at King's College are significantly more skilled. I learned that there are alternative medications available beyond ointments and creams. The dermatology department at King's College has truly made a positive impact on my condition.

評論內容:
I have always been treated well and respected by the staff, Doctors and Nurses including all Medical Practitioners and NHS Employees.

Kings College Hospital is my second home due to MS. This for me is a challenge to navigate as my mobility declines quicker than I am prepared for and it’s permanently impossible to reverse and there is no cure…. (Booo)
So what do we do? We carry on as best we can and make life as good while we have Life! We take pictures through the pain and make these google reviews that may help others!!!

This also helps me to be honest with myself and open about the difficulties I face on a daily basis - most of my reviews do not show my true pain or walking aids, roller or walking sticks.

I had a quiet year with reviews due to being housebound, unmotivated, crippled in pain & unable to get up and about…simple!

Life Is Ok…. please Enjoy!

評論內容:
AMA/TRIAGE department needs better organisation and management. My niece had extremely low blood sugar she attended this hospital on Saturday 8pm  feeling very weak dizzy. Her first blood sugar test she was 3.4! !!!!! They didn't give her anything for the next 4 hours when she complained about feeling very dizzy and about to pass out! They came over and said ohhh someone should have brought the dextrose over.... so they did another blood sugar test beforeeeeeeee actually giving her the Dextrose(makes no sense because we knew it's loww)))   the second test was 2.1 which was not ridiculously low!!! Believe me we didn't even get an apology. Instead, just told to come sit here and take this.

Fiona, and the other head nurse!!!! Just shocking, zero communication, lots of attitude, rolings their eyes when we had to remind them to do a simple blood sugar test which was ordered by the Dr...I went to Fiona politely to remind them that no one has come to do the test, both nurses looked at each other and just rolled their eyes as if I have begged them for money!!!! Fiona looks at me with a very patronising ton.  "I will let the nurse know" for the next hour no one came!! I went back and she looked at me sorry we are busy doing a handover give us 5 minutes. Moral of the story thus department staff needs to be investigated. I have been to north middlesex and Barnet and other a&e departments in England. Never have seen such a level of negligence from so called head nurses

評論內容:
I have always seen the NHS staff as heroes, almost angels, but after dealing first hand with them, I am beyond impressed..

I was in for a robotic partial colectomy, a state of the art technique to remove cancers and other unwanted presences in the colon.

I would like to thank in particular my surgeon, Dr Emmanuel, and his team together with the entire staff at the Coptcoat ward, where I stayed. They were professional, attentive, upbeat and helped me go through a serious challenge almost without feeling it.

The results were amazing, not only in terms of efficacy but also in terms of speed in recovery.

There was a glitch though: an unethical communication issue in which I was not told that there was a last minute change of the head surgeon in charge of my operation. Although this is shocking, this has nothing to do with those who dealt with me in the ward and in the operation theatre to whom I could not be more grateful. I guess it ended for the better.

A warm hug to each and all of them,

The good reviews seem to be from people with actual medical needs, the poor ones from people who didn't need to be there in the first place.

評論內容:
Had the worst experience with a so called ‘senior’ doctor called Fadal and so called head nurse James in the Major B department at Kings College Hospital, who refused to explain the conclusion of an MRI scan to my aunty with dementia and language/cognition problems as he did not want to engage with her. I’ve checked the GMC and NHS websites and this directly contradicts the fabrications they had tried to feed us, as patients DO  have the right to refuse a transplant or if they prefer a family member. He had done this deliberately in order to questions pertaining to my aunties health condition. He then attempted to tell me to ‘get out’ as I’d explained she did not need an interpreter as she was with me (a relative) who she has requested to help support her. He was extremely dismissive and unprofessional, when my aunty explained that she did not require a translator. He then attempted to accuse me of saying I’d forced her to say that. This caused extreme distress for my aunty and I have video proof of this, which I will be sharing with PALS, in order to review duty of care for vulnerable patients under the care of these two men.

To add insult to injury, the ‘head nurse’ on duty - a man named Jamie, attempted to double down on his colleagues assumption that she is being co-erced - although, they were trying to take away her right to consenting to a translator. None of her needs were taken into account and this startled my aunty. This conversation caused my aunty distress and asked him to leave repeatedly. Jamie then asked to speak to me privately and patronisingly asked me to ‘go get some rest for my eyes’ which was unwarranted and walked away and refused to engage, making us wait an extra 5 hours before being seen by another health care professional. Jamie refused to come after I had called for him after wars. Worst hospital ever, please don’t attempt to go there if you’re ever in need of urgent care.

Since when was it hospital policy to force someone without consent to use a translator? It seems as though they’re letting anyone into healthcare these days. So called ‘senior’ Doctors who lack compassion, and a clear understanding of their roles such as Fadal are an absolute disgrace to this profession and do not possess the knowledge, empathy or understanding to work with vulnerable patients and I worry deeply for patients who are vulnerable and under his care. This situation has led to my aunty having a severe mistrust of the healthcare system in the UK. I’ll be filing an official complaint with the evidence I have of this situation. Patients, please be wary about Doctor Fadal in the A&E unit.

It’s such a shame that a ‘senior doctor’ and ‘head nurse’ (lol) will try to fob you off as much as possible, under the guise of ‘policy’ that isn’t contextual to the needs of the patient or true at all: therefore, please make sure that you’re well versed on the GMC and NHS guidelines. It’s such a shame that you have to come prepared with the bureaucracy and fodder that some of the nurses and doctors at Kings College Hospital such as Fadal and Jamie will do.

*I just wanted to add that the rest of the team we dealt with were amazing and gave us the due diligence and care required. Fadal and James making up delusional fantasies about ‘coercion’ was proved wrong when an amazing consultant provided me with the correct information AND allowed the opportunity for my shanty to ask questions via a translator. This was a massive win and my aunty left feeling extremely happy and having trust restored in the healthcare system.

Yasmin

評論內容: King's made lots of positive changes in recent years. It looks organized,tidy, clean and much friendlier staff and effective communication . And I was always 100% satisfied with my doctor.It would deserve 5 stars by my recent visit...4 stars is only because of the lack of disabled car parking space. The hospital closed the old visitor parking site and it uses it as staff car parking site . Which I understand, because the staff don't have time to circulate 1 hour and look for a parking space before work....But the same hospital has a legal obligation to ensure that disabled people independently  can get to the medical treatments there. I could not find any car parking place in the hospital's land,nor on the surrounding roads.Zero disabled parking bay in the hospital - 5-6 disabled car parking bay on the surrounding roads -all were used, its a huge hospital.  I'm fine with walking 50-100 meters - in the end I had to do 400 meters twice. I don't know what the solution will be - perhaps a large car parking building . But the problem is not solved today - that's a fact.

評論內容:
Brilliant work from the maxofacial clinic here! First consultation was done very quickly (from me arriving to the clinic to out within 15 mins) and very polite and nice staff, never felt rushed and was genuinely surprised at how quick it had been when I left!
Returned for a wisdom tooth extraction, was in and out in an hour.
The ladies who were involved in the extraction were very nice, checked all my pain when giving me the local anaesthetic, (my choice over general, I needed to drive and I don't mind the drilling), and made sure I was fully numb as it took a little more to numb my mouth.
And even though the extraction took a little more umph as my tooth did not seem happy to leave, they were letting me know everything they were doing, everything they needed me to do. And were so friendly and kind the whole time!

Would 10/10 recommend!

評論內容: Awful, came with my son with him stuck in his airways , right off the bat, looked like no one cared, the first nurse was just absolutely awful, asked 2 questions and and made a decision that he does not need to be seen and can go home as ‘he wasn’t suffering or in pain or having difficulties talking, I was shocked and responded with, you want him to be suffering before he is seen, he has a foreign object in potentially his lungs and your worried about how fine he seems, as a nurse you should know that a foreign object that does not dissolve stuck in your wind pipe be it partial blocked or not can lead to further problems, even if his wasn’t fully blocked so he was talking and breathing but that still needs to be seen, gum does not disintegrate in your airways, it’s not going into his stomach to then come out in a couple of days , I’m appalled at the lack of concern. finally she agreed to have his observations and now I’m sat here waiting in the room where I have witnessed dozens of people come in after me and my son and have already been seen by the doctor, so I can only assume the know it all nurse has pushed him at the back of the list out of spite, when I’ve gone to ask the reception they’ve given me a very generic response priority, and what 10 other people have been prioritised  and they seem to not be ‘suffering’ either. but here we are still waiting, I don’t understand what do these doctors and nurses think we come out to wait for hours on purpose because we like it or somthing, no one wants to come to A&E out of choice. honestly only here as we’re were asked to come here by 111

評論內容: Went to A&E under the advice of a secondary party and then was later admitted to the gynecology unit for further investigation of ongoing conditions. It's always busy in the hospital especially on Friday evenings but the staff did what they could to get me pushed through the system. The gynae team were lovely when I was in severe pain and have given me further support if I need it. I can't remember all the nurses names unfortunately but I do recall Lucy and Rachel, thank you to them and all the other staff working the night 15th August and the morning after.

評論內容:
The care given to patients is, rightly so, adapted to them. However as is expected of any nurse or doctor, time is precious. Whilst I understand their time stretched beyond any sane amount, taking time to read a patients notes, further back than the here and now problem must be looked at. For example, knowing that the reason a patient is here is, complicated for want of a better word, means you take extra care in reading *all relevant notes*.
The food is ok, however a lack of choice and small portions, especially where pre and anti natal patients are concerned, is rather concerning..... breakfast there is a lot of choice, but its never varied again either. Its doing what they can with what seems to be very minimal effort to offer anything other than the same thing, day in day out. Maybe have a look at expanding the menu, and adding portion sizes, dietary requirements etc.... (diabetic/ceoliac options etc)
Shout out to Dr Sadiki, Charlotte and Sumeyyah, just a few of the most understanding people I've ever come across within the NHS. After my shit show of a situation, they deserve a medal.....

評論內容: Had the best experience at the Royal 29-30th /07/25 came in with sever abdominal pain, shivers, head ache, the works basically, was seen very fast by a lovely nurse who took my bp, ECG, my heart rate, pulse and recognised something was wrong, she was so welcoming and reassuring. Was sent back out to the waiting room ofcourse to wait to see another nurse which was again pretty quick for it being the emergency sit and wait she was amazing and patient with me being a nightmare patient (I can’t swallow tablets + hate needles and bloods being taken) but she was fab never made me feel like I was being hysterical and was really reassuring. She then allowed us to wait in her room and lie down as I was quite a lot of pain, already at this point had fluids + antibiotics prescribed by the doctor which was fab. Got moved into the major blue ward were everyone was so so lovely I believe it was Ken my HCA was the sweetest and really tried to make a scary situation better they were all fantastic though. Once bloods came back (within the hour!) I was sent for a ct a few hours later (only took this long as they were deciding weather it was appropriate for me to be exposed to the radiation at my age as I am a young adult) everyone in the ct room was lovely and reassuring as well. The results for that came back pretty quick as well where I had been given a diffinitive diagnosis of appendicitis and was told I would need an operation and therefore moved onto ward 16 which was just as fab as major. The lovely nurse that was there when I arrived was so comforting and understanding of my worry as I’d never had an operation and wasn’t going to be able to see my parents before hand as they had scheduled my surgery for the first thing in the morning (which looking back was amazing) the HCA I had was amazing as well talking to me about her sons surgerys and not to worry trying to distract me from worrying which was lovely. The Anesthesiologists and the surgeons of course came in to speak to me as well where I got upset as I was very very nervous and they were absolutely fantastic such lovely and talented people so so reassuring and understanding really listening to me and my concerns and were there for me and comforted me all through up until I was out asleep they honestly exceeded my already high expectations from the rest of the hospital as they were just brilliant. The recovery nurse I had as well was so so lovely as well reassuring me as I came round telling me my parents had arrived checking in on me very frequently and barley left my side unless to get medication. My recovery in ward 16 was amazing as well everyone in there is so sweet and helpful I’ve honestly never had such a clean, professional, caring, patient, understanding experience and team of staff and am so so happy with the care I have received at the Royal. I wish I knew all of their individual names so I could accurately give credit where it is due for these lovely people as they all deserve it!! ❤️

評論內容: Absolutely outstanding experience with the A&E staff at Leicester Royal Infirmary after I broke my ankle playing baseball. From the moment I arrived, I was treated with care, professionalism, and genuine kindness. The team was not only highly efficient in assessing and managing my injury, but also incredibly personable. I felt appropriately looked after at all times, which made a painful situation much easier to cope with. Huge thanks to everyone who helped.

評論內容: My GP sent me at LRI for a check up as I had the symptoms for a long time and my blood sugar was very high due to my diabetes. GP rang through to LRI  “discussed with bed bureau who will discuss with GPAU re-admission to their trolley area. BB will contact pt re where to attend”. There was a lady who rang me back saying I can be seen straight away just ask for the GPAU. I went to the reception and showed her the letter. I was handed around as if no one knew what was going on. I went back to reception and she said the GPAU is now closed and I have to wait to be seen. I’ve been waiting for nearly 4 hours. There is no communication between hospital staff. Now I wonder if it was worth coming as I honestly don’t think any of them know what they’re doing. Please don’t get me wrong I know it’s very hard for the NHS staff and I salute them all. In LRI there’s no solid system at all. I’m not just saying this I have experienced it last year as well. I have sciatica and  my GP sent me for a MRI. I went to A&E at 19:30 and by 9:30 the next morning I was still there unseen. Every 3-4 hrs they were injecting me with morphine for my pain. By 10am I had enough so I took a taxi went home and saw my GP.

評論內容: We are all aware how the NHS is completely broken. However, I was ambulanced into hospital last week. I waited an hour for the ambulance and the two paramedics were incredible. I arrived at the hospital and after a very long wait I was admitted. I watched as the staff were treated badly, sworn at, threatened and abused…. Yet they still treated everyone with dignity and kindness. After being admitted into a ward, moved to another ward and having to sleep in a corridor due to them being totally full, I was again treated with respect, kindness and was taken care of by great, decent in fact phenominal drs and nurses. Again it’s the system that’s broken and these nurses and doctors are working their butts off to get us well and back home with little thanks for doing it. All of the staff including the dinner/tea ladies were kind, they listened and again treated everyone with a smile and respect. Everyone wants to knock LRI which is a shame because my stay in hospital was made much better just by the care I got. Ward 34…. Windsor… you got it right. Thank you so much

評論內容:
Even though it was so busy in A&E and my elderly mother had to wait 17 hours on a trolley bed, the majority of staff were very attentive and willing to answer any concerns and questions I had. Whilst also regularly asking her if she wanted a cup of tea which we know makes such a difference to some people. A couple of the male staff were quite rude which I did bring up at the time.
A special mention to Suki (Deputy sister), very empathetic and helpful girl which put my mum at ease when she first arrived as she wasn’t feeling well and was in a lot of pain.
Also the staff were on top of the regular meds my mum needed to take whilst she was there and call bells were answered promptly. They deserve more praise for the immense pressure they’re under.

評論內容:
I had a horrendous experience at this hospital I was put on ward 7 after 22 hours in A&E and harassed by a nasty Ward Assistant, because I said I felt isolated. Nobody spoke English elderly confused women were crying out, 1 person in a side word obviously distressed banging on the door shouting “ let me out “
The nasty ward assistant continued to harass me trying to say I was a raciest . ( she was black)
She even refused to open the door to let my husband pass me some ice for my water as I had not eaten and only had tepid water for 2 days. The hospital still employ her.
I discharged myself after 29 hours with a carrier bag of medication as feeling to unsafe.to stay.  I got home 30 hours after leaving home still standing in the same clothes I left in.
My husband was in A&E for 5 days a few months ago with a severe infection & internal haemorrhage. ( he was recovering from major brain surgery at QMS after a serious bleed on the brain)! He was in a side room with another very unwell man : there were dunk women in recliner chairs outside their bay room in A&E inviting their friends in all night shouting, laughing and just there to be warm and free food. A security man had to sit outside my husband’s room 24 hours a day.
A close friend arrived at 4am this morning. Chest pains and unwell 72 years old surrounded by drunks and people handcuffed to police officers. And if you are given a bed in a bay awaiting an allocation to a ward. The staff talk, laugh and carry on like it’s the middle of the day even at 3 in the morning.
The most unsafe dangerous place for the sick and vulnerable in the country. Don’t even try to go to PALS the UHL PALS are the biggest joke in the UK. Another Friend was in A&E went home after 24 hours with head lice! An absolute disgrace of a hospital. No leadership, no strong security and protection for real unwell people and staff with chips on their shoulders. Sad very sad and it’s not about money.

評論內容: I’ve been in and out of this hospital over the past few months and can honestly say they are the absolute best and here’s why, it’s ok being a nurse, dr, orderly, cleaner etc they are all titles but what makes a person or professional is the ability and humanity to listen!! I’ve always been spoken to and asked how I feel and been given a sympathetic ear whilst I vent my frustration or how scared I am and they have always been 100% even the orderlies will stop for a chat if you need someone to talk to!! But my special mention goes to the security staff with whom I wouldn’t be here today ( you know who you 4 guys are) you looked after me without judgement helped me whilst I was struggling and gave me hope in a hopeless world when I thought mine was falling apart, I owe you more than I can say but guys like you are an absolute credit to your profession not just to stop the occasional bag head but to take the time and help someone in need so thank you from the bottom of my heart you helped me more than you will ever know thank you all

A absolute disgrace of a company. Dr Curran and his team should be ashamed for themselves of the level of care they provided to my sister. They have left her with a surgery that did not work and for months they’ve been promising to fix it only to keep cancelling the surgery’s and are now saying they will not do the surgery! Disgusting when you pay private for a surgery to work then they provide next to no aftercare absolutely ruining my sisters life. The mental health issues they have caused and the lack of professionalism from them and their team is like nothing I have ever seen before.

If you value your health then do not go here!! They don’t care about their patients, just want your money then leave you needing remedial surgeries and refuse to do them!

Great service, despite waiting for over 7h I could not complain. A lot of staff working under awful conditions due to abuse the general public. I can’t understand how or why they believe they are entitled to act like this. Most people complaining could not grasp simple instructions and information, this was due to people either not listening or not hearing what they wanted to. Examples of what they have to put up with included one patient complaining they mispronounced his surname so didn’t come forward when called! It was ACU staff fault he missed  the first opportunity to be seen! Another arguing with a receptionist that their partner condition was serious cause the gp said so, whereas the doctors within the ACU after further test said it wasn’t. As a result they would have to wait. There delightful person was threatening to sue. What idiots! They left in the end, so he clearly care that much for his partner if he really thought it was life threatening!

Yes the wait was long last night, but priority is rightly given to those who need it most. Even after being told by the doctor I should have been seen sooner to take blood samples, as I got missed somehow, these things happen. The service from all of the staff was great.

評論內容: This review is to do with a terrible experience I have had with the A&E department. I came down with awful pelvic pain the other day (could barely walk) and was refused an ambulance. Dragged myself to A&E, only to be fobbed off by an extremely condescending nurse who kept dismissing all my symptoms, whilst also continuously repeating she was not doing so. I felt like a 5-year-old being told off for not picking up their toys after playtime. No abdominal exam, nothing, and I had my blood pressure checked with a device that wouldn't even work properly. The whole department feels really dirty (ABYSMAL toilets) and the staff seems more concerned with idle chitchat and their personal affairs rather than the patients.

評論內容:
Attended last night due to falling down around 15 stairs and landed on my back unable to move.
Reception staff at triage were lovely and friendly.
Once you pass this point and go into the ED, it completely goes down hill.
I was told I « hadn’t been triaged properly » by the doctor (after 4 hours of waiting at this point)
I requested some painkillers and told them I had started to get shooting pain in my neck - I never got these painkillers. Told the doctor I didn’t get them, still received nothing from them.
The doctors and nurses are rude and wouldn’t tell you even if your hair was on fire. I get it’s a stressful job but it’s a job that YOU chose and you have a duty of care for these patients.
There is a clear failure for patients in this hospital, no urgency, security are rude, every single staff member other than receptionists and porters are rude. You are made to feel like an inconvenience by them. I was prescribed nothing by them for the pain, not gave any advice or anything on how to make it better just told to « come back if it gets worst » and sit through 8 hours of A&E again? No thanks.
Something needs to change in this hospital as this A&E is by far the worst I have ever been to in my life.

評論內容: Went to MRI last night after 24hrs profusely vomitting (have been in couple times same issue) can’t figure out what causes it. The nurses last night shift weren’t nice or nurse assistants tbh. I couldn’t keep anything down & body was going into shock as severley dehydrated & exteme nausea. I got told to sleep on the cold floor waiting 3hrs until I got 1x shot of anti sickness in my arm. I got left waiting for it to kick in but bc of the dehydration I kept sipping water n vomiting even more. Wasn’t offered fluids or a bed as sitting up kept making me pee myself & vomit. They said I had nothing else for me, I said I will discharge myself and rest at home still knowing I wasn’t feeling good and couldn’t sleep on the cold floor any longer. I went home could not sleep due to nausea / vomiting and went back to MRI to get told to go to another hospital which I did North Manchester who were superb. The triage nurse also told me I was being quite rude to staff? Why they don’t want to see me. I wasn’t being rude I was left on the floor in pool of my own sick n pee and was requesting more sickness or privacy as my clothes were drenched in sick. I went to north Manchester where they put a canula in straight away after checking in & gave me a drip of anti sickness and a 1hr IV fluid which severely helped me. I got another anti sickness drip & got discharged by 10:30am with some Omeprazole & Cyclezine. All in all, MRI usually are very helpful and have looked aftered me super well in the past. This really upset me that at 5am they refused to see me bc apparently I was rude to staff? I was crying & sick.. I’m 28 and come from a dental background, never cursed or threatened. All I did was go to the reception numerous times to ask for anti sickness or some help. Post 10hrs, I’m in my own bed, just licking soup of a spoon & self healing with North Manchester Dr’s advice. May be my next go to hospital even though MRI is 5mins away from me. Saddened but low key expected from the second triage nurse or assistant. He was a Asian guy, green uniform & was the one who did my bloods who I found was rude & complained against me for using the plastic room to vomit in privately with which was empty. I’m happy I am alive but if something sinister happened whilst on a hosp floor. It’s not nice for my loved ones. Thank you for taking a time out to read.

評論內容:
Ambulance was forever and a stressful experience to get dispatched. I was clearly in an emergency from attempting a medication swap. Despite every other patient relaxing and talking. I was withering in absolute agony for several hours without a bed.

Staff spoken to me like I was trash and seemed to be enjoying the spectacular show of watching a desperate and sick man in close to the most pain that is humanely possible whilst alive.

Here is what should have been done:

“Treating Precipitated Withdrawal

The principle is simple: provide a high dose of buprenorphine to maximize its agonist effects combined with a single low dose of benzodiazepine to address fear and anxiety. The standardized approach presented here should be applied as quickly as possible.”

However, the incredible NHS gave me absolutely nothing. The Doctor was even considering reversing the condition which could have put me through immense torture followed by death. Why not just go forward with what I had already initiated and I could have walked out of there today successfully inducted on the Medicine that I spent the last several months fighting to be able to make the switch to? Instead I have taken several steps backwards and I am forced into going back on the Medication that I just spent countless years coming off.

They then told me to walk home in the lovely rain alone whilst on deaths door being full blown tortured; and refused to call a taxi or show any compassion whatsoever. Another patient who witnessed this spoke to me outside and said well done for what I was attempting. He was astounded at the arrogance of the Staff. He was also convinced that they seemed to be enjoying the suffering they were seeing and hearing.

Never again. The only time that place and those awful people will be seeing me again is when they scrape me off my floor deceased, I recently opted out of default Organ Doner NHS status.

I am genuinely traumatised by the ordeal. I will never call 999 for an Ambulance Ever again. The two Ambulance girls were okay. However their words were misleading because if I would have known they were going to give me absolutely nothing and then tell me to get walking through the rain home whilst severely sick I would never have got in the Ambulance.

NHS is best for lonely elders who fancy a bit of an adventure to pass the time and not feel so alone.Also any Foreign nationals would like the experience as they get a bed and have the protection of Equality to ensure they are not treated the way they treated me.

But for the sake of quickly prescribing a couple of Diazepam and drip dosing Buprenorphine until I stabilised within 12 to 24 hours. They clearly chose to give me nothing including no respect or understanding.

This was another nightmare failed attempt at moving forward. And now I know not to ever call the NHS for help.

評論內容:
Excessive waiting time — over 17 hours in the A&E with no urgency shown.

Poor communication — waited 5 extra hours for results without being told the doctor had ordered a CT scan two hours earlier.

Unnecessary suffering — my mother was left in pain for hours due to lack of updates and action.

Staff disinterest — many staff appeared uninterested in patients and more focused on personal activities.

Lack of professionalism — behaviour suggested some staff lacked the basic training or common sense expected in urgent care.

Neglect of urgent patients — urgent cases were not treated as a priority.

Inappropriate behaviour — staff “playing games” while patients were waiting and suffering.

Disgraceful standard of care — a total failure of compassion, respect, and responsibility.

Loss of trust — I will never bring a loved one to this hospital again.

Government oversight needed — this hospital should be reported to the government for investigation. I'm ashamed of NHS here.

* The picture says it all just unbelievable and useless*

評論內容: Really poor treatment of women undergoing treatment for cervical issues. They insisted I have a LLETZ procedure even thiugh the cell changes were minor, I agreed as they told me it would make the underlying virus go away. Fast forward several more smears and it hasn't gone. Not only that but when they checked the removed tissue they found the changes were so minimal they didn't need to be removed. Honestly this is so bad, it leads to miscarriages and I haven't even had children yet. I can't even begin to describe the effect of this on me emotionally, the lying about it resolving the virus and the stress of knowing I underwent the procedure that possibly means I won't have children now. I never expect a lot from the NHS as let's be honest their care of women is dreadful generally but even I was shocked at how bad this was.

評論內容:
I received an email today demanding proof of my right to stay in the UK. The tone of the email was quite intimidating, suggesting that I would be charged for the entire treatment and that they would inform my GP to update their records because I didn't respond. However, I haven't received any email or letter from them. I also regularly check my spam and MyMFT. The woman who sent the email from the Overseas Chargeable Patients Service claimed she had sent it by post. I left the hospital just last week (Thursday), so it makes sense that I need a little time to receive the letter.

Why is there such a need to intimidate patients? Give us time to breathe; I am still recovering, show a bit of respect. I’ve been dealing with a heart infection, and I won't even mention the eight-hour wait I endured the first day, trying to see a doctor through incredible pain. I was asking for a doctor to explain to me what was going on for ten hours the day when I was admitted to the hospital, and nobody came to see me until 10 PM since 12 am.

When I returned to the hospital yesterday for a fer injection, the doctor requested a blood test, but nobody took blood for the test. Finally, the doctor did it. Your services are incredibly slow, yet you demand things from patients without even proper communication. It’s terrible service.

The woman I spoke to didn’t like it when I explained that I haven’t received the letter, so why did she dare to threaten me with charges and updates to my GP? She didn't like that. She hung up the phone, claiming that she felt intimidated by me. How rude and weak are you? Why? Because I said, I could prove that she created anxiety in a patient with an already vulnerable health for no reason? You think you are entitled to threaten me, and I have to feel fear of you?

The whole experience has been horrific. I  used NHS services to feel better, not worse. It's unbelievable to witness such a lack of responsibility for errors made on your part!
I didn't have any reason to avoid responding; I just had to prove my settle status with a shared code; it was so easy! Terrible, terrible and rude! You think with your fake thank you and sorry you are polite! Ridiculous
Update! I complained about this ridiculous behaviour and of course, I was wrong and the excuses ridiculous as well. We live in Britain where nobody wants to solve problems, only to cover up them... and we pay taxes!

評論內容:
Certainly. Here’s a short, formal review of your experience at Manchester Royal Infirmary, maintaining an academic tone:

⸻

Short Review – Patient Experience at Manchester Royal Infirmary

During my recent visit to Manchester Royal Infirmary, I experienced significant delays and poor communication. Patients were left waiting over six hours, with staff repeatedly calling the same names without coordination or clear purpose. There was a noticeable lack of clear information when inquiries were made, leaving many patients feeling confused and ignored. Blood test results took an unreasonably long time, and some staff appeared disengaged, spending extended periods in offices rather than attending to patients. Instead of receiving care and reassurance, the experience left me feeling more distressed and unwell. Improvements in communication, organisation, and patient engagement are urgently needed.

評論內容:
1 star for communication between staff and patients, 2 stars for meals especially if you are diabetic, 3 stars for students, 4 stars for assistant carers & nurses & 5 stars for the Surgeon. It could be better if the English word was understood and spoken instead of misunderstandings! Fighting between staff in front of patients should be a sackable offence and lying to patients needs to cease. We are in pain and trying to recover and most definitely do not need this because it has a knock on effect! There are staff walking around in scrubs because they have not got the correct uniform and who are not allowed to perform certain tasks; some patients with mental health issues are thinking that they are surgeons and qualified doctors-buy the correct uniform. They spend on these stupid air mattresses that do you more harm than good, but the staff have to sing the same tune " it prevents bed sores." pfffft! Cleaning is in the morning, so you hold going to the toilet because the person before messed it up - no infection control yet they swab your rear and groin to check for infections 🤷‍♂️. I am disappointed with some of the staff, the ones that showed empathy know who they are, it's a shame the rest are to blind to see what's happening. I've witnessed a lot of ill treatment and heard a lot of horrendous stories from other patients and despite being ignored and not listened to, I made a few good friends and will be keeping in touch.  I think my surgeons were amazing they did my bypass and made sure they informed me of what they did, which I find is excellent bedside manner and they understood pain management ( I can't speak for those who complained on my vascular ward) I received what I needed and was up and about by day 3&4. They didn't stock a dressing called Softpore which I'm used to, instead they put a dressing on with plastic film ( I did tell them that I'm allergic to that type of plaster), I had a red hospital bracelet which advises that you have allergies. I had to go to the 24/7 restaurant because I couldn't eat the hospital food; I tried to educate some staff on the dangers of diabetics going into a hypo, but they looked at me as if I fell from the moon. There are plenty places to get food.
Be careful of some individuals outside A&E they're not patients but nuisance spongers.
On the whole, this is definitely not the best NHS hospital, it used to be and sadly I can't see it changing. Nurses are getting a raw deal!

Not sure what the cleaner was doing
but certainly wasn't cleaning. Asked Nurse for assistance was told he would come come back 3hrs later no where to be seen... . My summary letter sent to doctor showing my reason for attending A&E was for a minor headache which was a complete lie,no wonder I was sitting ducks in that dungeon of hell.

Furthermore, the hospital need to look into employing triage nurses who actually know how to do their job saving peoples life's and their valuable time.

評論內容: Sorry to say this was the most disappointing experience I’ve had with any NHS service, after an ice skating accident my partner was taken to this place with paperwork from the paramedics to support a suspected fracture to her eye socket and/or cheekbone, the triage nurse seemed the least interested a ‘professional’ could possibly be, and even with my partner being in obvious pain and feeling the nurse it was a 9/10 on the pain scale, NO painkillers were offered, after being sat in a quite dirty reception/waiting area for 4.5hrs and her pain getting worse I approached the desk, apologised for the question I was about to ask, but asked about wait time, to be barked at its at least 6hrs, what from now or when we checked in???? I asked about pain relief for her to aging be barked ‘the nursing staff will see to that’ but what nursing staff? The only ones I saw were in the triage offices so how do you speak to them? Wait till they open the door and pounce on them? Also I need to add considering it works on a priority of conditions, we sat there and watched people (and I heard this) a sore thumb come and go, I saw a guy with a sprained ankle come and go, and any amount of obvious substance abuse cases go before us after arriving after us, I can’t suggest what it was that put her to the back of the Que but I would say if you are unfortunate to need emergency assistance then have a massive accident otherwise you have no chance of help! FYI we arrived at 6pm and gave up at gone 11pm

Let down by one receptionist on the night shift, rude and sarcastic to my daughter who had waited patiently for almost 6 hours, when she enquired about possible waiting time.
The A&E waiting room is a portacabin, attached to large new build, unpleasant and claustrophobic to wait in at the best of times, let alone when injured or unwell.

評論內容:
I was so close to stopping breathing and found out I had a severe asthma attack. It was terrifying but they got me straight through a&e and helped me straight away. I couldn’t be more grateful for one of the scariest nights of my life. The team there were amazing. I then moved to the ACU and I couldn’t fault the nurses/ team up there either! (The night nurses were a bit loud at silly o clock but they were funny and lovely so made up for it).
Thank you also to the blonde woman (sorry I’m bad with names)  from the asthma team who took me through everything I needed to know. Could not fault at all.
The only thing I will say is the male DR coming round in the day just trying to send people home whether they were ready or not. Didn’t seem to want to listen fully and wanted empty beds. Which I could understand but if I went home when he tried to send me I 100% would’ve been back that very same night. So thankfully took on the advice of others. I am not a regular hospital visitor and feel bad for being there anyway. But this was one under life threatening if not life threatening.
Just thank you to all the team in A&E and ACU. You’re a credit to the NHS and very underpaid!!!

評論內容:
My grandmother was admitted to City Hospital after what began as an infection was later diagnosed as pneumonia. During her stay, further tests revealed she had lung cancer, news that was delivered to her without care or compassion. For two months, she was placed in Fleming Ward, where the experience became more distressing than supportive. Despite being on end-of-life care, the staff did not communicate openly with us about her condition. We arrived just twenty minutes before she passed away, leaving us little chance to say goodbye properly.

Throughout her stay, the standard of care was deeply troubling. She often waited long periods for assistance after pressing her call button, sometimes up to half an hour. On several occasions, she was handled roughly, and once she was even dropped. At night, doctors would remind her bluntly of her diagnosis, showing little regard for her emotional state. When she struggled to eat and drink, no IV drip was provided, even though family members with medical knowledge suggested it. Requests for simple interventions, like a blood test, were poorly managed and left her in pain.

Her dignity was often ignored. She was left exposed during bed changes, made to wait uncomfortably for the commode, and denied basic comforts such as adequate bedding or access to a fan. The ward environment felt cold, unwelcoming, and at times unhygienic. Family members were even reprimanded for small things, like getting water.

On her final days, she appeared frightened and withdrawn, expressing feelings of being mistreated and unwanted. Her last words reflected a deep sense of mistrust and sadness. What should have been a place of care and comfort in her final weeks instead became a source of suffering, leaving our family heartbroken and appalled.

On Sunday 27/7 I was staying with my sister in Nottingham when I was taken ill. She called the ambulance service & as I was having difficulty with my breathing I was taken to the respiratory ward at this hospital. I spent 1 night there and was then transferred to the cystic fibrosis unit as there was a spare bed there. I was there for 3 nights. In all that time I had the most amazing care from all the staff. Everybody was very helpful and very cheerful. I really could not have had a better experience at an expensive private hospital. Even the food was good!
Thank you so much

評論內容:
Was in for surgery in May 2025. Parking seems non existent, the place is poorly laid out. Pre-op preparation was fast, efficient and organised. The porter was grumpy and gave me grief about having my surgery (I assume he was still waiting for some treatment and let his personal affect his professional). The surgeons and surgical team were wonderful.

The after care in Loxley ward was a joke. I was left for hours without appropriate pain relief, water for my 2 paracetamol or even my property. I couldn't call my family, they didn't inform my next if kin I was out of surgery, and my buzzer was ignored by the nurses so many times I had to walk to the nurses station carrying my catheter and drip. They ignored my request for pain relief for hours putting me in danger. I was left with blood soaked clothes and through my bed, despite them mentioning it. Also kitchen wasn't informed of dietary intolerances and they had to borrow another patient's personal food for me to have anything the next day.

It felt like the nurses were preschool children playing role play with shiny machines and no actual care.

Felt so vulnerable and in danger. Had many hospital stays over my time - this was the worst.

QMC contacted the ward in advice,on arrival we were given a chair (sign this wasn't going to be a quick pick up)after being asked what medication was on prescription (how should I know )1 hour later received prescription so off back to QMC.
How can a hospital discharge patients with medication only for pharmacy to be closed.
We have had good experiences with city hospital before but you could just not make this one up.

評論內容:
South well ward:
Amazing and sincere staff who take time to listen and understand the patient and family. It is evident that this is more than just a job, everyone went far above the expectations and their duties to make us feel and experience the true meaning of what care is.
A few special mentions:

Athira - always took time to ask how the patient (Faisal) was doing including me (Parent). Extremely polite, kind, attentive and genuine.

Eunice - always greeted me with a smile which was contagious and warming. Very caring and always ensured Faisal had what he needed. Built rapport and remembed details from conversations. Periodically checked in on us and asked if we need anything. Took extra care with responding to our requests and did so swiftly.

Sini- Treated faisal with the upmost respect by talking directly to him and kept him clearly informed in simple terms of what she was doing & explaned why. Made us feel confident in the care and process at every stage.

Sonia - greeted me each time with a smile and eye contact, made me feel valued and always explained each stage of treatment or care that was provided, like Sini, did so in a clear and simple manner.

Thank you to all the staff, you made this difficult time more easier to bear.
(On behalf of the parents of Faisal, discharged on 15/5)

評論內容:
Had an appointment with “Das” at the women’s dept. I have had many hospital consultations but have never left one in tears before. I specifically voiced that I was there for a routine appointment and wanted nothing invasive done nor did I want anything done that would require recovery and I had MULTIPLE biopsies taken without warning or consent. Das hurried out of the room before I had a chance to process what happened and left the nurses to break the news to me.

Her attitude was extremely hostile the entire appointment and as someone whose partner and friend group are all doctors/healthcare staff I expected better. They also sent me out multiple referral letters that weren’t mine with other people’s hospital number and personal information on. Avoid this hospital at all costs.

評論內容:
The staff at the Breast institute are wonderful human beings. I’ve been seen here several times over the past decade and always had a good experience. The nurses are so caring and informative and always put you at ease. Even the healthcare assistants and ultrasound technicians are always lovely. I can’t thank them all enough. NUH gets a lot of bad press and I think we forget about all of the amazing staff that work their socks off to provide a caring environment.

Parking is difficult I’ll admit that but park at Wilkinson street and get the medi link which runs every 5 minutes. If not leave at least an hour before your appointment and you will always get a spot as the turnover for parking is quite quick if you’re willing to wait. You are always warned about limited parking on your hospital letters.

評論內容: My dad having had acute bleed on brain causing a stroke and sent to Good Hope Hospital. A&E amazing so was AMU but stroke ward terrible. Despite raising concerns for his safety as at high risk of falling (my dad was a very active man and just wanted to get out of bed) they said he was in a ward where someone was there all the time as the bay was for all high risk patients. He fell out the bed when no-one was there and fractured his femur. Transferred to Heartlands for surgery to have it pinned together. 2 weeks later fell out the bed in Heartlands hospital! They knew he was high risk - yet again apologies as no one present in bay?? Another head bleed from falling! Had to stop blood thinners because he had a clot following surgery! Then moved to West Heath for assessment where it would be decided where he was to go after eg care home or back home. 2 weeks fell poorly - shaking, high temperature. Asked if they had checked for Sepsis. They did this on the Monday and sure enough it was sepsis. Rushed to QE to be waiting 10 hours in 4 different ambulances. Developed a bed sore, no fluids or drink as had to have thickeners in water. Finally a bed in A&E for 1 day and moved to AMU then to a ward in main hospital. Can't find sources of sepsis, weeing blood, trying to get out of bed, mrsa so DOLs involved and padded gloves on both hands (boxing gloves) to stop him pulling catheter out and getting out of bed. My dad crying, not eating/drinking - he is slowly being broken down by all this. What would have been my dad walking out with a walking frame is now a very frail man with more complications than he went in with, to now being bed bound to failures of their ability to risk assess adequately. Staff over stretched and working with whatever they have in place which isn't fit for safety of the public. My dad has worked all his life in UK and paid tax etc into the systems and there is nothing left for him but to take a low grade service of a broken nhs. I'm sure there are thousands out there feeling the system if failing them in many ways. I never want to get old in this country or be ill.

評論內容:
My brother was treated appallingly in this hospital’s A&E. He has a colon stoma and went in with a high fever, yet they made him sleep on the floor in a corridor like he didn’t matter. Fourteen hours he waited — fourteen hours — with barely any care or attention from anyone.

No bed, no comfort, no basic dignity. He was in pain, exhausted, and completely ignored while staff just walked past. Sitting on a chair was unbearable for him, and he was left with no choice but to lie on the cold hospital floor. It’s beyond disgusting.

They knew he needed to be admitted for another procedure the next day, yet still refused to provide him a proper space to rest or recover. How is this acceptable in a place that’s supposed to care for people?

The whole experience was a disgrace — cruel, chaotic, and heartless. My brother deserved care and compassion, not neglect and suffering. No family should ever have to go through this.

評論內容:
Poor family experiences of AE & Urology services. Improvements, higher standards of patient care and support is greatly needed. In particular to the cancer service where so far there has been no consultation, information or support for the patient and loved ones.  This is from my own family experience and I feel completely let down. I am also a staff member of many years who is very concerned and saddened on the direction of this once excellent hospital.

Update 09/09/25:  Hardly surprised by the league tables published today of the worse & best performing hospitals where UHB is the 4th worst general hospital.

評論內容:
I had my MRI done, so I called my GP to ask if they received my report. They said no.
The next day (today), I rang the MRI department, and the woman on the phone told me they had already sent the report to my GP.

I called the GP again still no report, no update.

So I called the MRI department back, and this time a different guy answered. He told me the report has NOT been sent to the GP.

Now tell me if the report was never sent, why did the first woman bother asking me for my name, date of birth, and all my details, only to give me a completely wrong answer? Working in healthcare, when people call about their reports, the least you should do is properly check, not just fire off random answers.

Honestly, that first woman who picked up the phone had no idea what she was doing. She clearly needs her own brain MRI.

評論內容:
ED the only let down in my acute surgery admission over the weekend. Despite me mentioning I had come to ED at the direction of 111 and the ambulance service (getting myself there rather than wait the 2hrs + for an ambulance) -this decision proved to be my downfall, subsequently waiting in ED with a perforated appendix for 7 hrs, no offer or visualisation of staff to ask for pain relief during this time, no communication screens informing anybody of waiting times?! Thereafter, once seen, service thankfully improved with surgery given within 3 1/2 hrs.
Thanks go to staff on the surgical assessment unit, surgical team, anaesthetic doctor and the fabulous staff on ward 620. As someone away from home, never been in hospital before- never mind in Birmingham, I was impressed with the quality of care given, the communication and the staff all looked happy to be at work. A warm and friendly professional service received- thanks all but triage needs to improve in ED- really poor, hopefully have avoided my chances of sepsis!

評論內容:
Appalling Disgusting Service Towards My 74 yr old Elderly mother! After a trip she had to AMU a few weeks ago my mom was told she had a suspected Blood clot in her leg which was believed to be the cause of her very swollen left knee & leg. AMU were great with her and provided medication to take and gave a discharge letter with appointment on it for a scan at DVT clinic on 12th September (today).
Upon arriving at 11am like the letter stated the department could not find my mom on their list, we then got sent to another department where we were told she had been booked an appointment which simply did not exist 😩😳well that’s more than fine isn’t it especially when she’s already waited 2 weeks to find out if she had a blood clot in her leg and does not know if she needs to be taken the blood thinner tablets the hospital had instructed her to take.
As anyone could imagine I was very upset close to tears as I had to book the day off from work today to take my mom to this phantom appointment that we didn’t know didn’t exist until we got there, my mom can’t manage to get to the hospital without my assistance due to how badly her mobility has been of late.
After 3 hrs in the hospital and passed between 4 departments I only found 2 nurses in DVT unit to be genuinely sorry for the massive error that someone had made, yet it wasn’t their fault to begin with. Now it’s another 2.5 week wait for a scan appointment, my mom needs to have someone with her as she does not always retain information well and they only offered crack of dawn appointments which I could not accompany her to and that would have been only a few days before 29th anyway.
A total lack of care and respect for the elderly no one seemed very concerned in most of the departments we went to. And all of this to a lady who served the NHS herself as a Nurse at the old accident hospital at Bath row Birmingham back in the 70’s.
Our lives in their hands literally these days and the appointment was in black n white on the discharge letter yet it wasn’t a genuine appointment and simply didn’t exist 😬🤷‍♀️

It seems like he does not take women’s health seriously. He followed my sister and would only allow her to go to minor injuries where they could not do the ultrasound or take her bloods which is what she went there for. My sister is crying in pain and she does not cry usually. She had been throwing up and unable to move due to the pain and had symptoms of an infection. The head of department is clearly a misogynistic man and is putting my sisters health in danger. Very unprofessional and rude!

評論內容:
I was taken by ambulance to Queen Elizabeth Hospital due to a severe asthma attack. Unfortunately, instead of receiving urgent treatment, I was placed in the waiting area from 6 PM until 6 AM. During all those hours, I was left sitting on hard chairs in the waiting room, struggling to breathe. The only treatment I received was oxygen, and no further care or proper medical attention was provided.

This was an extremely painful and disappointing experience for me. I was in severe distress and truly suffering, but I felt ignored and neglected. Even after leaving the hospital, I am still experiencing the same symptoms and feel let down by the care I received.

I believe patients in such critical condition deserve immediate and proper medical attention. My experience has left me feeling very hopeless and disheartened.

評論內容:
Yesterday evening I was admitted to A&E via 999 Ambulance.

The Ambulance staff were absolutely amazing thats where it all changed.

Upon arrival I was informed by the Ambulance Crew that I had to be taken off the stretcher, and put into a wheel chair, even thou they informed the A&E staff this wasn't possible due to the injury I had. (Slipped disc and trapped siatic nerve) I was then left standing in A&E for over 2hrs before I got assessed and given pain relief, via morthpine,  however this was given to me standing up, where I felt very wozzy. Again no bed was offered, and the drug was given to me in a corridor where she left the seringe in my arm whilst she went and checked her paper work.

After another 2hrs I was told to go into a consultation room to be assessed, after 40mins of waiting a nurse entered the room and told me to get out as the room as it was needed for another patient. I tried to explain that the pain I was in it was not possible for me to do so, she was very rude, and told me and my wife to vacate the room now, and to wait in the waiting area, again standing in a lot of pain.

Finally at 04.37hrs I was seen by a Dr and told that they know what my injury is and to go and see my GP inregards to a scan, I was told to move from there to the treatment centre where I was given some more morthine and a diclofenac suppositorie. Then I was told I could go home.

My wife asked for pain relief for when I get home as the morphine would wear off in the morning. We were told that they had ran out of pain relief and to go to the pharmacy in the morning.

I'm now at home with no pain relief and the suppositories are still not ready, leaving me in alot of pain.

The service I received from all of the A&E staff was absolutely shameful, and to be sent home in pain with no pain relief is totally diabolical.

No empathy was shown at all by any of the nurses in that department. Being a former employee of the QEHB and seeing how the department is now was a complete shock.
Something really has to be done about this, the major trauma centre for the West Midlands to be told I can not have a bed and no pain relief then to be sent home, is a disgrace.

評論內容:
I am extremely disappointed with the infection control standards at Queen Elizabeth Hospital Birmingham.

On Friday, 15th August 2025 (Ward 518, Room 3), Sister Nurse Otilla (Team Leader) was about to administer my husband’s PEG feed without wearing gloves. When I raised my concern, she argued with me and said: “Why do I need to wear gloves? Should I wear gloves when feeding him through his mouth as well?” These were her exact words. Only after I strongly insisted did she put on gloves. I found this behaviour unprofessional and unacceptable, especially from a Team Leader who should set the example for others.

In addition, when my husband was in AMU Bay E, Bed 25, on the 13th August, nurse Hadiqa caring for him did not wear gloves at all, even though nearby patients had visible wound infections. This creates a serious risk of cross-contamination and endangers patients’ health.

To make matters worse, when I raised my concerns further, the Ward Manager told me that wearing gloves is not necessary. I completely disagree. My husband already has a PEG tube and developed a catheter-related infection that has made him very unwell. Infection prevention measures, such as wearing gloves during invasive procedures and when caring for patients with infections, are a basic NHS safety standard.

As a family, we are trying our best to help my husband recover so he can move forward with rehabilitation. Seeing such a careless approach to infection control has left me extremely frustrated, worried, and disappointed.

評論內容: This was my dad’s main hospital during his terminal cancer treatment. Due to the type of cancer he had, he had to have a feeding tube fitted as he could not eat food orally. The staff at this hospital fit the feeding tube and the same night he was back in a local hospital with signs of sepsis as they had fitted it wrong and it was piercing his stomach lining. They didn’t even bother checking to see if it was fit correctly through a scan / checked if it was measured correctly for his size. Because of this, he had to stay in hospital for 3 weeks with infection & had to have the feeding tube re-fitted. When he finally went back to queen Elizabeth to see if he could continue his cancer treatment they said no due to losing so much weight being in hospital for so long with minimal food. His McMillan nurse was absolutely awful towards him saying that “these things happen” and being completely dismissive. As a trained PROFESSIONAL these things should not just happen and had the correct precautions been taken while the feeding tube was being fitted then my dad would have been able to continue his cancer treatment and may have been here for longer. I feel completely let down by the staff that’s main priority is meant to be the patient, especially the McMillan team who get so much praise but the only time my dad ever saw or heard off them was when he was physically in hospital and didn’t check on him. The only positives were the palliative nurses however, who were so caring towards my dad especially in his last days. I can’t praise them enough for how they put a smile on his face and would always come when he needed them quickly & would stay as long as he needed them for. I hope no one else has to suffer from the medical negligence at this hospital the same way my dad did.

評論內容:
I am writing to express my deep dissatisfaction with the experience I recently had during my blood test appointment.

Firstly, the initial nurse was unable to find a suitable vein and managed to collect only a few drops of blood. As a result, I had to wait for 3 hours until another nurse could take my blood properly.

After the test results came back (about 2 hours later), I saw the doctor who then informed me that an additional element needed to be checked in my blood — something that, in my opinion, should have been tested in the first place. I then had to wait an extra 2 hours for the second result and a further 4 hours to be seen by the doctor again.

This resulted in a total wait time of nearly 9 hours for something that could have been handled more efficiently with proper planning and attention.

I kindly request that you review this matter internally to ensure a better experience for future patients.

評論內容: I can’t review ward 412 at the QE more positively after the way both of my parents were looked after on there . They had a motorbike accident at the end of 2023 and both taken to ward 412 . My Dad was in a really bad way and died in the ambulance and bought back to life . The whole time my parents were in the QE I can’t fault any of the treatment . The staff on 412 even took my Mums bed into my Dads room so they could watch the fireworks together on New Year’s Eve as it was my Mums birthday at midnight . My Dad was given a cutting edge operation to take a muscle from his back to put onto his ankle to save his foot and he was in a terrible way and a terrible patient but the staff were fantastic with him . The whole team have done their best for him . He’s been in and out of the QE numerous times with infections in his leg and each time he receives nothing but the best treatment . The team deserve so much respect for the work they do and the sights they see . My Dads leg is not pretty even now but at least he’s still got it after they gave him 20 mins to decide if he wanted his leg removed . It’s been a long 18 months but he couldn’t have asked for more from the staff at the QE. The NHS at its best .

評論內容:
Shocking, my husband was on the acute respiratory ward which means that the patients are meant to be monitored more closely. The nursing staff were great but the ward sister was  arrogant, rude and totally lacking in compassion. I don't know how he got to be at the position he's at it certainly wasn't for his ability to care for patients. My husband asked for a towel so he could have a wash  and still hadn't been given one by late afternoon when I arrived for visiting and luckily had brought a towel in for him. The most shocking thing of all was that they put my husband on DNR (do not resuscitate) they should never have done this without discussing it with nxt of kin they basically talked him into agreeing when they knew full well he was suffering with memory loss and confusion at the time due to a lack of oxygen to the brain and couldn't remember half of what the staff had said to him. He couldn't even remember the conversation he'd had with them abt going DNR. There were other incidents during his two wk stay but its just to much to go into. I spoke out abt his treatment to the ward sister and was spoken to like I was nothing, he was so rude and when I asked a question abt a certain matter he blatantly lied to me abt who could help me with a certain situation and said
he didn't know, however the nxt day I found out that he was in charge of sorting this particular thing I'd asked abt. So he obviously took a dislike to me just because I stood up for my husbands rights and expressed my unhappiness at the way in which his care was being handled.....which was inadequate and unprofessional. A disgrace, Q.E used to be an excellent hospital but its really dropped its standards

評論內容:
Came into A&E after fainting 5 times in 12 hours. Lost consciousness each time with no warning.
I am diagnosed with a heart problem that makes sudden cardiac death more likely. The biggest warning sign of cardiac arrest is fainting with no warning.
Had an ECG which came back abnormal, waited hours for bloods to come back to then not see a doctor and have a nurse walk past and tell me I can go home.
Against all guidelines and completely unsafe!!!
No arrhythmia identified even though ECG was abnormal, and no attempt to find the cause of the fainting.
Very neglectful and just all round poor performance.
This means I now need to travel to another hospital to be seen.
God knows how many people have died a preventable death in this place because doctors can’t be arsed.

評論內容:
I had an appointment on Thursday 26th June 2025 with Dr Mark Thaller, I'm not going to lie I was very anxious mainly due to this being my first time at Queen Elizabeth Hospital and also slightly anxious about my appointment.

Dr Thaller was absolutely amazing, he was very welcoming towards me and my mom, he asked both of us questions and he then explained to me about what treatment options were available to help with my migraines and he didn't interrupt me, Dr Thaller was very knowledgeable about some of the things that might trigger a migraine attack and he made me feel at ease throughout my appointment.

I would also like to thank the staff who guided us to where we needed to go. Also I would like to thank the gentleman on the main outpatient reception for booking me in because the self service kiosk wouldn't scan my appointment letter it kept saying that there was no record of the appointment.

The reason why I was at Queen Elizabeth Hospital is because the Neurologist at Walsall Manor Hospital wanted a second opinion due to medication not working to stop my migraines and so I was referred to Dr Thaller's headache clinic and I am grateful I was given an appointment 2-3 months after my Neurology appointment at Walsall Manor Hospital.

I would very highly recommend Dr Thaller's headache clinic and Dr Thaller to anyone who is like me and suffers daily from migraines/headaches and you have tried so many different medications. Thank you all at Queen Elizabeth Hospital for making my visit less stressful.

評論內容:
I have travelled to this hospital many times for treatment over the years and have always found it to be a positive experience. Not TODAY !!
Part 1) I arrived as always 30 minutes before my appointment so 8:30am and decided to grab a bite to eat beforehand so chose the “spice of life restaurant” in the foyer next to Costa which I haven’t tried before.
After initially being ignored I ordered a sausage and bacon bap. Asked if I wanted a drink I decided against that as the prices for a coffee ranged from £3.60 to over £4. I was charged £5.70 for the bap omg! After picking myself up off the floor I made my way to the seating areas. The tables are all very badly stained and the floor was disgusting, chairs with stains on and littered with food matter. It looked filthy and unsanitary I was shocked that I was expected to sit here and eat food. I decided to sit around in the costa coffee part as the tables looked cleaner. Anyway the first bite of the bap was absolutely disgusting, both the bacon and the sausage were cold and the bacon was gross, not much meat and far more fat than anyone could stomach this early in the morning and dripping in grease. The sausage skin was so tough I had to take it out to bite it and bap was drier than the bottoms of Jesus’s sandals. The bread just disintegrated in my hands, it’s unforgivable for a hospital concession to serve this dog food. Needless to say I abandoned it and left.
Part 2) Made my way to the normal out patient dept needing in mind I have been coming here for some years, at reception the administration staff member didn’t even lift her head to greet me but just looked disinterested and said “date of birth?” Then turned to a male staff member at the desk and said “should she sit down here?”
I could see the waiting area was very busy already and some patients were coughing so I asked the male staff member for a FRSM (Fluid Resistant Surgical Mask) he said “what’s one of them?” I then said a mask please can I have a face mask?
He then HANDED ME A MASK FROM A BOX ON THE DESK but it slipped onto the floor
NO 1 RULE: DO NOT HANDLE THE FACE MASK AS A THIRD PARTY IN ANY WAY SHAPE OR FORM!!!!!!
He then proceeded to hand me another before I said please do not handle the masks for me that goes against everything we have been advised since COVID? He then shrugged his shoulders and gave me the box. Unfortunately he wasn’t wearing his name badge so I cannot identify him.

I’m extremely disappointed around the way I have been treated today. From the catering staff to the clinical. No sign of putting patients FIRST and clear breaches of INFECTION PREVENTION & CONTROL PROTOCOLS
I know the NHS is in crisis but haven’t witnessed anything first hand until today.
Following my appointment I cried in the car having felt 100 % let down by the service  and very overwhelmed by it all.
After working full time my whole life and paying my Income tax and National Insurance Contributions I’m now realising as a nation we are truly screwed. It’s so sad.

評論內容: My brother died 6 months after having a liver transplant. Due to being transplanted with a virus (kaposi sarcoma) which has no cure this is  something he should have been tested for! He was diagnosed with PSC after falling ill and the care up to the transplant was great but after he was re admitted 4 months after the transplant, the doctors and care was horrendous all round. He was admitted to the icu we were never kept informed. We were told by one of the nurses to prepare from him to die and then the doctors told us different. When we got told that he had contracted the virus he was transplanted with (kaposi sarcoma) Dr Janmoahamed told me over the phone while I was stood in the hospital that “this was all just a bit unlucky” imagine being told that the chances of him surviving were not good and those were the words of the consultant! No compassion by any of the doctors or consults at all, felt like he was just another failed transplant to them and on to the next.

評論內容:
Absolutely appalling experience at Queen Elizabeth Hospital Birmingham.

If I could rate this place 0 stars I would my friend has been sectioned and is currently under their care, but the treatment she’s received is nothing short of neglect. She was left alone and in distress, and ended up hurting herself while in a room that was supposedly meant to keep her safe. Staff only removed harmful items after she’d already done damage this is a clear failure in duty of care. There were no regular check-ins, no proper monitoring, and her fiancé who was actually trying to help was pushed away and separated from her, even though she was the only one who could actually calm her during an episode. Instead 4 male staff members pinned her down which triggered her ptsd

For the last five days, she’s been left sitting on hard chairs, with little to no comfort or dignity. While staff stood around chatting at their desks, my friend’s mental health has deteriorated further, and yet they still refuse to discharge her. Instead of helping her recover, they’ve made things worse.

This place is supposed to provide care and protection, but all we’ve seen is mismanagement, lack of compassion, and serious negligence. Deeply disappointed and incredibly concerned for her wellbeing.
