評論內容:
The neurological team missed a subarachnoid hemmhorage in my Grandmother's brain after CT and MRI scans. She was sent home with no treatment plan after a full-on stroke because they were miffed and couldn't be bothered to look further into it.

She then had another and was treated at a separate hospital in Ipswich where the new stroke was properly diagnosed and then they found the old one there that the QE missed.

Pure incompetence from the consultant staff.

評論內容:
Bad. Bad bad BAD! I’ve never been so humiliated and embarrassed when in the worst moments of my life. I was having episodes of excruciating pain and weeklong flares of excessive nausea & vomiting and I needed help. I repeatedly visited the A&E over 3 years whilst at University. I had no clue what my issue was, but it turned out to be a simple one. They always ran basic bloods, gave IV fluids for severe dehydration, told me everything was fine and sent me on my way. I was repeatedly berated by staff for being “in the way” and asked why I had come here as i’ve been before and nothing had been found, so why was I back, what did I expect from them? I EXPECTED MEDICAL HELP. I was scared and suffering, away from everyone I knew. Why would I want to be in the worst place imaginable whilst suffering, for fun?? So many stories I could tell about the nightmares of this hospital. This was not my first port of call, I had been to my GP, urgent care, walk in centres so many times just looking for ANYONE to listen and help me, but because I was young no one cared and was always told it was stress, anxiety or, my personal favourite diagnosis of “too much google”. I couldn’t even pick up a pen never mind look at a phone. I was 18 so had no idea what the proper route was to get help and was too sick to do anything but what I was told by “professionals”, which was go home, wait and see. At one point I was given medication that I was allergic to and vomited in the street having a reaction on my way home. They also gave me steroids and made me take them then and there and sent me home. All 8 pills, on an empty stomach of over a week. No advice or explanation as to what it was. It was the most excruciating experience I have ever had the displeasure of existing in.
After being told repeatedly by my GP and hospitals in Birmingham (over THREE YEARS) that nothing was wrong with me and I essentially needed to get a grip, a simple trip to my GP in my home town up North found that I was riddled with massive gallstones. Because of the negligence of birmingham doctors, my health and immune system has plummeted and my body no longer wants to absorb any vitamins — they are dangerously low. I live in fear of food and have no appetite from the length and depth of suffering I experienced. I have a phobia of ANY new medication from the pain of my stomach turning itself inside out from countless incorrect meds and advice from this hospital. I suffered from multiple chest infections and serious complications as a side effect of my body deteriorating slowly over the 3 years I tried to seek help from anyone. Viral gastroenteritis slapped on every diagnosis (NEVER mentioned to me). At 21 my liver is now severely damaged and I am in pain every day of my life. Laughable that my liver levels were one of the only “further” things tested and picked up on in this hospital, but was NEVER mentioned to me. When I asked for my records (which was a difficult process) there was a clear deterioration of my liver upon every test. Three years later I am still trying to get to the bottom of this. My results are now off the charts. I have a vitamin D of 10, and nothing will help it. TEN. The treatment in this hospital is disgraceful. I experienced it and I saw it all around me. You will only receive help if you are actively dying. They don’t have time for anything else. At one point they told me I was having a pulmonary embolism and sent me home to come back the next day as it was “too late” and the machine was closed. They gave me a blood thinner that made me feel like a pile of mashed potatoes and sent me on my way. When I asked for pain relief for my severe pain I was told to go buy some paracetamol and it was slapped on my permanent records that i’m desperate for analgesics and to watch out for me. Also put on numerous times that I smoke excessively and roll X amount of cigarettes everyday — I DON’T EVEN SMOKE! Quality of care here is disgustingly bad.

評論內容: I learnt in random way on the 17th Feb that my younger brother had died in an ambulance or QE Hospital after collapsing on the street on the 6th Feb. The hospital didn’t bother to contact the next of kin and both my brother’s landlord and myself have been given conflicting info by the hospital. No one from the medical team would speak to me when I travelled over 100 miles to view the body, except for a nurse that wasn’t on duty in the hour and 20 minutes my brother is said to have been in the hospital. I walked over 9,000 steps from department to department, making calls and speaking to hostile staff on the medical examiners team trying to get information about my brother. My son and I were shown no dignity, kindness, compassion or respect and I can only conclude it was because my brother, his nephew and I were black. I was repeatedly told there was no next of kin on the system during my visit on the 24th Feb but this was a lie. Of course I’ve complained but I have no expectations from staff. This hospital should be shut down as it’s clear all the best staff have been transferred to the Harbone private hospital connected by walkway. One of the staff members I spoke couldn’t speak English and he was telling me off! It’s atrocious and even if I was accompanied while ill, I pray I never end up in this hospital.

評論內容: Absolutely disgraceful! I brought my 19 year old daughter who has Downs Syndrome here she had slipped down two steps at home, and had hurt her foot so we needed an xray. We got the xray and was told it was ligament damage and to go home rest, elevate it etc. Great! Next day we received a phone call informing us that the radiographer had checked the xray and there was a fracture and could we bring her back! So I struggled to get her into the car because she was in pain. Got to the hospital, left my daughter in the car asked at the reception of A&E for a wheelchair, no sorry go down to the main entrance and ask for one there! So I had to leave my daughter in the car to go round the hospital looking for a wheelchair! I then took my daughter into the hospital and waited 2 hours only to be told that she had a fracture to her foot... Really? No cast, no boot nothing else. Why couldn't you have said this on the phone? Whilst we were there we were one of four other patients who had been there the day before who were recalled! Absolutely shocking. So if you suspect a broken bone you won't get any help just sent away twice to simply get on with it!

評論內容: A family member was admitted to ambulatory care on 7/02/25 the early morning staff were ok… and the surgical/theatre team and her consultant Dr Jolly were amazing! However after she was brought to her bed(13) on the ward in ambulatory care the service went downhill they were not caring or compassionate, all they cared about was staring at you and watching you incase you did anything wrong instead of looking out for the patients needs. The patient couldn’t  speak or understand English and nothing was explained to her family neither were they contacted or spoken to when they went to pick her up. We were told she was ready to leave once we got there they still had her cannula in they didn’t give us an update from her doctors visit. If the nurses don’t care enough then a family  member should be allowed to stay behind to help the patient.

評論內容: When I was finally seen after attempting to commit suicide 3 days prior I was very emotional and shook up about what was going on. The first "doctor" was the most horrid person I ever met, he consistently asked me to explain what's going on and when I did he would constantly interrupt me. After asking this "doctor" to stop interrupting me he continued to do so until I had to raise my voice due to him causing an anxiety attack. This "doctor" then pressured me with questions relating to my attempt to take my own life after I confirmed that I didn't really want to go too deep into the details as I was still very shook up about everything. Once the "doctor" caused my anxiety attack he threatened to call security on me even tho I was referred to them by the crisis team and was brought in on an ambulance. A sweet nurse then came in and got the "doctor" to leave me alone. I felt trapped and bullied in answering questions I didn't want to answer due to them being sensitive. 8 hours and 4 IV drips later I was told I can leave which really took a weight off of my shoulders. I went to the toilet before I left and when I came back to gather my things I was told I was to stay overnight with another 8 hour IV fluid drip that I was not told about once. As a mental health patient with sleeping issues I was expected to sit in a room with everyone else, unable to sleep with no additional things from home due to the fact I was not told I would be staying overnight. This caused another bad panic attack which resulted in them giving me oxygen. They then said that my release will finally be arranged. It took 1 and a half hours to get me 1 box of antibiotics and to remove the cannula from my arm all while still having a panick attack. In conclusion I would not wish this on my worst enemy and now I'm pretty certain I've gained a new phobia.

評論內容:
I have been treated for Crohns disease for many years at QEHB. There are several complications of this condition with no cure. It can cause debilitating symptoms to many parts of the body. Thus, i have had many surgeries. My most recent being another lengthy surgery. Its always frightening to be so poorly that you can bearley move for pain. However, my experience at QEHB has been excellent. Last year i became ill, once again with complications which could have lead to sepsis. Following regular consultations with Gastroenterology and Dermatology, a plastic surgeon was involved. This was concerning, of course, but i realised it was necessary... my quality of life was very poor. The surgery, in September (2024), was a success. I came out of theatre feeling better than i have felt in several years. I was no longer in pain, and my fear of sepsis diminished. I have often spoken to an IBD community for sharing and advice. I was not alone in my suffering, but others were so afraid of long and complicated surgeries for fear of "disfigurement". I am now happy to let others know that living with such a disabling condition was not an option for me, and could be helpul to others who have been struggling for too many years. Years of medical treatments can also cause ill effects as well as reistance. Antibiotics are one thing but spending many years on opiates can be damaging too, adding more complications to an already difficult disease.
I would like to thank both medical and surgical staff for their efforts. Several hours of surgery, to turn a life around, is definitely worth it.

評論內容:
Was admitted as emergency for acute abdominal/appendix/colon twist. Staff were amazing and received rapid IV antibiotics and fluids to prevent sepsis.  Emergency surgery and great explanations pre and post op.  36 hrs of exemplary care - thank you.

My only issue was the appalling discharge lounge adjacent to ward 108.  This was an ill managed service where the nurse in charge was clearly unable to manage the service.  She constantly asked people who they were and on one occasion accused me of leaving the area.  When I told her I had been here throughout ( two others agreed with me!) she said I was wrong … by which time I and others were frustrated and annoyed.
A gentleman (whilst in the discharge lounge) was in obvious pain due to massive delays in his pharmacy prescription as part of his discharge.  He was given a “top up” of meds in full view of the discharge lounge adjacent to- this involved squirting meds orally.  That’s not on.
Another man had been in the discharge lounge since 0930 thst morning (this was now 1400) awaiting an ambulance transfer.

A gentleman arrived hoisted into a chair, showing to all his incontinence pad and dressings.  It was awful and embarrassing to everyone in the “lounge”.

Treated like cattle.  Surgical side was excellent and huge thanks to them but the discharge lounge - well - nightmare .

A LOT of work needs to be done on discharge lounge - it feels tacky, it feels poorly organised and most importantly, it feels devoid of care and disrespect.
cleaned_text: was admitted as emergency for acute abdominal appendix colon twist staff were amazing and received rapid iv antibiotics and fluids to prevent sepsis emergency surgery and great explanations pre and post op hrs of exemplary care thank you my only issue was the appalling discharge lounge adjacent to ward this was an ill managed service where the nurse in charge was clearly unable to manage the service she constantly asked people who they were and on one occasion accused me of leaving the area when i told her i had been here throughout two others agreed with me she said i was wrong by which time i and others were frustrated and annoyed a gentleman whilst in the discharge lounge was in obvious pain due to massive delays in his pharmacy prescription as part of his discharge he was given a top up of meds in full view of the discharge lounge adjacent to this involved squirting meds orally that s not on another man had been in the discharge lounge since thst morning this was now awaiting an ambulance transfer a gentleman arrived hoisted into a chair showing to all his incontinence pad and dressings it was awful and embarrassing to everyone in the lounge treated like cattle surgical side was excellent and huge thanks to them but the discharge lounge well nightmare a lot of work needs to be done on discharge lounge it feels tacky it feels poorly organised and most importantly it feels devoid of care and disrespect

評論內容:
I had an emergency operation last month at the ERI. While the staff were all great, the food was, at best, adequate, when I was able to eat. The ward was overheated, and the pillows were small and lumpy - unlike anything I’d ever experienced before.
My treatment, on the other hand, was exemplary.
They really need to look at the nutritional needs of patients, how the food is cooked and kept fresh for serving. Possibly using fresh instead of packets.
And, maybe invest in some decent pillows!!

評論內容: My mother recently passed at the hospital and being in the hospital late at night after 11 all I noticed was nurses standing about chatting and when asking one for help for something simple getting them to engage was not easy. The stories of the NHS ran off their feet may well be true in A&E etc but these wards late on at night you won’t see any nurses bursting a gut or working hard. My mum was on a bed hunched over looking very uncomfortable until we got her adjusted to be much more natural in her position on the bed. Asking a nurse anything about my mum on the ward all I got was generic answers she is settled in for the night etc utter nonsense. They all seemed desensitised and lazy and when asked for basic help it was like asking for blood from a stone.

評論內容:
On Sunday, May 18, 2025, I had a motorcycle accident in Edinburgh around 3:30 p.m. The ambulance arrived within 10 minutes, and I received first aid.
The paramedic on board the ambulance (Steve...) was extremely professional and compassionate. He carefully ensured that I was as well as possible immediately after my accident, and I would like to express my sincere gratitude for that!
Due to the hospital's extreme capacity on that Sunday, I had to wait a few hours in the emergency room.
All the staff present (nurses and doctors) constantly checked on my well-being and provided me with painkillers and drinks as needed.
The "service" was exceptional, despite the obvious high stress levels for everyone!
After all examinations were completed, I was transferred to an observation unit (the "ward") overnight.
Here, too, the staff were dedicated to my well-being until I was discharged on Monday afternoon.

I would like to thank everyone involved at the hospital from the bottom of my heart!
At no point after my accident did I feel like I was alone in the situation!
cleaned_text: on sunday may i had a motorcycle accident in edinburgh around p m the ambulance arrived within minutes and i received first aid the paramedic on board the ambulance steve was extremely professional and compassionate he carefully ensured that i was as well as possible immediately after my accident and i would like to express my sincere gratitude for that due to the hospital s extreme capacity on that sunday i had to wait a few hours in the emergency room all the staff present nurses and doctors constantly checked on my well being and provided me with painkillers and drinks as needed the service was exceptional despite the obvious high stress levels for everyone after all examinations were completed i was transferred to an observation unit the ward overnight here too the staff were dedicated to my well being until i was discharged on monday afternoon i would like to thank everyone involved at the hospital from the bottom of my heart at no point after my accident did i feel like i was alone in the situation

評論內容:
I want to express our experience with medicine in Scotland and it will be very positive 🤓
My grandmother was diagnosed with bilateral pneumonia and a virus. We were admitted to the emergency room in a serious condition.
Due to the lack of rooms in the respiratory department, we waited 27 hours in the emergency room for a bed in the right department - but all the necessary treatment was prescribed.
Then we were transferred to the respiratory department, I have never seen such service and treatment!
All medications, artificial lung ventilation, oxygen, massage, computed tomography, X-rays, heart cardiogram, blood tests, regular checks (every 2 hours), immediate responses to needs, choice of food on the menu, water change, bedding, in my absence - doctors called me and reported the plan and results of the work done, cleaning was at the highest level.
The doctors come to the revue twice a day with a clear plan and conclusions, what has been done and what will be done and whether it is effective.
I am shocked that my grandmother said that her legs hurt and the head doctor (not a physiotherapist) lay down on the floor and began to massage her legs + called a physiotherapist and began to do exercises and prescribed treatment for her legs.
At night, she had a fever, so the nurses started wiping her from sweating and changed her clothes.
The treatment itself is very effective, every day my grandmother felt better than yesterday and it was noticeable.
Beds, equipment - everything is at the highest level, you won't see this in private hospitals.
I can write a lot, but in one word, SHORTLAND MEDICINE is TOP !!!

Grandma is at home, we let her out for Christmas Eve and we are grateful to the doctors, nurses  and God that everything is fine and that she is healthy 💛🤓

評論內容:
I took my son to A&E because his temperature was 40°C, and our GP was closed. I wouldn’t have gone unless I felt it was serious, but I had no other choice. When we arrived, the children’s section was completely empty, yet we were told to go to Urgent Care and wait for four hours.

It was really upsetting to see my sick child waiting that long, especially when others in the waiting area didn’t seem as unwell and were laughing and chatting. I don’t understand why the nurses took his temperature, saw how high it was, and still sent us to Urgent Care instead of getting him checked right away.

This system feels broken — families shouldn’t have to wait hours for care when their child clearly needs medical attention. We pay for a service we can’t even use properly when it matters most. Very disappointed.

評論內容:
Writing this at 2 in the morning, as had this most unprofessional experience with an assessment nurse in a&e this evening, at 12-1am on october 20. Turned away a patient to sit in urgent care centre for the next 5 hours not a&e ward, who was clearly struggling to breath and had chest pain, very onset and sudden.
Not only did she not do a thorough evaluation- didn’t listen for any chest wheezing, but then was overheard complaining to colleagues about the patient and him putting on a show to get seen quicker.
Why would we come to a&e if it wasn’t a life threatening concern. Every Google can tell you struggling to breath and chest pain go see a&e.
Absolutely unprofessional to be complaining to colleagues about the ones that rely on them for proper care.
Will be following up with PALs as it was appalling.
No, we were not there to misuse your time, unlike others. It’s a shame they’re overused and misused as it affects their care onto others.

評論內容: The dermatology department had me waiting for nearly an hour and did not inform me or apologise for the wait. I had to ask and when I did I was just told “not yet, she’s having problems logging on to the computer” she didn’t even know why I was there, really?! No notes or nothing. I’m sorry but that’s not good enough because if I was late due to transport, they’d be quick to say “the doctor can’t see you as you’re late”. Then the appointment begins and I went to show her what’s on my chest, we were first in the consulting room where people could look in, my chest was out then she mentioned how maybe we should go in a room for “privacy” but at point, it’s defeated the point. After those 30 seconds we went back to the consulting room and then I told her what are my options and the only option I had, she tried to say that I would look more “less atheistically pleasing”. What a choice of words! This is a huge confidence issue for me and she sure made me feel 10 times worse. The appointment literally didn’t even last 5 minutes, maybe 3 minutes, tops. Classic NHS but still just an awful experience. ChatGPT is probably more helpful than today’s visit.

評論內容: From the bottom of my heart, I would like to thank Dr Rehan Khan for his humanity and real care for his patients. I was one of his patient in my last pregnancy back in 2023 and he carefully follow me and sincerely listen and support me throughout. I am now pregnant again and unfortunately had to register in a different hospital for personal reason. The experience there has been awful and at 34 weeks of pregnancy needed to change hospital urgently. I contacted the hospital and Dr Khan again exposing my difficult and anxious situation. He was really prompt again to support me through the process of rebooking at royal London and dealt with my problem within hours of requesting his help. Through him the entire team has been soooo helpful and understanding. He had no obligation to do it as I am not his patient at this present time but helped me without hesitation.!It is really rare to see doctor who still really care about patients and do whatever they can to help but Dr Khan does it naturally and even his attitude when speaking shows that this is really the type of human he is. God bless you and protect you always for the kind and caring person that you are beyond being a doctor.

評論內容:
Worst experience I've had in a hospital in my life! Was taken there by ambulance due to being knocked of my bike by a van. Suffered multiple breakages in my body, face required stiches and braces. They didn't even keep me in overnight and discharged me the very same day - and I had to find my own way home, as well as pay for the taxi. Before all that, I was left inside the corridor by the main entrance when brought in by the ambulance with not even given a blanket and left in my boxers. In the ambulance, they cut open my clothes but had no blanket, and when we arrived at the royal london I was left in the corridor at main entrance in full view of everyone for hours. Not one member of staff thought it was a bad look to have someone laying on an ambulance stretcher almost naked at their main entrance. But they made it a priority that I wasn't allowed to move or even if it meant to use the toilet - but they gave me a bottle made of cardboard, as a substitute for a toilet! When I finally was taken in for x-ray I was physically assaulted by the staff member, as this staff member struggled to understand that being flattened by a van had left me severely injured and treated me as though I was putting up resistance. My helmet would also be stolen somehow, and the staff argued with me that its something I didn't need anymore (or was important) because it was damaged. The staff were just trying their absolute best to get rid of me and didn't hide it. So much so, it was until I made it home, that a needle was found still left in my arm from when they took my blood! USELESS staff, so much so it was no surprise that my official complaint was brush under the carpet by their complaints  team - their official excuse for their staff conduct and me being discharged the same day from an accident was that they were experiencing some glitch with their computer system that day. But I know NEVER to seen in that place again - it's a shame that place and its staff can't be given less than 1 star because if I could I'll give them a minus grade!......oh and two days later from being discharged, I went to another hospital (a proper one) and their x-rays found both my arms had breakages and placed them in castes

AVOID AT ALL COST!

評論內容:
A few days ago I had the most severe pain in my lower abdomen and after a few hours in agony my wife and I went to the Emergency ward at the Royal London Hospital.
It was crowded and everyone was really busy but I was looked at by a nurse after about an hour’s wait and then sent to the UTS department. It took another couple of hours before a second nurse took some more data and did a few other tests.
I was then seen by a GP who sent me for a CT scan that later confirmed that I had a kidney stone.
After the scan the renal consultant spoke with me twice. The second time to confirm the diagnosis and to give me my prescription, that I subsequently picked up from the hospital’s pharmacy.
All in all it took about 10 hours to do the preliminary testing, urine and blood test and the CT scan, and to get my diagnosis and prescription.

I am writing this post to thank the medical team that treated me; the nurses, radiologist, GP and renal consultant along with everyone else who works at this hospital, especially the security and cleaning staff and the young nurse who came around to the waiting area to take everyone’s blood pressure. (I went on the 1st of September at around 11pm and left on the 2nd at around 8am. )

I was afforded the best possible service from start to finish, and all with a smile. Thank you all for this wonderful service.

Finally I would like to mention that I am visiting from Canada and that in spite of not being a UK resident I received this fantastic service. What is even more amazing is that when I asked for my bill the young lady looked at me and said that I owed them nothing and that this is all part of NHS. Including my medication!
This is not something we have in Canada.

Thank you Royal London Hospital and thank you NHS !

評論內容:
My wife came into the A&E Monday with a bad cut from a fall. From being checked in, to waiting, to finally being seen and treated, the whole ordeal took about ten hours. To give them a little slack, they were busy, clearly shortstaffed, and we were informed that there is a strike of some kind going on; we're from the states so this wait time isn't uncommon to us, it'a just unfortunate that it was bad timing on our part. They treated us in the waiting room when her cut reopened, got into an exam room for a CT scan, and eventually stitched up in an actual room. It was a bit unfortunate that they told us to wait in the waiting room for discharge, but again... they were busy and short staffed, so I understand. The staff there were very nice to us and helped ease our anxiety on the whole situation, even though they were also dealing with other patients who were not so pleasant.

However... the follow up is why I'm inclined to write this review and give it a lower rating.

We were told to come back on Friday to ensure that my wife would be able to re-take her blood thinners in order to fly home on Sunday. We came back, and they were very confused as to why we were there because apparently we were supposed to get a telehealth call to follow up and not be charged for an in person visit. We were very grateful that they were doing that for us, but unfortunately... they never called us. We called them every few hours on Friday and Saturday and EVERY TIME we were given the runaround: doctors are too busy, doctors are changing, call back in about two hours, etc. We were even put on hold for almost an hour before it disconnected and no one had any idea we were on hold.

So we were put in a very hard scenario where we had to either continue to call and get ignored, or go to the hospital and be seen/charged for the visit for what would likely be a five minute conversation. We also told them the urgency of the situation as we were flying out Sunday, but it didn't seem to matter.

We thankfully ended up getting a hold of our actual doctor who was on call in the states and he gave us the medical advice we needed. We still have not received a call from the hospital and we fly out in about sixteen hours.

The past two days have been filled with so much anxiety and concern for absolutely no reason. All the doctor had to do was call us, ask a few questions, and give us their verdict. I would not have been opposed to doing an in-person visit in order to be sure, but we were reasuured that we would be getting a call and we never did.

I'm keeping my fingers crossed that things are going to turn out okay for us, and whatever is going on with these strikes right now, because this was very disappointing and made an already stressful situation much, much worse

評論內容:
I had an extremely distressing experience at this hospital. The environment was unclean and the staff were unprofessional. Despite having a suspected broken foot, an open bleeding wound, severe pain, and breathlessness, I was not given a wheelchair, crutches, or any form of assistance. Instead, I was forced to walk. I experienced what felt like discriminatory treatment — I noticed certain patients being prioritised ahead of me based on background, while I was left waiting for hours.

I had a panic attack in the waiting area, yet there was no care, compassion, or urgency shown. The nurses were dismissive and showed no concern for my injuries. This was one of the worst healthcare experiences I have ever had, and it has left me feeling traumatised. No patient should be treated this way.

評論內容:
Was sent for an MRI from whipps Cross and was told later the next morning it was sciatica and its a painful condition.
I 100 percent knew that was b.s because of the pain I was in was excruciating I mean excruciating.
The doctor is gas lighting me into a condition I already suffer with and used it to get rid of me sending me back to Whipps Cross for pain management. I haven't slept since Thursday its now Sunday.
I left whipps Cross after them also down categorising my serious life threatening pain and sent me back to a&e to stand up for another 10 or more hours which I had been doing for almost 28 hours already as I could not lie down the pain was so bad. Yesterday Saturday after leaving whipps Cross and returning home I had to call yet another ambulance to take me back in after serious projectile vomiting and still unable to sleep.
It turned out to be kidney stones.
Unacceptable behaviour by both hospitals putting my life at risk as a vulnerable adult alone with no family support.
How dare doctors from 2 separate hospitals gas light and somehow it ends with me apologising to them for being so upset when they were 100 percent responsible.
Denise a nurse on the ward was the only good thing to come out of this nightmare so I've given a couple stars for her alone.
Needless to say I made sure paramedics did not return me to either hospital instead ending up at st George's in Goodmayes where a simple urine test would have helped with the diagnosis.
I had another MRI a ct scan and a tummy scan pregnant woman had.
The stress and pain of these deplorable people who call themselves professionals isn't acceptable and I will be taking legal action against these 2 hospitals.
Shocking care failures who shouldnt Carry the title of Dr spok  let alone a qualified doctor.
Don't go to any of them especially whipps Cross.

評論內容:
I recently had a hospital stay via the Paramedic team who attended my home and assessed me, they were very polite, caring and professional and decided to take me in an ambulance for further assessment at The Royal London Hospital. I was admitted and treated for 8 days in hospital.

Initially I was in A&E for two days in a room, very well looked after followed by admission on ward 11E, 11F, and 14E and I just want to take a moment to express my deepest gratitude to the entire medical team. From the nurses to the doctors and every staff member in between, your compassion, professionalism, and dedication made a world of difference during a difficult time. I was treated with such kindness, respect, and attentive care every step of the way. It’s clear that you all genuinely care about your patients—not just physically, but emotionally too. Thank you for going above and beyond to make me feel safe, supported, and truly cared for. You are all amazing, and I’m incredibly grateful.
Mrs J Khalisadar

評論內容:
Vicky the triage nurse!

I’m genuinely shocked by the dismissive and unprofessional attitude of a triage nurse named Vicky at the A&E department. My brother arrived with a suspected blood clot (this is what the GP said) and shooting pain in the left arm, a serious medical concern. Without taking any observations — no blood pressure, temperature, oxygen levels — she immediately sent him to Urgent Care (Out of Hours GP). No explanation, no urgency, just a brisk redirection.

When I questioned her approach, she confidently gave her name as if she was doing something right. Meanwhile, intoxicated patients were sitting in the emergency waiting area, being treated as higher priority.

It raises real concerns about unconscious bias and the inconsistent application of triage protocols. A suspected blood clot should never be brushed off like this.

I’ll be following up with PALS to understand whether this is standard procedure or a case of serious negligence. Either way, the level of indifference shown today was unacceptable.

評論內容: Maternity: great during pregnancy and during labour. The worst aftercare. 3 years on still have PTSD from being left unable to move and no-one coming back. Baby fed formula without permission (despite me being in a bed in the next ward). When my baby choked on day 5 I did my own CPR (im trained) because no one was around, exept a receptionist that was too busy trying to cover my boobs up. She choked because the nurse didnt properly check my feeding finger technique, after i asked doing it for the first time "is this right?" She said it was whilst standing at the curtains. And due to poor aftercare I ripped (despite being a csection) and have had 5 surgeries to repair it over 3 years in a different hospital. I wouldn't go anywhere near royal london for maternity after care and i am only writing a review 3 years later because I just woke up from another night terror remembering what they did to me.

評論內容:
On the 13/10/2021 my mother attended the RLH for day surgery to have a hiatus hernia repaired, she was in good health and suffered with no high risk factors other than her issues with the hernia. While in the hospitals care she contracted a virus/bug and this wasn’t picked up by them, she had to stay in over night due to her vitals being low. On the 14/10/2021in the early afternoon she was discharged and had to endure a long car journey home(over 40 miles as the consultant wouldn’t come to her local hospital which is where my mother should have gone)in discomfort. When she arrived back at home I was there to greet her and could see she was in a lot of pain. During a sleepless night she had sweating and complained about her breathing(which she told me over the phone while she was on the recovery ward that it was slightly shallow), these symptoms were taken as post surgery symptoms as the hospital gave no information on what to look out for, they also didn’t check her vitals before leaving the hospital, something I’m sure would have given an indication of her need for help.
In the early hours of the 15/10/2021 around 18 hours after surgery she asked me to help change her nighty, while I was helping her she displayed confusion and said she couldn’t breath and felt as if she was going to faint, I told her to lean on me and in a beat she collapsed on the floor, I had to struggle and give her cpr while calling for an ambulance. The ambulance crew and air ambulance service worked on her for an hour but sadly she could not be revived… after weeks of her being with the coroner they confirmed she had died of acute respiratory failure caused by bronchial pneumonia(from whatever virus/bug my mother picked up from the hospital which with her immune system being low accelerated into BP), this caused her lungs not able to provide her body with oxygen and her heart went into cardiac arrest from working/struggling too hard. The hospital investigation took almost a year with them holding back paperwork and ultimately, not accepting liability. Their paperwork showed she was ok to be discharged, this is something I believe was not right. The media continues to report on failings nationally where the NHS and Trusts(in this case Barts)have failed patients with many different conditions, I believe the NHS is sadly full of people inadequate of doing the job and providing the proper care so many need. But things are being covered up. I believe the RLH killed my mother and they should have accepted their failure, because she deserved better. If you are attending this hospital I pray you don’t end up getting the same poor standard of care my mother did, something that will stay with me for the rest of my life.

The NHS is broken and part of that, is certain people working within it.

Rest in peace my amazing mother.

評論內容:
My mum was in a hospital nearby waiting to have knee surgery. While there she fell ill and needed to come here to A&E as it was the closest one. We knew there would be a long wait, as always, but seriously? We took her there at 6pm Friday and although she was spoken to a couple of times she wasn't properly seen to until 7pm tonight (saturday)!!!! That is crazy! You will have surgery in the morning...oh sorry we are busy so not this morning this afternoon... oh we don't a room ready so no not this afternoon this evening. Surgery finally happened around 8.30pm. Also dirty hospital. No toilet paper in the toilets and someone's ripped jeans left on the sink in the toilets. Yuck!

Would also like to add that a lot of the other hospitals would go patient by patient and write their discharge letter by patient. Here they go to every patient first and then write all of the discharge letters together which takes longer and is prone to more mistakes. 11am discharge papers not ready although told she could go home. 3.30pm still here... no discharge letter still

I had a very disappointing experience at this hospital. The staff were unprofessional and unhelpful from the moment I arrived. Despite having an appointment, I had to wait for hours without any explanation or updates. The nurses seemed overwhelmed and inattentive, and the front desk was disorganized and rude when asked for assistance.

Communication was poor throughout my visit, and I felt ignored rather than cared for. Cleanliness also seemed to be an issue in the waiting area, which was dirty and overcrowded.

Overall, the lack of compassion, efficiency, and basic courtesy made what was already a stressful situation even worse. I do not recommend this hospital and hope they seriously consider improving their patient care and service standards.

評論內容: Can only give 5 stars to the staff who are clearly working their butts off to get everyone seen as fast as possible. I had no less than 10 staff looking after me who were all clearly busy so I really appreciated them all. I had a really thorough visit including tests, a scan, medication and general checks so even though it took a few hours what more can you expect when pretty much everyone is in the same boat? They do their best to see people on order of urgency, for instance I was seen immediately then others took priority once they’d run my tests and realised I’m not critical. A little patience and some manners I’m sure would be welcomed from some of the other patients I had to share the waiting room with. Thank you and hopefully wont be back to A&E but if I was I’d feel in safe hands

評論內容: While the wait in time at The Royal London hospital for an appt at 11 lasted for 5.5 hours, it’s understandable given the stress the nhs is under. Makes me realise how important it is to fight for this institution and demand increased funding from government to support innovation and good organisational leadership. They were all clearly overworked and under pressure. Most of the staff were really caring and friendly, a few seemed disconnected from the job, but sparking conversation with kindness and humour worked a treat. I had an amazing anaesthetist called Charlotte who put me at ease and made me feel calm and relaxed, ready to face the situation. Layo in recovery was a real sweetheart too. While ultimately these care workers see many patients go through every day, their work is essential to supporting a healthy society and I am grateful for their dedication to what may sometimes feel like a thankless job. There seemed to be a lot of camaraderie on the ward which was nice to see/feel. Keep up the good work. And thank you. There will always be challenges with large organisations. Stand up for and support our nhs. It’s made up of a diversity of people from all walks of life. Be as compassionate to them as you would like them to be to you. I’m recovering nicely and am grateful for everyone that helped on the day.

Honestly, I was looking for a hospital to go asap as I had really bad tonsillitis and a fever - this was one of the best care services I got. I went on to A&E at midnight and was seen very quickly, never waited more than 30min.

The nurses were really kind and caring, always checked on me. I did cry a lot as I was in a lot of pain but they would constantly check if I was ok,  did my tests, got out on a drip, asked me questions and communicate with each other.

I left at around 11am because they wanted to make sure I was ok to eat by the time I left but honest shout out to the nurses, at least 3 of them, I wish I had their names 🤍

評論內容:
What a refreshingly positive experience we had at our Royal London Hospital Children's Outpatients appointment on 14th May at 0950 for the brilliant Dr Daniel Crespi's Clinic.

By now we are seasoned hospital visitors, but that doesn't necessarily make these experiences easier. My seven-year-old daughter and I received exceptional card and expertise.

The entirely mysterious lift "system" in this hospital continues to utterly elude and bewilder, disorientating all who dare to commit to this vertical strategy through necessity or otherwise...however...

Between merry lift dances, we had the pleasure of meeting the most WONDERFUL nurse who listened to me, empathised and understood, making a huge impact on my little daughter's mental health and wellbeing; Dr Crespi, a very kind and brilliant consultant who also listened and made some very sensible recommendations; and an attentive dietitian.

All these people made the appointment a breeze: in fact, everyone from the train to the waiting and consulting rooms was as taken with my beautiful, lovely and impressive daughter as ever 🥰, and I came away with some positive options to reflect on.

I would love this to get back to the professionals involved, including the nurse's manager - I wish I'd given her a hug, so please pass one on from me as well as recognising her brilliant work. 💙

評論內容: The sort of idiocy you would expect from the NHS. I accompanied my partner who had a potentially life-threatening condition and my partner was given an ECG then told incorrectly to wait back in the main waiting area (which I queried and they reiterated). We waited for several hours then when I further enquired they admitted that they should have sent us to urgent care and failed to. So our name had been called out several hours earlier at urgent care while we were waiting in the wrong area, where our name would never be called. And this was for a potentially life-threatening condition that they had assessed as urgent. Imbecility of the highest order.

評論內容:
I had a terrible experience at The Royal Londob Hospital. I came in with a dangerously high fever (up to 39.1°C), severe dizziness, chest pain, a painful cough with phlegm, body aches, and even lost consciousness at one point. Despite these serious symptoms, the only advice I was given was to take paracetamol and go home—no proper examination, no tests, no real concern for my condition.

I felt completely dismissed by the medical staff. A high fever with dizziness and loss of consciousness should not be ignored, yet I received no meaningful care. This level of negligence is unacceptable, and it could put patients at serious risk. I strongly urge the hospital to improve its standards and take patients’ symptoms seriously.

I do not recommend this hospital to anyone seeking urgent medical attention. If you are experiencing severe symptoms, I suggest going elsewhere where you will actually be examined and treated properly.

評論內容:
Maternity care at Royal London was appalling. My pregnancy journey with their midwives was a nightmare—I wish I had trusted my instincts and transferred hospitals sooner. The midwives were overstretched and clearly exhausted, and I never saw the same one twice, leading to constant conflicting information. Appointments routinely ran late, often by an hour, and shockingly, I was even assigned the wrong blood group.

I was booked for an induction two weeks past my due date as I was carrying an LGA baby. On the morning of my appointment, I called to confirm and was told they were running two days behind schedule and couldn’t see me. After being passed from one department to another with no clear answers, I finally contacted Homerton, who were incredible. The difference between Homerton and Royal London was stark—Homerton’s staff were kind, caring, and efficient, and I gave birth later that day. Despite a stressful morning trying to find somewhere to give birth, I’m glad it lead me to the Homerton. I felt safe and well cared for. They couldn’t believe I was allowed to go overdue with a big baby.

Throughout my pregnancy, I felt anxious about giving birth at Royal London, and I deeply regret not transferring sooner. They showed no concern, offered no apology, and never followed up after my traumatic experience. I would not recommend Royal London, especially for first-time mothers.

評論內容:
We were treated extremely poorly by the receptionist at the emergency room. We are tourists, and my husband was feeling very unwell, so we went to the ER, where the receptionist was completely rude to us. She refused to answer our questions about the form and even went as far as mocking us, making the sign of the cross and rolling her eyes. My husband’s blood pressure was very low, and he had to sit down quickly to avoid fainting, but she simply called the next person in line and left us without any assistance. I took a taxi, and we went to St. Thomas Hospital, where we were treated with great kindness.

Reading the comments below, I saw several complaints about the receptionists at this hospital. If you lack the sensitivity to work with people who are sick, then find another job!

評論內容:
I have mixed feelings about NHS services and once had a bad experience at RLH. however today I'll give it five stars for the wonderful service of the Colposcopy clinic. From rescheduling an appointment to the consultation, the team shows their empathetic approach and patience.

I must add, Mrs Anna Parberry - The Nurse Colposcopist - is wonderful. The moment I arrived at their reception I saw many awards for her such as NHS Heroes. Anyways thank you ladies for what you do - your service truly makes a difference! ❤️

評論內容: My first experience with the British NHS and lord have mercy was it horrible. Thank god all I needed was stitches in my finger, but I had to wait 7 hours on a Monday night and I still don’t have any feeling in the top of my finger 5 months later. People who had just been arrested were being brought in here, there were homeless people sleeping in the corner, a guy listening to music at full blast. Jesus Christ there was a lot going on and all I needed was to get out of there. Sure it was free but it was also torture and I’d rather pay than deal with that again. I was sent to another part of the hospital to get stitches, only to wait there for 2 hours and be told they didn’t do stitches in that part of the hospital. You really can’t make this up. The only redeeming thing about this place is that there were a couple of nurses/doctors that were incredibly nice, and I do understand the amount of pressure they are under on a day to day basis.

Terrence Clark is the most friendly, outstanding staff I’ve ever met, the hospital overall was average but I rate it 5 stars solely because of Terry. He’s a healthcare assistant who is so devoted and empathetic to each and every patient. He's genuinely so caring and compassionate, he’s cared for both me and my father on separate occasions and has always remained friendly, respectful and professional despite working hours on end. I truly wish others can learn from him as the positivity I received from him truly makes a difference.
Thank you Terry for the wonderful experience at Royal London hospital.

評論內容:
To the Doctors and Staff of the Critical Care Unit, The Royal London Hospital at Whitechapel:

I want to extend my deepest gratitude to the entire team at the Critical Care Unit for the exceptional care provided to my wife from December 25th to December 29th of 2024. Your professionalism, compassion, and dedication made an immense difference during a challenging time for our family.

Doctors and Medical Staff: Your expertise and meticulous attention to my wife's condition were evident throughout her stay. The clear communication and comprehensive explanations offered by the medical team gave us confidence and reassurance. Your swift and decisive actions, combined with your unwavering commitment to her well-being, were truly commendable.

Nurses and Allied Health Professionals: The nursing staff's constant vigilance and tender care were profoundly comforting. You not only addressed my wife's medical needs with precision but also offered emotional support to her and our family. The allied health professionals, including physiotherapists and dietitians, contributed significantly to her recovery through their specialized skills and collaborative approach.

Support Staff: The seamless operation of the unit would not have been possible without the tireless efforts of the support staff. From maintaining a clean and safe environment to ensuring that everything ran smoothly, your behind-the-scenes contributions did not go unnoticed.

Your collective efforts provided an environment of safety, compassion, and hope. We are deeply grateful for the exceptional care you provided and for the dedication you demonstrate every day. Our heartfelt thanks to each one of you for making a difference in our lives.
Special thanks to IZZY, Nurse, Maureen, Nurse, a Tibet Nurse (name not known), and few others.

With sincere appreciation,

Imran Khateeb, PA

評論內容: This hospital is a joke. I have a knee injury in my knee which is a cyst, Ive been to a clinic near my home which they have referred me to this hospital, i had two options, to get a surgery to remove it or a injection. I came to the hospital before i got referred because ive been having chest pain, quite alot of swelling around my knee and high temperatures around 38.7. The staff were nice and seen me quickly. When i told them about my temperature they checked it and it was 35.9, is that seriously a joke. Then they told me i look completely okay and theres nothing wrong with me. As i told them about my high temperatures at home they told me they dont look at those ones but only the ones they check at the hospital. I have also told them about my cyst and they told me they cant do anything about it and they do not do injections in this hospital which is quite strange because ive been referred here for the injection or the surgery. Second of all im on cruthes at the moment because i cant walk from the pain and my fever keeps on rising constantly. So i went to a different clinic for a blood test and a check which i had to pay for because NHS clearly didnt help me and told me im fine. My blood test came back and turns out i have a chest infection and a different doctor will be seeing me for my knee to arrange a injection or a surgery. Was it that hard for this hospital to give me a blood test or to check my chest? If you are planning to go to this hospital, its a waste of time.

I meant to have my surgery today at 9.30 through a letter that got delivered to my home. I waited 3 hours of my time just for them to tell me that my surgery got cancelled.
The hospital should at least phone me the day before or at least an hour before to tell me my appointment got cancelled.
Very poor and wrong information to give to the patient and bad time schedule.
Has to be fix up or they would loose the patients in the future.

評論內容: I would like to express my immense gratitude to my consultant surgeons from the Limb Reconstruction Clinic, Mr. Kavi Patel and Mr. Dimitrios Sarris. On November 20th, I was operated on by them. The operation was very complex and took over 6 hours. Broken orthopedic screws and an implant were removed. 4 centimeters of bone were removed at the fracture site and a nail was placed to stretch the bones. I have been living with a non-union femur fracture for four years and many doctors refused to treat me due to the complexity of the case. I thank Dr. Kavi Patel for his immense professionalism and care for me. He came every day to monitor my recovery. I thank my nurse Mark from the intensive care unit and Jed from 4F. Thanks also to the physiotherapists from 3F and Dan from the Fracture Clinic. The Royal London Hospital is a perfect place for treatment with many professionals. I am happy that you are treating me, stay healthy and always so dedicated.  to their patients.

評論內容:
Lost my partners shoes during intake (after the ambulance, during the ER > ward transit)

The nurses were nice enough to look for the shoes, never found. Gave him jelly for his troubles...

3 days later, got a text from him, hes been "discharged", canula removed, bleeding into a sink, locked doors between us. Took me 30 mins on arrival to find a person with a key card to get in to the ward. Horror show in the room, blood over the floors from getting his phone to call me for help. Help alarm in his room is still going. No asks if he's okay or help to get the bleeding under control, just turn off the alarm and said someone will clear the room up after we're gone so don't worry (about cleaning up all the blood)...

Next time, I'll pay for a cab to take us to UCLH, instead of the free ambulance to Royal.

評論內容: I was appalled by the awful treatment patients received when visiting maternity triage in the evening of Thu 19 Sep. It feels like if this standard of care continues, a mother or baby are going to end up dead because of the neglect shown. We were encouraged to attend triage (6F) because we were worried about the baby’s lack of movement. No one was at reception when we arrived at 7.45pm. We waited half an hour to be checked in without any explanation of what was happening. Once checked in we went to the hospital station to give notes to a midwife but no one was there. We waited another 20minutes until we saw our first midwife and got to hand in our notes. After another period of waiting, we asked how long it would take to speak to someone about the baby not moving. We were told they didn’t know, and as they had only just come on duty, they didn’t know what was going on, or where the doctor was and were told to sit down. I feel we were spoken to better as a white couple, because I could see that when Bangladeshi couples went up to ask the same question, they were met with hostile responses to sit down. One couple who had been there for hours were mocked because they said they were exhausted and wanted to go home, and encouraged to self discharge. The total lack of empathy was astonishing. They treated vulnerable women with disdain. The midwives acted as though they did not want to be there.

評論內容:
I am writing this complaint to express my deep concern regarding an extremely distressing experience my friend encountered during her visit to your hospital today.

After arriving for treatment, she was left waiting for an extended period without any updates. Only after she inquired herself did a nurse finally check on her status. Shockingly, this was followed by a loud argument among staff members, which we overheard. Disturbingly, the nurse in charge of my friend’s care was shouting, stating that she “doesn’t care” about my friend’s condition, even saying that “they should die for all she cares,” while placing blame on the doctor instead of addressing the situation professionally.

This behavior is not only highly unprofessional but also poses a serious risk to patient safety and well-being. The lack of accountability and communication demonstrated here is unacceptable and could potentially endanger lives. We believe that such staff members should not be employed within the NHS, as their conduct undermines the quality of care expected.

We demand that this situation be investigated immediately and that appropriate action be taken against the staff involved. Additionally, we request a prompt update on how this matter is being addressed.

Thank you for your attention to this serious issue. We look forward to your swift response.

評論內容:
I have never seen such shocking neglect and incompetence in a hospital. I was left waiting over 16 hours for my pilonidal treatment, and not one single doctor or surgeon bothered to see me. I was told not to eat or drink, so I spent more than 24 hours starving and dehydrated, in constant pain, completely ignored by staff.

Every time I asked for an update or to speak with the surgeon, I got the same useless response — “they’re busy.” Busy doing what? Ignoring patients? There was zero communication, zero compassion, and zero professionalism.

This hospital should be ashamed of itself. The way they treat patients is disgraceful and inhumane. If this is the standard of care at Royal Sussex, it’s no wonder people lose faith in the NHS.

評論內容:
Lacking for staff welfare.

Rest - There's no appropriate rest areas for night shift workers. Have to sleep screwed up on a waiting room sofa in a family room or on rolled up bedrail covers in a cupboard.

Food - There's no affordable place to eat since they closed down the subway, never enough time to leave the ward to go across to the restaurant. Which also isn't affordable unless you get a jacket potato which are very limited.

Security/ID - The ID Suite (office to fix ID badges) has really inaccessible access hours. How can Monday - Thursday 07:30-15:00 serve the entire hospital????? When most of our 2nd breaks start 15:00. Then Friday is even worse 07:30-14:30 with them closing for break at 12:30-13:00.
It should be open a few minutes before our shift so we can not have our day interrupted without being able to get in places. E.g today I had 15 extra minutes before my shift but couldn't go to the office as it opened at 07:30, that means I can't get into the staff room to store my lunch and have to pester people to let me in all day. Why should I sacrifice my lunch break to go and join a queue?
Then waiting till the end of the shift is impossible as it's closed. It also closes for lunch for a long time. It really needs to be expanded to meet staff demand , it's way too small and not enough workers.
I had to go on my lunch break just to be dismissed and informed that the staff room access had to be granted from the ward manager. If the person this morning just listened to my request instead of sending me away because they weren't open, I wouldn't have wasted my time twice today.

評論內容:
Not very impressed, spent 4 hours in a&e with excruciating sciatica. I knew it was sciatica so imagine my surprise after a 4 hour wait to see if there was more they could do to manage the pain.. I was told.. nothing more than I was doing already (taking co codemol and Neproxin) could be done and that in 12 WEEKS time if I’m still in pain I can put myself forward for physio.
So no scan, no MRI.. numb leg, excruciating pain.. a job to hold down, a family to support and that’s it.. ‘wait and see’ ..
wouldn’t mind so much if it was the dead of night and incredibly busy but it’s a Thursday afternoon with not that many people waiting. I feel completely unsupported and now potentially have weeks and weeks ahead of pain and not being able to return to work.
So there you have it.. if you can get to another a&e in sussex then I would opt for that. RSCH fail again!

評論內容:
What a wonderful hospital , staff so overworked but helpful and mostly very pleasant!

BUSY A&E as to be expected

Did 7 hours there with my Autistic Grandson who did SO well with the noise and crowdedness

Not enough room for all of the beds in A&E but that did not shock me and 7 hours in A&E is long yes but they were THOROUGH in regards of my intense pain which turned out was a hernia

We were actually on holiday when this happened ie acute and concerning amount of pain in my tummy so being from London the wait times there are seriously WORSE , so I was not surprised about the lack of bed space etc and the staff all did incredibly well!

I only got upset at the end as waiting for my meds to take home approaching 10.30pm took such a long time and we were both beyond exhausted and I had eaten nothing at all all day and My Grandson had not had his dinner and was tired etc

Turns out he actually LOVED it there at the hospital and the friendliness of the staff and other patients he ended up NOT wanting to leave when I was shattered and beyond exhausted and needed some food and my BED , so all was well when I chased up my pain killers and off we went with nothing but PRAISE for this hospital and it's DEDICATED staff who are literally run off their feet and I do not know how they DO it tbh and a huge well done of GRATITUDE from us to all of them!!! <3 <3 xxx

評論內容:
My husband & I were taken to the RSCH A&E Dept. by ambulance last Thursday evening, while on holiday.  I'd suffered a cut to the back of my head when I lost my balance on a steep slope & crashed my head into a parked van! The ambulance staff were kind & reassuring & even though the circumstances were awful, the whole ethos of the Dept. while we waited was calm & professional.  The wait time was minimal compared to other hospitals & the Information Board with approximate waiting times was regularly updated.
I was examined by Meirian Evans & Harneet Kaur who could not have been kinder.  They talked me through what they were going to do at each stage which enabled me to relax & trust everything they did.  They explained clearly what we should & shouldn't do once we got home & handed me a copy of the letter sent to my local surgery.  We can't thank you both enough for looking after us so well.
The receptionist also deserves a mention as she took away the stress of us having to phone for a taxi, all with a smiling, caring disposition.  The taxi driver was amazing too - very thoughtful, looking after our well-being with a warm taxi.

評論內容: My husband was blue lighted to RSCH in September 2024 and taken straight into Resus.  At no time did any of the medical staff speak to me so I had no idea what was happening.  My husband was left in A&E overnight in a cubicle meant for one person but there were three patients in one cubicle.  My Daughter and I couldn't even get to his trolley because they were too close together!! There were dirty dressings and bedding left on the floor and discarded surgical gloves.  After 48 hours, he was given a bed on a ward where he spent 8 days.  Not once was he given a gown and it was only the clothes I brought in that meant he had a change of clothing.  The toilet on the ward was blocked, which meant patients had to walk to another ward to use their toilet facilities.  I have no words for this hospital.  The parking facilities are disgusting and add to the stress of appointments at this hospital.  Sorry about this review but something needs to be done.  I have no problem with my Husband's consultant for his ongoing treatment.

評論內容:
The new hospital design and layout is utterly bizarre—so much empty space, with long distances between everything. It’s deeply flawed. The reception desk is enormous and completely unnecessary—remember, this is public money. The corridors are a maze of long, sterile white walkways.

As for the old wards at the back, the nurses and all staff are wonderful, but the wards themselves are swelteringly hot. It’s incredible how nurses and doctors manage 12-hour shifts with barely any airflow. As a patient, the heat was unbearable. The staff are the only reason it was even remotely tolerable.

The food is some of the worst I’ve ever eaten—just junk, the cheapest of the cheap TV-dinner food, with nothing remotely healthy on offer. I wasn’t expecting gourmet cuisine, but I also didn’t expect food so lacking in nutritional value.

評論內容:
I visited Royak Sussex A&E yesterday evening as I had just had a rather bloody fall on Brighton s unique seafront curbstones!
Having received some almost instant and compassionate care from passersby at the site of the fall, one of whom produced a totally magical icepack, my wife whisked me the short distance to A&E.  I walked into A&E, a stumbling old man shedding blood everywhere. I was dealt with immediately by competent, compassionate staff who staunched the blood flow and cleaned me. Subsequent treatment was of the same standard and I cannot praise the whole team too much. Thank you

評論內容:
An absolutely exceptional hospital. Yes they may be busy and they may be crowded but the true level of care, compassion, and actual knowledge is unparalleled.

Ive sadly had to use a number of hospitals around the country in the past and the one thing I've always noticed is that as much as the nurses are always kind, the Drs not so much. Often being judgemental and rude as if they didn't want to be spoken to. At the RSCH I even had a Dr apologising for my treatment elsewhere as I said to him "I know you'll be peed of for me asking but I have to".

If you have the opportunity to go here rather than Worthing for an example. Go here.

11/10 In my opinion

評論內容:
It is genuinely with regret that I give the RVI a one star. In areas they are trained in they can be second to none, and some staff work their socks off.

However, I was tested for severe allergies to 2 types of Local Anaesthetics, and the tests never made it to my records.

For 25 years I was challenged when I pointed out that I had these allergies. This happened often and comments like “You’re just afraid of needles” and “You are putting us to more expense” hurt, and were upsetting.

God knows what was written on the secret parts of my records ? But the way I was talked to indicated that I must have been written off as a hypochondriac.

This poor service culminated in me being given numerous injections of one of the dangerous local anaesthetics, and they won’t admit it or even retest me to try to find a newer safe alternative.

The RVI even wrote to my MP denying they used a local anaesthetic via extensive injections.

(As of End September no re testing has been carried out, and no admission of the drug's use has been made.)

RVI : “Great if you fit in their square hole, Hell if you don’t”

評論內容:
Terrible hospital
They treat patients like animals
One particular receptionist was extremely racist towards me and my mother. I saw her talking to a white family before me with a big smile on my face and as soon as i come forward her face turned into pure disgust - which i could ignore. But then she continues to speak to me in such a patronising and disrespectful manner. I told her my mum is unconscious and is really struggling, yet she still spoke im such a sarcastic manner and rolled her eyes and gave me soo much attitude because i misheard her? I had to go back to her 10 minutes later and as soon as i went up she said go sit your mum down first im busy right now and completely ignored me - my mum was unconscious very visibly and needed some attention asap. And when i went back she just pointed towards another person and said talk to her not me.
I understand she might of had a long day at work but thats no excuse for racism- i was the only person she was treating like that otherwise she was very friendly to all the other white people.
Also my mum was unconscious and i was told a nurse will see her to assess her after 3 HOURS and the doctor might take 5- 6 HOURS!!!!
I took her home because that hospital is no use.
I asked for her name and I only got her supervisors name - sacha clarke who actually apologised to me.
I really want action to be taken and i will be talking further steps to make sure that happens because its just wrong and im glad i know how to stand up for myself but some people may struggle to do so and they shouldn’t have to go through what i did today just to get some help.

評論內容:
My experience at RVI was traumatising. This may not apply to all, I had an emergency C-section and after that was in Maternity ward that was transitional care. This was due to the fact that my son had a feeding tube.
I'm not going to type everything out but in short:
1) The older the staff members the less empathy for women.
2) Told women after csection to be "up and about" after hours after surgery when women asked them for help.
3) One of the midwives kept force feeding my son because she just refused to listen that I said that the teat was the issue not him. In the end she gave in and I was right.
4) Lots of people, no air in the room and constantly babies crying so absolutely 0 rest for mums or babies.
5) Visiting times were 08:00-20:00 but, people had little 10 people visiting them and so there was no space or air. And some men stayed untill waaaay later and staff members were scared to say anything.
6) Were very disrespectful to women as soon as partners left.

評論內容:
I cannot thank the team at RVI Hospital enough for the outstanding care and support I received during my delivery. From the moment I arrived, every single member of staff—from the midwives to the doctors—was kind, patient, and reassuring.
The midwives were truly incredible, making me feel calm and supported throughout the whole process. Their professionalism, compassion, and dedication made such a difference during a time that can feel overwhelming. The doctors were attentive and explained everything clearly, ensuring I felt safe and in the best hands.
The facilities were excellent, and I always felt well looked after, both physically and emotionally. I will forever be grateful to the RVI team for bringing my baby safely into the world and for treating me with such care and respect.
Thank you for making such a special moment in my life even more memorable. I couldn’t have asked for a better place to give birth. ❤️❤️❤️

評論內容:
I know some people complain about the NHS, but in regards to the RVI I have nothing but Praise.

I know they have kept me alive to my grand old age of 77 and whenever I needed them I have always been dealt with by lovely people, caring, thoughtful, expert… So I always feel safe and relaxed.

I was in Dermatology on Monday to have a skin problem removed from my scalp. My doctor was really kind and immediately diagnosed it, then I was quickly shown into Nicole and Michelle who removed the offending growth. Both girls were very gentle, caring and really nice. Couldn’t thank them enough!

Well done as always, RVI.

評論內容:
My husband recently underwent major surgery at the RVI and I cannot praise the medical and nursing teams enough. He was admitted to hospital after the surgery and stayed for a few days.
The surgeon, Miss Randhawa, was so professional, knowledgeable and helpful. We were reassured that everything would be fine. She made us feel as if my husband was the only patient she was dealing with and took time to answer any questions and concerns we had.
The ward staff on ward 46 were also truly amazing. They were all so helpful and compassionate at all times while having to care for high dependency patients. A huge thanks to Tracy, the staff nurse, who was able to calmly deal with all manner of situations so professionally and compassionately.
We are incredibly grateful to everyone at the RVI. All too often the NHS is criticized in the media. This is not our experience. The RVI at Newcastle is an amazing hospital and should be cherished by all.

評論內容: I recently injured my hand whilst preparing food with a large kitchen knife. I was bleeding badly and needed an ambulance - which thankfully arrived within ten minutes. From the ambulance crew to the RVI nurses, from the receptionists to the porters and then up to the anaesthetists and the surgeons who operated on me, everyone was uniformly brilliant. Follow-up appointments were also great. I genuinely don't have a single complaint, it was a humbling experience. Where would we be without the NHS? Thank you so much to everyone at the RVI!

評論內容:
I went there for an appointment. But the Imfirmary has a well deserved reputation. It is very good.
I was an in patient for 81 days  and those N.E Nurses  are good lasses. They know their stuff.
The Doctors and Consultants are extremely specialised in what they do. There is NO second guessing with those guys.

Update 10/ 6/ 25
There is no getting away, how good this Imfirmary is.
Now let me tell you about the extras.

1 There is a Cinema to use, with all the latest films for the  long stay kids and adults.

2 There are about 3 cafes in the infirmary.

3 Also 2 shops.

4 There is 1 hairdressers/ barbers, though there should be more.

5 N.H.S Chemist. Though there should be one at each end of the Imfirmary.

6 There is also 1 A.T.M. Again there should be more. 1 at least at each end of the Imfirmary.

7 There should be more seating throughout.

Nevertheless the care given by the staff, is second to none.

I have to say it's been 7 years since I've had to ring 999,for an emergency boy the NHS has changed its not National Health Service,it's National Help Service,I had a pop varicose vein never seen so much blood I was the first call out for an ambulance crew they were ok the younger guy wasn't as nice as the other 2 a trainee and a more experienced paramedic.That was average but when we got to the hospital that was a different story patients in corridors some really poorly ones the first nurse we seen was lovely from Canada why she came to our National help Service is beyond me.anyway she was lovely put my daughter at ease she was struggling. We went to a side room they left my door open and all you could see was nurses walking around talking etc patients still waiting in corridors I was there 5 hours and some of the patients were still in the corridors when I left,it's crazy the NHS was one of the main should I say the main reason the UK was put on the map not any more and your asking for another pay rise some of the doctors deserve it some don't,those who don't should give £10 a session back everytime they spoke about something other than patients save your holiday and your small talk for your breaks,patients are waiting longer than ever really poorly patients they need your help not you to talk about what your doing on a Friday night after work or your holidays.The NHS is on its knees don't even no if it can be saved without a rich country buying it,it's a shame.And now after my first visit to the district nurse I've have found out the nurse that dressed my wound never put any mesh over the wound so what she did put on stuck to my open vein it's a good job I had a nice nurse who didn't just pull off the old dressing and it's a good job my instincts told me to go and see the nurse 3 days early even the district nurse said to me it's a good job I didn't leave I until my original appointment it would have been like concrete and could have cost me a longer stay in a hospital who doesn't have a clue what there doing.my 17 year old daughter could do a better job.
And you have the nerve to ask for a pay rise again,seriously give it to someone who actually provides a decent service,oh no I forgot there isn't anyone in the UK anymore.If I could give a minus 1   I wouldn't hesitate.

評論內容: I have mixed feelings about this place. Under the care of neurology or on various wards I’ve been in I’m looked after quite well and some doctors are amazing! bar feeling like things are taking too long and I still haven’t been referred for some tests I was told I needed months back!. My medication was mixed up three times but I got an apology as this meant I was unable to drive or work. However i have slight trauma even thinking what happened to me in a&e. I was took in by ambulance and made to sit in a busy corridor full of people in beds waiting on a hard plastic chair for 13 hours due to overcrowding.(no one’s fault and some people needed more help than me).  I was begging for paracetamol and shaking with the pain after about 6 hours. People kept saying they needed to ask my doctor if I could have pain killers but six hours later I was vomiting with the pain to the point I lay on the floor and still no pain killers. Eventually I was told I had a badly fractured skull and given some painkillers and told to return in a day or go elsewhere due to overcrowding. Most horrific experience ever.

評論內容: The A&E experience was quite good although I was made to wait for about 4 hours before being seen as the hospital was nigh overloaded. The doctor that had seen me gave me an examination and correctly guessed my diagnosis even without having the blood test results yet, which later confirmed the diagnosis. She was brilliant. The day care was a whole different can of worms though. I was made to wait ridiculous hours to be called up for an ultrasound. It must have been at least 6 hours before I suspected that something was wrong. Either way, I just left as I couldn't bear it any longer. They later admitted that they "lost me in the system" and that's why I hadn't been called up for so long so effectively that means that I waited for bloody nothing. Some brilliant people working here as well as borderline incompetent hence the mixed review.
