Unfortunately I ended up in hospital for a week and I have to say I was very surprised how good the service was in St Thomas hospital. They really looked after me well and made sure I had a safe and speedy recovery.

The meals on the other hand lol 😅
They weren’t actually as bad as I imagined them to be.
Every morning they you bring you a menu and you get to choose your lunch and dinner.
They have a few choices for you to choose from and you get dessert which is always a good look!
They take their time to serve the meals so they were sometimes a bit cold.
But overall you can’t complain!

The hospital pet scan  department itself nice and clean , reception pleasant, gentleman who took me in was really nice ,made me feel comfortable, the ladie that took my details made me feel quite uncomfortable , firstly I didn't realise chewing sugar free gum while fasting would affect me having the radio injection ( which I kept apologising for) she made me feel very awkward ,and uncomfortable mentioning ,it,saying you may not get the injection, it's still food, taking the gum off to show ,telling the man to do a prick finger test ,Then are you claustrophobic to which I said well yes somewhat ,  well will you be able to go through with it , saying something else that I couldn't  really  hear,  To which I said  I have to go through with it ( as I'm getting  checked for cancer)...I get all the questions , It's just they way she was,Doing and  saying it all made me 10 times more nervous than I already was, I'm 56 not a child.. Then after all that I do get the scan,The lady in there was
quite  Ignorant did not say much at all apart from asking my name n dob, I don't understand why these nurses are like this,please strike up some conversation to make us feel comfortable ,it's supposed to be a caring job, they are supposed to make people feel, At ease ,comfortable,calm,  it's a scary thing getting a pet scan .. praises to the gentleman again  ,very nice and pleasant ,that's how everyone  should be ..So not a nice experience for me at all.Yet I have another coming up next week . Im definitely not looking forward ..

Dieses Krankenhaus rettete mir mein Leben.
Bei einen Kurztrip nach London holte ich mir einen Infekt,der auf die Lunge schlug,
Ich wurde dort  künstlich beatmet , ins Koma gelegt und  nach ca.1Woche wieder zurückgeholt.
Das das geklappt hat war aufgrund meiner chronischen Lungenerkrankung nicht selbstverständlich.
Das Personal und die Ärzte waren unfassbar kompetent und fürsorglich.
Meine Lieben durften jederzeit zur mir und wurden toll umsorgt. Es war immer jemand da,der ein offenes Ohr hatte.
Selbst,als ich das Schlimmste überstanden hatte , wurde uns Hilfe angeboten.
Wir hätten jederzeit Kontakt zu einem Psychologen vom Krankenhaus aufnehmen können.
So ,noch nirgendwo erlebt.
Dankeschön ❤️

Very Rude staff (you find one nice between 20 Rude staff) Receptionist, Nurses , senior Doctors….it looks like its a cultural to be very Rude in this Hospital.
I’ve been in so many Hospitals in the US, Italy, France , Even I’ve been in hospitals in middles east (Saudi, Jordan, Egypt, Marocco), Honestly Never in my life I saw such an Extreme Rude staff in my life.

評論內容:
Review of St Thomas’ Hospital, Westminster

St Thomas’ Hospital is one of London’s most well-known and historic medical institutions, dating back to the 12th century. Originally established as a charity hospital, it was later relocated to its current site in Westminster in the 19th century, where it now stands proudly along the River Thames, opposite the Houses of Parliament. The hospital has been at the forefront of medical advancements, playing a key role in modern healthcare and medical training. It is also home to the Florence Nightingale Museum, celebrating the pioneering nurse who reformed hospital care.

Emergency & Specialist Care

St Thomas’ A&E department is a busy, well-equipped unit providing urgent and emergency care for central London. With access to a wide range of specialists, it offers comprehensive treatment, particularly for complex medical cases.

Evelina London Children’s Hospital

Attached to St Thomas’, Evelina London Children’s Hospital is a state-of-the-art paediatric centre offering world-class care for children. With its unique design and child-friendly environment, it provides specialist treatment, including critical care, surgery, and long-term condition management.

Intensive Care Excellence

St Thomas’ has a highly regarded intensive care unit (ICU), catering to some of the most critically ill patients. It boasts advanced facilities, including a dedicated high-dependency unit (HDU) and specialist support for major trauma, cardiac, and respiratory cases.

Overall Verdict

St Thomas’ combines a rich history with modern medical excellence, making it one of London’s top hospitals for emergency, paediatric, and intensive care. Its riverside location adds to its unique presence in the city, but more importantly, it continues to uphold a reputation for delivering high-quality, patient-centred care.

評論內容:
Recently had cause to visit A&E, and when I saw the queue at the door I was a bit put off but going home wasn't an option unfortunately.  Guy came along the queue periodically to check everyone was where they needed to be which I think was helpful.
Waited about 25 minutes to get to the triage nurses.  My nurse was very nice and very thorough.  You then sit and wait for the admin people to call you over and to check your details are correct on their system.  Waited only two or three minutes for the next guy to call me over.  While waiting, overheard the first nurse on the phone notifying someone I needed to be seen urgently.  Admin guy called me over, again very nice and friendly, told me he would be quick because someone was waiting to take me 'through'.  Finished with him and another nurse appeared seconds later to to take me through to the bowels of A&E where I was on a bed in a pod in what seemed no more that 10 minutes of having spoken to the first nurse.

I was then attended to throughout my stay by a series of staff who, without exception provided outstanding care and consideration.  I don't know whether its even called customer service in a heathcare setting, but for want of a better phrase I will use that. Just exceptional customer service.

The staff were attentive, they all introduced themselves, explained who they were and what they would be going to do.  They all did it, so I'm guessing this is down to good training.

I'd been there before for a similar problem, so I had an idea about how the problem had been fixed previously.  I was able to discuss this and how the treatment would be approached this time, my views were taken on board.  I know this isn't always something that's possible, but it was good to know that the doctors were happy to listen and to take on board patient views.

There were so many places I would rather have been than in hospital with kidney failure, but really there is nothing more the hospital could have done to make by stay there more bearable.

The care from the staff was exemplary.

Disgusting behaviour from someone who is meant to help. We were then called by a lovely lady who took the bloods and made my mum feel comfortable as she did it. She told us we would get some pain relief and anti sickness when we came out and still after 3 hours nothing was given even thought asked for a million times. The receptions make you feel like a right burden

評論內容:
Subject: Heartfelt Thanks to the Teams at St Thomas’ Hospital and Guy’s Hospital

Dear St Thomas’ and Guy’s Hospital Teams,

I am writing to express my deepest gratitude for the exceptional care I received during my recent visit. I initially went to the emergency department at St Thomas’ Hospital with severe kidney pain, where I was thoroughly examined and then transferred to Guy’s Hospital.

I regret that I cannot remember the names of everyone who helped me, but I want to extend my sincere thanks to each person involved in my care. From the cleaning staff to the nurses, nursing aides, medical assistants, and doctors, everyone was attentive, professional, and compassionate. I felt truly looked after and welcomed by all.

A special thanks goes to Katarina Spurna, who on my last day provided me with all the information I needed with patience and kindness. Her support meant a lot to me, and I am immensely grateful.

Thank you to the entire team at both St Thomas’ Hospital and Guy’s Hospital for your dedication and care. Your kindness made a difficult time much easier, and I will always be thankful for that.

Warmest regards,
[Rafael Donatão]

I recently had the pleasure of being treated by Dr. Emily Howell at St. Thomas Hospital, and I wanted to express my heartfelt gratitude for the exceptional care I received. After a previous visit two months ago due to kidney stones, I returned on January 1, 2025, experiencing pain and discomfort.

Dr. Emily Howell, who specializes in otolaryngology, was incredibly attentive and thorough in her approach. She conducted the necessary tests and clinical examinations with great care. She carefully examined my abdomen, checking for any abnormalities, and took the time to ensure I felt comfortable throughout the process.

What stood out most was Dr. Emily Howell’s kindness, patience, and genuine concern for my well-being. Her dedication to her patients is evident, and I truly appreciate the respect and compassion she showed me during my visit.

I am deeply thankful for professionals like Dr. Emily Howell, who go above and beyond to provide excellent care. We need more healthcare providers with such a strong commitment to their patients. Thank you, Dr. Emily Howell, for your outstanding service and for making a difference in the lives of those you treat.

Regards

Rafael Donatão

評論內容:
I must caveat this regretful review with the fact this is not about the UCH Cancer Hospital, nor those who were tasked with my sadly now-deceased Mother's care prior to Monday 6 October, 2025.  This review is specifically about the horrendous neglect, negligence, dereliction of duty, and cruel treatment at the hands of the Head Nurse and another nurse (B.) during the day shift on Monday 6 October, on the 8th floor of the main hospital (T-8).

We had taken my Mum to UCLH's emergency care department on Thursday 2 October, 2025.  She was seen as a matter of urgency and it was discovered that she had dangerously low sodium levels.  She was treated with the utmost care, and her sodium levels recovered and the specialists were optimistic that she would be able to come home after around three to four days.

My Mum was then moved to the 8th floor, T-8, the respiratory ward, where she was cared for attentively and compassionately by dedicated nurses.  This very unfortunately changed for the very worst on Monday 6 October.  The Head Nurse and the nurse B. ignored my Mother when she was in pain, skipped her medicines or had administered them at the wrong time.  They "forgot" to administer vital anti-fungal treatment, which played a role in the development of the eventually-fatal infection which took my Mother's life. At dinner time, both the Head Nurse and B. were engaging in laughter and small talk with other patients whilst my Mum coughed blood and was crying in agony.  When I approached B. for assistance, she crudely remarked that my Mum is being cared for by a nurse on another ward and told me to wait.  That nurse, R., when he eventually turned up much later, was also dismissive, rude and arrogant.  That evening, I was told to go home, but I was very concerned for my Mum.  The nurse, R., dismissed me and said, roughly paraphrased: "Your Mum is fine and you are welcome to sleep on the pavement outside the hospital if you are that concerned".  One hour later, I'm informed that my Mum is being taken to Intensive Care/Critical Care and I rushed back to the hospital after taking the train home to Broxbourne.

Despicable treatment.  I'm so sorry that my Mum had to suffer at their hands during the last few days of her life.

On a more positive note, I wanted to thank the lovely gentleman Dr Papadatos-Pastos for the affection, conscientious care and optimism he injected into my dear Mother's life.  A wonderful, dedicated person who is an immense credit to his profession.  My Mother was so grateful to him.  Also, thank you to the UCLH staff who cared for my Mum prior to Monday 6 October, and to the Critical Care staff.  It's a damned and unforgivable shame that the Head Nurse, B. and R. on the day shift of Monday 6 October, 2025, were so utterly awful, neglectful, mean-spirited and cold towards my Mother, and had ignored their duties to my Mum whilst they were laughing with the other patients.  I will never forgive or forget.

I'm grateful to those at UCLH who cared for my Mother with dedication, kindness and love.  My review is not aimed at you.

Love you always and forever, my precious Mother.  I'm so sorry it ended this way.  You deserved so much better.

評論內容:
First of all, If I could 0 stars I would.

When I first arrived at the University College Hospital, I was already very stressed because my GP had called the hospital and referred me there, saying my toe might be broken. As soon as I entered, I was confused because the sign near the reception area said “Car Park,” so I wasn’t sure where exactly I should go. I was speaking with my partner to figure it out when a short-haired woman with brown hair — a staff member at the front desk — spoke to me in a very rude manner. She said something like, “So, are you going to register or what?” in a harsh tone.

Even though I was clearly in pain and shaking from stress, her behaviour didn’t change. When I explained that a doctor had referred me and called the hospital, instead of listening, she mocked me and laughed, saying, “What do you mean someone called you? So you came here because ‘someone’ called you?” I found this very humiliating and unprofessional, especially considering I was in distress and seeking urgent care.

So after this really bad reception experience,
I sat down and waited, still feeling extremely anxious and in pain. No one clearly explained what would happen next or how long I was supposed to wait. I had arrived around 8 PM, but I didn’t leave the hospital until almost 2 AM. Around 1 AM, I was finally called in. Despite clearly seeing that I couldn’t walk properly, no one offered me any help or even held my hand to support me. Everyone was just watching while I struggled to walk on my injured foot a distance that would normally take 5 seconds took me about 5 minutes. I found this absolutely unacceptable and extremely upsetting. When I finally reached the room, the doctor who had previously spoken to me on the phone for a long time and told me I would get an X-ray, looked at my foot and said, “Do you want an X-ray? Because I think it might be fractured.” I said yes, and he told me to wait outside again. I then had to walk all the way back to the waiting area again, completely unaided, limping and in pain, wearing only one shoe and one sock.

After about another 10–15 minutes of waiting, I was called for the X-ray. Once again, I had to walk there on my own. The X-ray was done, and I was told everything seemed normal. But again, nobody helped me on my way back — I had to walk all the way to the waiting room alone.

About 15 minutes later, the results came back, and I was called in one last time. I walked there by myself once more, and that’s when they finally told me that I actually had a hairline fracture in my toe.

The entire experience was exhausting, painful, and emotionally distressing. I cannot believe that a patient with a visible walking difficulty was made to move around repeatedly without any assistance for hours.

So basically, I had to wait for almost 8 hours, sitting there with a broken toe, and I wasn’t offered any kind of help or support during that entire time.

評論內容:
My husband Devon started admission into UCLH and Hospital for Neurology from December 2024 and had a very rare illness that the doctors found very difficult to diagnose.  He was treated well sometimes and mistreated sometimes.

Some of the nurses, healtcare assistants and support workers,  mostly from African countries,  were nice and did the job out of passion while some were just about the money or opportunity and could not care less.

He was in and out of hospital and from April to July 2025, his condition worsened and so he had to remain in UCLH without any discharge from April to July.  Now that's a very long time to be in hospital.

He was on one on one and I want to commend the Good Healthcare Assistants like HCA Esther, HCA Kate from Neurology who sometimescame over to cover in UCLH, Support Worker Aziz and that Lovely Yoruba female Support Worker, I cant remember your name.  You guys really took care of Devon and made sure that he was ok and i really appreciate you all.  Thank you so much.

To the other good Nurses, Healthcare Assistants, Dieticians, Food Servers, Ward Managers & Managing Assistants and Doctors & Junior Doctors who made sure that Devon did not suffer, A special thanks to you all as well.

To the African Support Workers and Cleaners who thought that intimidating and humiliating Devon because he had no control over his bowels after the near death experience and had to wear pampers or sometimes could not help the accidents that he did on himself or shouted at him asking him why did he have the accident or forced him to clean it up by himself,  knowing his poor condition,  I hope that one day, you yourselves get to experience the same things that you put Devon through.

It was so inhumane, so cruel, so wicked to shout at a very ill man for doing a number 2 in his pampers because he could  not control his bowel or humiliating him to the point that he became so scared that he would quickly try to clean up the floor himself fearing that humiliation, even to the point that he passed out on the floor a few times.  He reported it, absolutely nothing was done about it.

You guys thought that Devon was in hospital too long and so after some time, you started mistreating him.  With the exception of the few that were mentioned before.  You all wanted him out at any cost and made his life miserable......this is a very ill man who had a very active life before becoming ill, was never lazy.  I wonder where your conscience are.  Do you guys not have father's, brothers, uncles, husbands?

UCLH is one of the best hospitals in London,  I do agree.  However,  with just a few horrible staff that has no passion for the job and just there for opportunity or money, the standards of the hospital will go very low very quickly.

If you dont have a passion for caring, you cannot care for another.  I know this as I myself,  I'm also in the health sector.  Alot of you are inhumane and because of your background,  despite this is UK, where things are done differently,  some of you still carry this bad background with you even here in UK and it's so bad.

If someone is ill, that person should be made to feel better and not worse, not intimidated or humiliated when you are being paid to do the job.  Why are you there if you don't like it?  For opportunity? For money?  That is not cool.  Not cool at all!

評論內容:
Autonomic Unit (UCLH):

For three decades, I've been consistently denied access to the NHS despite suffering from a severe and rare degenerative disorder that triggers cardiac arrest. Initially evaluated by an expert Prof Christopher Mathias at the Autonomic Unit in University College London Hospital (UCLH) back in 1996, a critical misdiagnosis prevented me from being referred to other consultants. Consequently, despite residing permanently in the UK, I've had to seek healthcare abroad. This disorder necessitates a specialised treatment available at the UCLH's (Autonomic Unit), a treatment administered to other patients but inexplicably withheld from me, a clear case of discrimination.

For 25 years, I've been importing and using this treatment as prescribed by other consultants, yet my rightful access to it via the NHS has been consistently denied. Despite raising a complaint with the Parliament Health and Social Ombudsman (PHSO), it was summarily dismissed following extensive email correspondence. I also sought assistance from my local MP, Zarah Sultana, who regrettably chose to ignore my pleas even a request to bring attention to my case in Parliament was disregarded.

The PHSO's actions unmistakably shielded UCLH, masking their failures with a litany of falsehoods and perjury, all in violation of my human and patient rights. Their consistent downplaying of the severity of my situation further compounds the issue. Over 30 years, I've been unjustly denied critical NHS treatment, revealing the PHSO's shortcomings in legality, flexibility, transparency, fairness, and accountability. Their bias in favour of the NHS, working to conceal its errors, is evident and disappointing.

It's a disgraceful display from an organization expected to champion patient rights and stand against the abuse and neglect perpetrated by the NHS. My story will soon find its place on a website and in a forthcoming book, adopting a style that calls out individuals and institutions responsible naming and shaming!

評論內容:
Having been to UCLH’s A & E several times now to accompany my 90 year-old mother, I can write with some experience that it has reached abysmal levels (last visit June 2025). With all due caveats that services are overstretched, it the normalisation of certain conditions and behaviours that is abhorrent. The Majors waiting room is absurdly small, the size you might expect in a small provincial hospital and not in London.
Consequently, they ban the presence of any patients’ relatives there, in my mother’s case this results in a very elderly, almost deaf and cognitively confused person with heart failure being left alone in a frightening environment, cruel in the extreme and counterproductive as fear and stress result in worse outcomes. It is shameful that there is no option for such patients to be accompanied by a carer/relative.
During the 8 hours that she was waiting there, first she then I approached the staff to enquire when she would be seen following her scan. Long story short, they give you literally the same meaningless answer to fob you off (‘about an hour and a half’) and by the end of those hours it is revealed how meaningless those dismissals are, not borne of real feedback from the relevant departments but just designed to get rid of you – one nurse literally rolled her eyes at her mother. Meanwhile another four hours pass and whenever one addresses the staff, even to request a spartan tray of food they simply stonewall you or give you a variation of the abovementioned dismissal.
Apart from these A&E visits, on two separate occasions earlier this year when my mother was an inpatient, we had encounters with two shockingly rude and incompetent nurses.
There’s a lot of signage at the hospital about ‘kindness’ and talk in general of abuse towards NHS staff and, while obviously that is inexcusable, the NHS urgently need to examine their own behaviour and the damage and alienation of patients they are causing. I’m saddened but not surprised at the quantity of bad reviews here that testify to these problems being widespread but the hospital seems to take no notice.

評論內容:
I came here today in urgent need of support and psychiatric care, and the experience was shocking. There were no clear signs to the actual psychiatric ward, and I had to ask multiple times (at least five) before anyone even considered letting me speak to a psychiatrist.

The nurses seemed more interested in socialising with each other than actually supporting patients in crisis. I waited over four hours and was never seen by a doctor. The lack of compassion, professionalism, and urgency was appalling.

This hospital desperately needs new management. The current staff come across as rude, dismissive, and completely uninterested in patient wellbeing. For a place meant to provide care, the neglect here is unacceptable.

The staff were some of the worst I’ve ever encountered—rude and completely uncaring, regardless of how much pain you’re in. Today I had an appointment with a cardiologist for which I have been waiting for 10 months and when I checked in at the reception they told me that the clinic would not be open due to a strike by young doctors....???? No one bothered to inform me and give me a new appointment, not to mention that I feel very bad, my health has deteriorated while waiting , thanks to their irresponsibility towards patients and because someone is sleeping and they don't care about patient health.... I ask the managers of this hospital, since you demand respect from patients for your doctors, shouldn't you demand respect from doctors for patients????? Their attitude and neglect of the patient can sometimes cost someone's life and then when they say sorry, will the problem be solved, will they return the patient's health... I apologize for the expression but this is, for me, impudence, unacceptable attitude on the part of doctors, they are very concerned about their rights and salaries, but apparently the rights and health of the patient is their last concern....
Today I wasted half my day without getting help and without visiting the doctor, and I ask why your employees decided that their time is more valuable than mine and are so irresponsible and rude to patients??? When today the employee I spoke to to make a new appointment for my doctor's appointment, besides not introducing herself, did not even bother to apologize for what happened... so before you demand respect from patients, teach your staff to behave with respect towards them... Thank you very much for the unpleasant experience you subjected me to today....

評論內容:
I've been a patient at UCLH for around 7 years now - and I'm just consistently surprised and amazed at how good the quality of care broadly is. In contrast to most NHS care I've received over the years, with the exception of my current GP, UCLH stands out as truly exceptional. The staff are frequently polite and caring, everyone has a good sense of humour to them, administratively things rarely go wrong for me, and the level of expertise and insight is really quite impressive. On several occasions they have diagnosed things for me that are in active research at the University and at the hospital. So incredibly grateful for this hospital and its staff. The pharmacy is also really proactive and quick to turn around prescriptions. The canteen staff are also really lovely and kind patients who require that little extra bit of assistance. At times both my partner and I have needed additional support from all different facets of the hospital including its facilities teams and the catering staff. Thank you once again for being amazing.

Also just wanted to give a quick shout out to Janet C. in the outpatients reception for being so kind and affirmative with my change of details 🏳️‍⚧️ such a wonderful human 🥰

評論內容:
For anyone having to go through the muchly feared gastroscopy and colonoscopy (on the same day), go to UCLH Euston Road hospital and you´ll be in good, safe and painless hands. I was scared to have these procedures done in my 30s - I was scared of the procedure itself but also for the results. I asked from some of the staff beforehand if they had gone through the procedures themselves so I could get honest opinions on what to expect (didn´t quite buy to my British friends repeatedly saying "you´ll be fine"). I asked about the different types of sedatives and numbing options and with the level of anxiety and fears I had beforehand I think moderate sedation was the perfect choice for me. I needed my body to be calm because I couldn´t calm it down the way that I would have wanted to. If I only had gastroscopy I think the numbing spray would have done it as it is SUPER EFFECTIVE but again with the level of my anxiety I am glad I chose sedation because I did not even realise that it was done. After I was given the mouth guard, the sedation was injected and the next thing I heard was "that´s gastroscopy done" and I was like really? And from the papers I can see it only took 3 minutes. So honestly it was nothing!
The colonoscopy was a bit more challenging BUT just because I had adhesions (which none of us could have known beforehand) - I remember two points where the pain was like a sudden pinch inside me but they got me talking about Lapland and northern lights and soon I was out of it all even realising what they were doing. At one point I even opened my eyes to look at the monitor and realised the room was dark and it was all pretty calming. So yes I was aware but no I could not feel much and I am honestly, positively surprised about how easy the whole thing was. The colonoscopy itself had lasted 16min for me and I was in the recovery before I even noticed.
The staff was super lovely and they were gentle like they had promised to. Choose sedation if you´re scared and rest assured the prep is a lot harder than the procedure itself!

BIG BIG THANK YOU TO:
List Consultant: Richard COHEN
Nurse Endoscopist: Dashnee NAIDOO
Endoscopy HealthCare Assistant: Felisa SISON
Endoscopy Nurse: Frances JOSEPH; Zainudin ISMAIL

<3

評論內容:
I was treated by doctors R Dixon and consultant V Schueler. Both were excellent.
I had an MRI scan that showed the problem. It was explained clearly and considerately by Dr Schueler.
There was a long wait, (only 15 minutes for triage) about 3 hours till I saw Dr Dixon - then the scan and diagnosis took my whole visit to about 6 hours.
BUT ! - it's an A&E department in the middle of one of the biggest cities in the world. Of course it's busy. They have more patients in need than staff to help them. The underfunding and attempted dismantlement of this beautiful service by previous governments is the cause of that. The doctors, porters, reception staff, everyone who actually works there did a brilliant job. They are amazing people.
And if you are unfortunate enough to have to sit in A&E here or anywhere, waiting in pain, it's not their fault.
I watched as I waited and I saw dozens of people doing their jobs, calmly, and as quickly as possible without ever stopping.
They are doing and giving the very best they can under a relentless pressure that's not of their making. Day after day, year after year.

I send them all my love and thanks.

(But I still hope I don't have to go back soon 😂)

評論內容:
I visited UCLH A&E due to a knee issue. The wait was extremely long — I arrived at 11 p.m. and wasn’t seen until 9 a.m. If your condition is not urgent, be prepared to wait even up to 8 hours. It can be exhausting, so patience is essential.

That said, once I was admitted, the care I received was outstanding. The staff were kind, thorough, and incredibly attentive to every detail. I felt well looked after and truly cared for throughout.

A heartfelt thank you to Joana, Izzy, Sunny, and everyone else who assisted me — apologies for the names I’ve forgotten, but I’m grateful to all of you. I left feeling confident and well supported.

Thank you, UCLH!

評論內容: Anyone who is a parent and have had a moment of vulnerability, do not attend the UCL A&E at all cost. As a mother, I attended UCL A&E for a check-up following consumption of UCL prescribed medication and experiencing effects. Instead of prioritising a full and proper assessment of my physical health, they swiftly escalated to child protection, inferred that I had a mental illness, and inferred that I was a risk to my children. Despite assuming I was doing the right thing for my health, UCL A&E staff passed judgement on me without any prior assessment of my health, and jumped straight onto needing child protection. They further shared my details to my local authority without prior discussion with me about what it is they felt was necessary, the analysis which underpinned this, or sought my consent. I was sent to a place of fear for my children, and no mother should ever be placed in this position. I always understood the hospital as a place of safety, empathy, and care. However, this experience proved I can never prioritise my health by attending a hospital again.

評論內容:
Used to be a great place for care, I am not sure what happened during the last few years but now the emergency services are dangerous, they lie in your reports over and over, I thought it was only my case but reading other comments it seems common practice.

If you been referred for basic control tests (ultrasound, bloods, etc), you will have a good level of care. But if something goes wrong ... no follow-up, lies, changes of shift and nobody is held accountable.

I was suggested by an UCLH doctor to take up my case to PALS, so even them may be fed-up of the situation. We all should write to our local MPs

評論內容:
Drs have the power of the pen. They can write anything because of their position.  No one question or investigates. Complaints go to PALs bounce around. But there is no black bocks system to monitor or record the  accountability of the Dr, nurse or other staffs behaviour, errors, and mistakes or poor experience of patient where lives are affected or die because of errors and wrongly diagnosed or no treatment.

I have had extremely poor care and extremely excellent care..On one occasion I had a fall from a height which resulted in me landing on ametal  radiator on my head I spent one night in hospital and was sent home with an okay , exerxray fine Years later Complaints of headaches and light sensitively.  I requested my hospital notes and was shocked....very shocked
To find out I have had swelling of the brain and a fracture.  No one told me.

Another aweful experience of iron infusion, given an antisickness medication not suitable for heart patient and administered fourced when manufacture say administer slowly. I had a serious reaction heart rate went to 180. Nurse told me to go home. I spent years writing back and forth. No one held accountable. I attended another hospital who immediately admitted me in and treated me.

I get a call to attend hospital could be life threatening.  I need an urgent MRI something found on previous results if I don't attend could be fatal. I rush to hospital do the MRI and there is no one to guide me.report to in fact I get results months later..

Blue lights by ambulance to hospital with Colvid. I must have been at the hospital  about an hour with Serious symptoms and an xray taken.
Shoo out. I get a call after being sent home what is my oxygen rate. By now 77. I am blue lighted again..I request my medical notes only to find.
My lunges were.affected by the Colvid. The x-ray showed in particular it was very white with a severe acute infection.  So why was I sent home. Knowing I was severe. It never came to.light.

I have had a thyroid storm and a wrong diagnosis of tonsillitis

I could go on with the lengthy shocking alarming misdiagnosis  of treatment.
I  have also experienced alarming rude offensive behaviour from Dr's and nurses.  One wonders why they choose to work with people with such appalling attitudes. You can't  teach respect, care  empathy or understanding.
NHS Is failing many patients.

評論內容: I want to thank the A&E staff of University College Hospital for being absolutely fantastic yesterday. They put me on a drip to get fluids into me and it helped me so much. I was further impressed by the cleanliness of the facilities and the calm of the staff. It was a very good environment to be in. I have been in other A&E departments in the past and have had a very different experience. I am very grateful, thank you so much.

評論內容:
Extremely disappointed with the follow-up care at UCLH Brock Street following my hand injury on 1st April 2025. After being referred for an MRI/ultrasound, I attended three separate appointments on 4th April, 25th April, and 2nd May — all during working hours — only to be told each time that my scan hadn’t been booked due to internal errors.

Each time I waited for over an hour, only to leave with nothing resolved. Staff admitted the mistakes and even gave me a written acknowledgment, but the same problem keeps happening. As of 2nd May, I still don’t have a confirmed MRI appointment — over a month since my injury.

This experience has wasted hours of my time, caused unnecessary stress, and left my injury undiagnosed. UCLH really needs to fix its communication and patient coordination systems. This level of disorganisation is unacceptable, especially at a major hospital.

評論內容:
I had an amazing three-week stay and truly appreciated the care I received. The room was clean, comfortable, and felt like a safe space during a difficult time. The nurses were incredibly friendly, compassionate, and always went the extra mile to make me feel supported. The doctors were thorough, kind, and made sure I understood everything clearly.

I was diagnosed with TB during my stay, which was overwhelming at first, but the entire team helped me feel informed and cared for every step of the way.

A special thank-you to Nurses Sofiya and Stephanie—these two incredible women treated me like a sister. Their kindness, warmth, and personal care made a big difference and brought so much comfort to my days.

Also, I have to mention—the tomato soup and tomato pasta were absolutely delicious! I enjoyed them so much that I had them almost every day. It’s the little things like that that made my stay even more comforting.

Thank you to the entire team for making a difficult time so much easier. I’ll always be grateful for your support and care.

評論內容:
I attended UCLH Emergency Department on 24/04/2025 with a documented MRI-confirmed spinal emergency and multiple red flag symptoms, including:
Bladder dysfunction
Progressive leg weakness and numbness
Saddle anesthesia
Cyanotic foot
MRI-confirmed L5/S1 disc herniation with S1 root compression
Despite this, I was discharged without neurosurgical escalation, no treatment, and no real plan.
You refused to help me.
I was not “just another patient.” I presented with a condition that should have triggered immediate surgical action. I was failed. I would like my experience to be remembered clearly and officially as a case where a patient with a neurological emergency was sent away, left to deteriorate, and put at risk of lifelong disability.
You may not have helped me but at the very least, I demand that this is acknowledged and never repeated with another patient.
You will be hearing from legal and regulatory bodies in due course attended !

評論內容:
visited the A&E at University College Hospital with severe neurological symptoms, including urinary retention, numbness, and leg weakness — clear red flags for Cauda Equina Syndrome.

Despite the urgency of my condition, I felt ignored and dismissed. I was in extreme pain, unable to walk properly, and yet no decisive action was taken.
No urgent MRI was arranged at that time, and I was not referred promptly for surgery.

As a result, my condition worsened. I am now at risk of permanent disability. This is not how emergency care should function — especially for a patient presenting with textbook emergency spinal symptoms.

評論內容:
Today I brought my daughter Sophia to the Pediatric Department at University College London Hospital because she had been experiencing persistent head pain after being accidentally hit on the head by a gymnastics hoop during training.

We were warmly welcomed by two incredible doctors — the beautiful Dr. Chloe Davies and the handsome Dr. Benjamin. They were not only highly professional and efficient, but also exceptionally kind and patient with my daughter.

What touched us the most was how they made the entire experience feel so comfortable and relaxed — my daughter didn’t even feel like she was visiting a hospital. Instead, she felt happy, calm, and completely at ease throughout the whole process.

These two doctors are truly among the best we’ve ever met — like guardian angels. We give them a full five-star rating and are sincerely grateful for their outstanding care and support.

評論內容: Went to A&E yesterday about 4:30pm with tightening and pain at 20 weeks pregnant. I had history of premature labour, our baby died 2 days after. The guy nurse (with shaved head) who saw me just to check my o2 saturation was the most un empathic nurse i have met ( i am also a nurse). Didnt even bother to check my Obs. He advised me to go to EPA which he said will be closed in 20min, so I told him with my.condition, I cant walk that fast and if I go there and they are closed, he said to just come back to A&E. The A&E was full, ended up just standing there waiting to be seen by the dr, nobody cared from their staffs. So decided to walk to the other side of the building to EPU only to find out the nurse didnt exactly know what he was talking. It should be MFAU so have to walk again to that department. Appalled by the service from A&E and how these medical staffs does not care.

評論內容: Went here for a life threatening allergic reaction and they did NOTHING! If I could give zero stars I would. The care I received here was absolutely appalling and the staff were completely rude and negligent. I was sent here after going to urgent care after having an allergic reaction and self administering an epi-pen. Unbeknownst to me the intake person wrote "sore throat" on my paperwork when I was having full on anaphylaxis an hour prior. This unacceptable error that the intake person made resulted in me not being seen for over 6 hours which is completely unacceptable when being faced with a life threatening emergency. I also have a tachycardia disorder which makes it incredibly dangerous for me to not be monitored after using an epi-pen. The doctor who did finally see me was incredibly rude. I was never asked about any medical history or allergies. I had told him that in addition to my allergy concerns I was having excruciating ear pain and that I have a history of eustachian tube dysfunction and had multiple ear surgeries as a child.  The doctor blatantly ignored this and diagnosed me with an ear infection WITHOUT even looking at my ears. He completely brushed over all my allergy concerns and then left after speaking to me for all of about two minutes. When the nurse came to give me antibiotics and painkillers I explained to her how I thought it was unacceptable how none of my medical history or issues were addressed and I was just diagnosed with an ear infection. The nurse then went to speak to the doctor. The doctor came back in to protest and was completely irritated and offended that I would possibly ask him to look at my ears before diagnosing me with an ear infection. He then looked in my ear for all of about 2 seconds and sarcastically proceeded to say "like I said earlier, it's an ear infection". I then went home at 4 in the morning. By some miracle I managed to get an ENT follow up with a specialist at Wellington hospital. As it turns out I did not have an ear infection. The ENT specialist confirmed that throat swelling from the allergic reaction had caused my eustachian tube to swell resulting in an ear drum rupture which was causing the pain. No surprise that I was misdiagnosed considering the front desk person cannot decipher or distinguish the word anaphylaxis from "sore throat". It is also shocking that someone with a medical degree can't possibly comprehend that you cannot accurately diagnose a patient with an infection by guessing. Had UCL hospital actually been competent and had I been treated right away for this potentially life threatening emergency with IV epinephrine and a steroid treatment for the swelling, I could have avoided a ruptured eardrum. Avoid this hospital at all costs.

評論內容:
Staff are extremely dismissive of symptoms, lack of communication between staff and patients - and on my last visit today it was absolutely filthy. I thought awaiting for test results and maybe further meds, a nurse who had NOT treated me walked into my cubical and told me I had to leave the room? I questioned this and told her I was waiting for results and the dr. She then proceeded to tell me I wasn’t waiting for testing results, no meds, no nothing? the nurse was done with me and I was to go to see GP - I proceeded to thank the the Dr that treated me and left the hospital, still having serious chest pains and unable to speak properly. I was scared and angry and all I could think of was getting home.

MyChart then sent a notification saying that I had ‘Walked Out’ ~ what an absolute joke!!  I was told to leave and see my GP! 🤯 the Dr that declared I had ’walked out’ was the same one I thanked…  his name was Agron Galicia how can u acknowledge a thank you while someone’s leaving and not stop them when they are clearly distressed and in pain??? What sort of Professional person treats someone like that - disgusting NEVER AGAIN

Had the misfortune of having to visit this hospital a number of times in the last year or so and with each visit I wish I never bothered. One time I was laying on the floor in a&e for 14hrs - one A&E nurse looked down at me ‘alright down there are we?? Laughed and walked off .. never to be seen again - I was waiting for an MRI 😒
***Avoid avoid avoid****

Went to A&E, was sent home with no blood tests done or scans. When looking at notes the next day the doctor who examined me wrote “patient refused blood test” I was not offered one in the first place.
My notes said I needed blood test, CT scan and to see a neurologist. And I got none.

I was in for severe migraines that I’ve had for 5 days now and the sumatriptan I was prescribed was not working so it seems I may have meningitis or sepsis, or possibly a brain tumour. I was not handled correctly.
I waited 5 hours to be seen, to be told “you should maybe changing your pillow, and you should try to sleep better” but I am in pain non stop with severe symptoms and can’t sleep. Overall, useless doctors. Don’t even bother wasting your time.

評論內容: I was referred to UCLH for IVF treatment, and unfortunately, the experience has been quite disappointing due to the lack of effective communication channels with the nursing staff. Communication is limited to email and voicemail, with the voicemail system often being full, making it impossible to leave a message. Additionally, email responses are not immediate, sometimes taking up to two days, and in some cases, emails deemed unimportant go unanswered entirely. This lack of responsiveness is particularly frustrating and distressing given the already stressful nature of undergoing IVF treatment. The quality of service has been far below expectations in such a sensitive and emotionally demanding process.

評論內容:
Last night 15th of December, I had a very bad experience with shortness of breath, I have asthma and had to go to the emergency. I was incredibly well taken care of, from the reception staff to the nurses. One of the nurses, I believe his name was Yahon, was outstanding. The doctors and nurses every single one of them, were amazing, and I am so grateful.

I was seen very quickly despite my serious condition. They ran tests, gave me inhalation treatments, and did everything possible to help me. Thanks to their care, I was able to come back home feeling so much better.

I want to sincerely thank the hospital staff for their quick, precise, and compassionate care. I am truly satisfied with the work of the medical team. Keep up the great work!

Neurology dept sent my 24 hr bp machine to an address I haven’t lived at in over 10 years!
I was notified by someone who knows my Brother after 2 weeks!
The Lady who lives in my old house was on holiday so gave it to a cafe in the town
It’s 30 mins away, I’m disabled and can’t drive so had to wait for my Husband to be available to take me
Woman was rude about it

Gastro have failed me lately too, consultant diagnosed me then a Nurse said diagnosis was wrong! Sent me home with treatment, treatment failed
Didn’t call on several occasions when appointment was booked
Found out from my GP lately I was discharged… zero explanation!!

Used to be one of the worlds best hospitals especially for rare things like mine… not any more!

評論內容: UCLH was once regarded as one of the best hospitals, but in recent years, the quality of patient care has significantly declined. 評論內容: Unbelievably grateful for this hospital, it’s cliche but they saved my life. I dismissed my chest pain for several hours and when i went to A+E every single member of staff was nothing short of incredible and compassionate. I was immediately taken back for an ECG, bloods, chest x-ray and a CT scan. The rest of the day was spent in majors with a fantastic doctor who listened to me, took a full medical history and genuinely cared for her patients. I was very apprehensive before going to hospital, concerned that as a young woman my pain wouldn’t be taken seriously, but they went above and beyond to reassure me and cared for me. The doctor I saw diagnosed me with a severe post operative infection and without her help I would not be alive. I cannot express my gratitude enough to all the staff involved in my care and how quickly they saw and cared for me!
